[h1]Mafia II: Definitive Edition - A Timeless Crime Classic Reborn[/h1]

[quote][b]"Forget about loyalty. It's a luxury you can't afford in this line of work." - Vito Scaletta[/b][/quote]

Mafia II: Definitive Edition throws you headfirst into the world of organized crime in 1940s America. You take on the role of Vito Scaletta, a young Italian-American man who gets entangled with the mob after a chance encounter. The story follows Vito's rise through the ranks of the family, navigating a world of violence, betrayal, and the allure of easy money.

[h2]Story: A Gripping Gangster Tale[/h2]

Mafia II's narrative is a rollercoaster ride of action, suspense, and emotional gut punches. The characters, from the hot-headed Joe Barbaro to the stoic Leo Galante, are well-developed and memorable, each with their own motivations and flaws. The dialogue is sharp and witty, peppered with profanity that feels true to the era and the characters' world. While the story might not break new ground, it's a well-told gangster tale that keeps you engaged from start to finish. Don't expect choices with branching paths, but the consequences of your actions play out in subtle ways, adding a layer of weight to your decisions.

[h2] Gameplay: A Familiar Sandbox with a Fresh Coat of Paint[/h2]

The core gameplay of Mafia II: Definitive Edition is a familiar mix of driving, shooting, and exploration. You'll spend your time cruising the streets of Empire Bay, a fictional city inspired by New York, Chicago, and Los Angeles, completing missions for the mob. The combat is satisfyingly brutal, with a focus on headshots and taking cover. While the mission design might feel slightly repetitive at times, especially escort and chase sequences, the story and characters keep things interesting.

The Definitive Edition shines in its visual overhaul. The game looks great, with detailed environments, character models, and lighting effects, but it's not the overhaul we saw in Mafia 1: DE. The city feels alive, bustling with activity and capturing the atmosphere of the era. The soundtrack is another highlight, featuring a mix of licensed classics and original scores that perfectly complement the story and setting.

[h2]Sound: Setting the Mood[/h2]

The sound design is equally impressive, with the crackle of gunfire, the roar of engines, and the ambient sounds of the city creating a truly immersive experience. The voice acting is top-notch, with each character delivering their lines with conviction. The soundtrack is a mix of licensed classics from the era, like "In the Mood" by Glenn Miller, and original scores that perfectly set the mood for the story's different moments.

[h2]Overall: A Must-Play for Mob Movie Buffs and Action Fans Alike[/h2]

Mafia II: Definitive Edition is a fantastic remaster that breathes new life into a classic game. The story is still gripping, the characters are memorable, and the gameplay, while familiar, is still enjoyable. The visuals and sound design are top-notch, creating a truly immersive experience. Whether you're a fan of the original game or a newcomer to the world of Mafia, this Definitive Edition is definitely worth checking out.

[b]In short, Mafia II: Definitive Edition is a visually stunning, narratively engaging, and action-packed remake of a classic crime story. Fans of the genre and newcomers alike will find plenty to enjoy in this timeless tale.[/b]

For $29.99 USD at the current price I cannot recommend this game. If you purchase this as part of the Trilogy bundle, then the cost is a bit more digestible as Maria 1 DE far exceeds Mafia 2 DE imo. 

Having never played any of the Mafia Trilogy games when they first came out, the bundle was appealing and I decided to dive in to the franchise. While Mafia 1 DE is a far better remaster, Mafia 2 DE is a step back in nearly all aspects. The story is one of the few bright spots, however, it's very short. I was able to finish the main story on hard mode in about 15 hours and that was even including gathering some of the collectibles, exploring the City, and achievement hunting. It's a very short story and not worth the dollar value per hour of entertainment in my book. 

The game also shows its age in other aspects. The lighting in certain levels was really bad and made some missions artificially more difficult as I struggled to see enemies in darker situations. The take cover, shoot at enemies, and do it over again combat style does get old especially late game. Pacing is also a weak point at times and the end of mission  "drive to your house" portion gets old considering you're usually driving across the map just to sleep in your bed so the next mission will start.  The world also seems a bit empty, even for it's time when you consider GTA4 released in 2008 and this game originally released in 2010. Overall though, if you can scoop this on a sale, I do recommend playing it to experience the story. Just don't expect to be entertained for long.

A Trip Down Memory Lane

Mafia II Definitive Edition brings back the classic mobster tale with upgraded visuals and all the extras. Stepping into the shoes of Vito Scaletta, players get a taste of the 1940s and 50s underworld, complete with a gripping story and authentic atmosphere.

The game nails the nostalgic vibes with attention to detail in graphics, character design, and a killer soundtrack. Vito's journey through the crime world is immersive and engaging, thanks to solid character development and voice acting.

However, a couple of hiccups may bother some players. The saving system can be a pain. Also, the realistic driving, while cool for some, can feel a bit too much for those looking for a smoother ride.

Overall, Mafia II Definitive Edition is a solid choice for fans wanting a refreshed experience and newcomers looking for a taste of mob life. Just watch out for those manual saves and be ready for a realistic, if occasionally slow, drive through the past.

Mafia 2: Definitive Edition is a remastered version of the original Mafia 2 featuring improved graphics and all previously released DLC. However don't expect a huge difference like in the first Mafia from 2002 and its remake. If you somehow skipped Mafia 2 in the past or played the original version but you missed the dlcs you have a good reason to try this,especially if you can get it on a discount. As a warning for those of you who experienced the original ,everything from story to music and collectibles remains untouched so if you'll be disappointed if you wished for new content.

For me this was a chance to revisit Empire Bay again, to step in the shoes of Vito Scarletta and experience his transformation from an ordinary poor kid to a crime boss. In the early years his father decided to move in America to escape poverty but as it turned out the plan didn't work so well. Vito and Joey Barbaro become best friends in a world where poverty made them choose to attempt small heists like the jewelry shop rob. Unfortunately Vito is caught and offered a choice to avoid prison and enlist in the army and this is how his transformation process begins. On his return he had a choice to respect his mother will and live a lawful life or follow his buddy steps and become involved with the mafia. However doing slave labour work like his father did for the same man at the docks and discovering a 2000 dollars debt his family had for a loan shark was the trigger Vito needed to make his choice.

This was just the introduction for a great story which follows Vito Scarletta and his rise through the ranks of criminal organizations,his struggle for a better life and a beautiful friendship with Joey Barbaro.  Speaking of Joey, he is so great that the game has a dlc where you can play as him. In Joey 's Adventures i had a lot of fun engaging in various missions and activities,set in the time Vito was in prison. 

I had a great time driving around ,listening to music on the radio and somehow the game successfully captures the atmosphere of the 1940's and 1950's in the fictional city of Empire Bay(inspired by real life locations like New York ). 

In a nutshell mafia 2 is one of the best games ever made from my perspective,i strongly recommend playing this if you never did before.

As far back as I can remember, I always wanted to be a gangster. To me, being a gangster was better than being President of the United States. Even before I first wandered into the cabstand for an after-school job, I knew I wanted to be a part of them. It was there that I knew that I belonged. To me, it meant being somebody in a neighborhood that was full of nobodies. They weren't like anybody else. I mean, they did whatever they wanted. They double-parked in front of a hydrant and nobody ever gave them a ticket. In the summer when they played cards all night, nobody ever called the cops.

I have mixed feelings about this game, but I suppose I recommend it overall for anyone who would enjoy a GTA-style action game.  Otherwise, it's not that special.

Before I say anything else, the game is poorly optimized for dual monitors.  I usually play my games on one monitor and have another one to alt-tab into for research or other stuff.  This game cannot fathom dual monitors and the display settings will be hosed.  I had to disable my second monitor, start the game, then re-enable the second monitor and it worked.  Bit of a lousy workaround, if you ask me.

My first dislike was the main character.  I did not find him easy to like or to get behind at all.  He gets in trouble with his friend, serves in the army instead of going to jail, gets back, his happy family isn't good enough for him and he immediately turns to crime again, putting his mom and sister in danger like he didn't learn anything from before.  Could have easily written this idiot better.

The gameplay is what you would expect.  Gang-related shootouts, intimidation, car theft, etc.  Lots of cars to drive, lots of weapons.  All of this is good, but that's about it.

Then, there's the additional content.  If I could review those separately, I would downvote all of them.  Jimmy's Betrayal and Jimmy's Vendetta are just empty shells of a game where you're sent to an arbitrary part of the map to start the mission, after which you're sent somewhere else to do the mission, then you're sent somewhere to end the mission.  I spent 90% of my time driving.  Just wasn't fun.

Joe's Adventures has a little more personality to it, but it was buggy.  I can usually work with buggy, but one mission bugged so much that I couldn't even complete it.  None of the solutions I researched worked.

As I said at the beginning, for those of you who would like a GTA-style action game, this will deliver.  Just play the base game, though.  Don't bother with any of the additional content.

Mafia Definitive Edition was a great remake of its original counterpart. This one was not.

Only improvement it has over the original is the textures. The animations are broken in some cutscenes, the impressive physics the original had when wearing coats, gone, the AI is broken in some moments and the dialog was broken too, as if they were having two dialogues at the same time, with a slight delay on the other. Small objects and some particle effects are completely broken, flickering around. 

Thankfully I don't remember having to pay for the definitive edition separately and the original is still available, included for free when buying this, so kudos to them for that. But the original is even less stable on modern systems and we can be sure they're not updating that one any more.

It's a shame, for once I see Hangar 13 as developers that genuinely care about their fan-base, unlike most companies under Take-Two, judging by the additions they later put into Mafia III after feedback and giving us a full-on remake on a beloved, outdated game from 2002. They just not the best at making games. None of that really applies to whoever they outsourced this remaster to though.
Overall, I'd recommend this game for the main story. The DLC missions kind of suck though.

Pros: The story line is pretty good (if a little classic), the setting and sound are wonderful.

Cons: The game has a lot of glitches (visual glitches, the game stutters on RTX 3070Ti  mobile, the script required to progress doesn't trigger until you redo that part several times etc.) The core gameplay consists of too much going from point A to point B over and over again.

Summary: The game doesn't quite live up to Mafia I quality. There are some nice moments and the world wants to suck you in with the music, storytelling and charismatic characters, but the game suffers from glitches and mediocre core gameplay. There are a lot of similar action games with open world that seem like a better investment of time, but if you have already played them all and love the genre then Mafia II Definitive Edition may be just the right game for you.

I ran it it an R7 3700x, with a 3070, and 32 GB of RAM at 1080p, aimed at 60 FPS. My machine should be able to handle way more than this game.

Unfortunately, the gold with Mafia DE has been shat upon by this.

The stealth is broken. Corner takedowns were removed, and often you don't get the prompt to take someone down, and you just punch them in the head, alerting everyone. This is an absolute downgrade from the last game.

The combat is the least enjoyable part of the game. With Aim Assist on, you will always aim nowhere near what you were trying for when you look down sights. Aiming out of cover is sluggish. Someone also decided to lock the sprint function out of combat in a cover based shooter.

Kudos to the devs for changing the speed limiter to the A button, allowing it to be a more functional E brake. The GPS is a downgrade from the last game, where signs showed you where to turn. Looking at the mini map is a distraction. You have the option to turn traffic laws off, and not need a speed limiter....except the laws come back on during missions. A whole function wasted because it doesn't work right.

The characters are great. Very well written. My only problem is all Vito's friends are pussies, and continually tell me to slow down (I thought wise guys were supposed to be tough lol.) The scenery, story, voice work, and back drop are all an awesome set piece. The music really shines in this game. The series tends to nail all of this. The only real problem in the story was not getting to meet Joe's sister. He always tells me I shoot like her, and I was popping headshots off. I really could've used her help.

The DLC wasn't very enjoyable. It was either GTA style games where you always have a timer, and a wanted level...or it was Mafia 2 cut content with a timer. It's not what I look for in this series.

Empire Bay, a bustling metropolis reminiscent of New York City, comes to life in Mafia 2.

One of the standout features of Mafia 2 is its rich and engaging dialogue. The characters' conversations are not just filler; they add depth to the narrative, making the story more captivating and the characters more relatable.The open world in Mafia 2 offers a significant improvement over its predecessor. The city feels alive, with pedestrians going about their business, traffic bustling through the streets, and an array of hidden gems waiting to be discovered. Visually, Mafia 2 showcases noticeable advancements compared to its predecessor. 

However, despite all its strengths, it's important to address the elephant in the room: the abundance of bugs. Having to restart missions due to cars getting stuck during tailing sequences, or characters like Joe becoming immobilised and unable to initiate critical cut scenes, can be a source of annoyance. Furthermore, the reappearance of old mission objectives for no apparent reason can disrupt the flow of the game play.

In conclusion, Mafia 2 is a captivating and enjoyable game that successfully captures the essence of a 1940s and '50s-inspired crime drama, shame about the abundance of bugs.

Ahhh, Mafia II Definitive Edition! Is it a perfect game? No. But very good and well worth the bit I spent to get all three Mafia games in the Definitive, including DLC's. Hours and hours of satisfying gameplay. I'd played these all in the past, but it was so long ago, I can't even remember if I had a controller for the driving function. I have a midrange setup with an RTX 2070 video card. The game looks nice. My monitor is 60hz, so I'm not trying to push anything crazy and I wonder if that's where some people are having issues. Asking an old game to do too much, graphic-wise? My settings are 2560X1080@60hz and most everything else is maxed out. The glitches I've seen are not graphic errors. They are glitches that either prevent you from doing an action or as some people have previously mentioned, there's a map glitch that will always show your best friend's house as a mission item where you are supposed to go sleep on the couch. If you try it, it won't let you after a certain point, so it's an annoyance that you live with. My recommendation would be in the first chapter, when it tells you to go to bed, don't go exploring, just go to bed, lol. This game is well worth the little bit it costs nowadays. The few glitches are usually remedied by restarting the game, with the exception of the one mentioned above for the map.

Original Mafia 2 was released in 2010 and it was big news then. I played it as a teen and liked it (I‚Äôve to mentioned that I haven‚Äôt yet played GTA IV at that time). Looking back at it now, it‚Äôs clear that the game was slightly unfinished and cut, you were introduced to a very lively world in first chapter, but soon all details would disappear and leave you in empty decorations. Also, this game was made by Czech studio in mid-2000s and encounter design is extremely dated ‚Äì enemies stand behind corners ready to one-shot you, see you through stairs and shoot through walls, sometimes also not taking any damage from your bullets. So, while the game, it‚Äôs music, driving, story and atmosphere are very charming, combat is frustrating half of the time. 
But here we have definitive edition and it doesn‚Äôt look all that good. There is still plenty of bugs from the original and some animations are now messed up as well. It looks a bit sharper, but still like a very old game, plus now there are some visual artefacts. DLC content is very unnecessary and low quality, I guess no one would be playing it now. 
Should you buy it? Only if you really want to get back into Mafia 2 and this is your only option.

"Mafia II: Definitive Edition" falls disappointingly short of expectations, particularly when compared to its predecessor. The graphics are a glaring disappointment, resembling a parody when juxtaposed with the visual excellence of the first game. Character movement further compounds the letdown, awkwardly reminiscent of the clunky animation seen in "Alan Wake" before its much-needed remaster. 

Adding to the dismay, the characters in "Mafia II: Definitive Edition" appear cartoonish, their movements unnatural and detached from any semblance of realism. This departure from the lifelike portrayals seen in the first installment only serves to diminish the immersive quality of the game.

So far, equally disheartening is the plot, which fails to measure up to the compelling narrative of "Mafia I: Definitive Edition." The story lacks the excitement and intrigue that captivated me in the original game, leaving a void where the anticipation for a gripping tale once stood. Nevertheless, I will continue playing the game with the expectation that my perspective might undergo a positive shift.

Either way, to compound the frustration, the controls have undergone alterations from the first game, introducing a level of inconvenience and discomfort for players familiar with the intuitive setup of the initial installment. 

Overall, "Mafia II: Definitive Edition" pales in comparison to its predecessor, marred by lackluster graphics, unnatural character animations, a lackluster plot, and questionable control changes that contribute to an overall unsatisfactory gaming experience. The intention behind the remastered version is supposed to give the game the appearance of a 2020 release rather than one from 2012.

I played the Mafia games back when they first came out and I have really enjoyed the definitive editions of Mafia and mafia II. While I think that Mafia is the best of the three games. Mafia II offers a charm that is difficult to come by with games that are released today. I especially enjoyed the time jump to 1951 and getting to hear music that I grew up listening to through movies set in the 50's or my grandmother or my mother playing rock n' roll from the 50's. With innovative mechanics for its time, and a map small but one that doesn't feel like it is small. A decent enough story with memorable characters, especially Joe. The variety of cars was nice too. The game isn't too long either, which is a nice change of pace in an industry that is over-saturated with games that can easily span for hundreds of hours, unless you basically rush the experience.

Some issues that I had was that the gameplay does feel dated. The shooting mechanics are simple but feel rather stiff and there is a lot of shooting in this game. Driving feels dated but is actually a lot of fun! I felt that the sound design was pretty good! The cars, the music, VOs... the only thing to really suffer sound wise was the guns. Of which for a game like there was a good variety, but would have liked to see some more rifles. One issue that I had is that the M1 Garand doesn't make its famous PING sound when the enbloc clip ejects. My biggest disappointment with Mafia II is that it didn't get the same make over as Mafia Definitive Edition. 

Overall a fun experience for Mafia fans and those who have never played Mafia (I do recommend starting with Mafia)

I'd recommend this game if someone just wants to hear the story but it's not exactly groundbreaking. In fact, the story and characters fall short of the first game, and the ending is unfulfilling. Perhaps it was their intention for the third game - I'll see soon enough. Overall it feels like this game is someone serving you skim milk when you asked for whole milk. It's a step down from its predecessor which is surprising given they received a definitive edition all around the same time.

There is no way to skip drive or use a taxi to take you to waypoints so you spend the majority of this game playing as a driving sim. The collectibles are the fluff to waste your life and time if you'll allow them to. There's a handful of guns with boring combat that's nothing to write home about. The graphics are poor relative to its predecessor. The steam from the sewer grates in winter, the lighting on dark nights, even the character models are generally flat and disappointing. The addition of money is a comical waste with adding gas stations, which I've never used, to gun shops that let you stock the gun you like if you haven't picked it up for the millionth time. If you want to throw your money at something, buy some clothes or change the rims or paint on your cars. Inevitably they will wipe everything you've bought and your money repeatedly anyways. Every day you're woken up with a phone call or doorball and get out of bed, address it, and put on one of your redundant outfits. Between the life-wasting driving and the bland combat you'll eventually get to consume a somewhat entertaining plot and narrative that doesn't run particularly deep and again feels a step down from its predecessor. At least there are three radio stations to choose from and you will have to change your radio settings every time you get in a car because nothing remembers your settings. Throw in some police to spice up your life but they only care if you're speeding or get into an intense collision. Then they'll make a show about chasing you but realize you're too fast or already gone and then you move on. If you scratch a car, drive in oncoming traffic, run red lights, swerve between cars, they're all good. Just don't drive through a fence. That's their line.

Overall, if you're playing the series and want all the stories, go for it. That's why I'm playing this and will finish it. But boy, I hope the third one is back to winning ways because this was a dreadful attempt at a sequel and a major letdown.

TL;DR Play it if you are trying to get the whole picture from a narrative perspective for the trilogy. But the game, as a game, isn't worth your time or money. Hard pass.

Mafia II Definitive Edition is not the best example of how to do a remaster yet is still an experience worth playing even if its bring some flaws and old bugs that should not be there is still a great game.

The Immersive Storytelling:

At the heart of this experience it's a storytelling triumph. Vito Scaletta's journey from a war-torn soldier to a rising figure in the Mafia is a nuanced exploration of loyalty, ambition, and the consequences of life-altering decisions. The narrative spans years, allowing players to witness the evolution of characters and the transformation of the city itself.

Timeless Setting, Modernized:

Mafia II Definitive Edition flawlessly recreates the post-World War II era, presenting a meticulously detailed world that feels both authentic and evocative. From the classic cars to the carefully curated soundtrack, every element contributes to the immersive atmosphere. The Definitive Edition enhances this setting with updated graphics a bit here and there yet don't have high hopes to see something next get on that regard.

Character Depth and Emotional Resonance:

One of the defining strengths of Mafia II has always been its well-developed characters. Vito Scaletta's journey is more than a rise through criminal ranks; it's a deeply personal exploration of his motivations, friendships, and the moral quandaries that define his choices. The supporting cast is equally rich in detail, contributing to a narrative that evokes genuine emotional investment.


The Nostalgia Reimagined:

For those returning to Mafia II, the Definitive Edition is a nostalgic journey made fresh. The familiar beats of the original story resonate, but the enhanced visuals that even if they are not much is decent, refined gameplay, and quality-of-life improvements make it an experience that transcends mere nostalgia. It's a reunion with an old friend, albeit one who has undergone a thoughtful makeover.

In Conclusion:

Mafia II Definitive Edition is more than a game; it's an immersive cinematic experience that stands the test of time. With a narrative that remains as compelling as it was a decade ago, visuals that bring Empire Bay to new life, and characters whose stories resonate on a deeply human level, this edition is a triumph of revitalization. Whether you're revisiting Vito's world or stepping into it for the first time, Mafia II Definitive Edition is an invitation to a world where crime, loyalty, and consequence collide in a masterfully crafted symphony of storytelling. Welcome back to Empire Bay; the streets await, and the story is as potent as ever.

Just finished the main campaign, still need to do the DLCs but i wanted to write this for the main game: 
Overall it's a pretty good game, the story is engaging, Graphics are lovely, the combat is decent enough, especially if you like lethal gunfights, and grabbing it on the sale as part of the trilogy made it a fantastic deal. It does however have some problems, so I'd like to outline my opinions below.

Pros:
-There's a good array of cars and guns, all in lovely detail. Also depending on the year new guns and cars will pop up. Its mostly Pistols, SMGs and Rifles, plus a single shotgun, but they have a decent variety. Also the cars can be tuned up and some have fantastic custom paint jobs
-The combat is pretty good in most aspects, Its lethal, you'll only take 2-3 shots before you die so cover is vital in most scenarios, but there's also ample opportunities to grab your machine-gun, walk-forward mowing people down, going brrrr. Hp only regenerates to 2/3s of max, you have to eat/drink to get it back up, but lose it in a single shot so i rarely bothered.
-The AI in combat understands cover and doesn't just stand there, It also advances if you stay in place, and will try to fire or move as you reload
-It kept the mafia/gangster aesthetic very well, the clothing, outfits and cars all feel in place.
-Lovely graphics, especially cutscenes, you can see where the DE touchups shine.
-Love the music, If you like the radio in fallout, you'll like the radio in Mafia II. The radio also regularly comments on your exploits.
-Characters were well done, I felt attached to a few of them, especially your bestfriend, and invested in what happens.
-Only ever encountered one or two bugs
-Don't feel like paying for it? Steal it! Clothes stores, Food Joints and gunshops can all be held-up and robbed to steal their inventory if you don't want to pay for it. Though holding up certain stores may require a gunfight.

Now comes the issues, and this game has a few, some which may be controversial.

Cons:
-Open-world in name only, there's no side missions, mini-games or side content beyond robbing stores, scrapping cars or fighting the police. 99% of the content is missions and going from mission to mission.
-In combat the AI will sometimes pull some stunts, like shooting you while on the floor, or spawning and gunning you while running to cover, very often i'd have an AI spawn or pop out of a corner and oneshot me and i'm wondering "where the hell...?" Also Grenades and Molotovs never flt that useful, At least when I was throwing them, not the enemy...
-Bugs: They do exist, I encountered one where during an emotional cutscene Joe failed to render, and was invisible, sort of ruining the moment, Another where dialogue repeated during chapter 14, often overlapping on itself, and also a bug preventing progress on chapter 14 if i'd robbed any stores during it, which the game advises you do to collect money. This required restarting the entire chapter and earning money via scrap instead
-This may be the most controversial one, but it really annoyed me. at least 3 times during the campaign, especially after a mission with a big payout, something will happen to your character and the game will take all your guns, Money and once even purchased clothes. This is a neat plot-trick once, but three to four times it gets frustrating. Especially as it never gives you the items back, you have to go and repurchase your guns, or collect new ones in combat. At this point, why even let me buy guns just to take them away, usually at the very start of the next level. It stops being clever or fun when you do it repeatedly. If there was one aspect of the game i could change it would be this.

Overall i'd give it an 8/10 maybe 8.5 for it great gameplay but a few glaring flaws. Definately grab it as part of the trilogy, especially on sale.

I want to mention the racism in this game. I know that it's set in a different time, and I know that mafiosi are bad guys. But if you're going to portray racism in a game, it needs to be handled thoughtfully. That's definitely not the case here: some of the dlalogue has a nasty 4chan stink to it.

Most of this game is driving and gunfighting. The driving is okay but boring, and I quickly got tired of driving from one side of the city to the other. The gunfighting is clunky. Moving and shooting from cover is often frustrating and I often felt that I couldn't get a good angle on target due to the camera and controls. The combat mainly involves blasting your way through waves of goons. It gets old pretty quickly.

The only good part of this game is the music. They have licensed some great old tunes for this game. There are plenty of AAA blockbusters with worse soundtracks. I could listen to this stuff all day.

In the end, it feels like the developers just tried to do too much with too little. If they had ditched the open-world pretensions, pointless fistfighting and half-baked stealth mechanics, then perhaps they could have produced a slick little '50s-themed cover shooter. Instead we're left with a glitchy hodgepodge of rubbish.

Finally I will add that the game plays fine on Linux using Proton-GE. You may need a workaround for the launcher - you can find that on ProtonDB. I did have to wait a minute or two on the first start for some PhysX stuff to download so do be patient.

"Mafia II: Definitive Edition" emerges as a disappointing endeavor, especially when viewed in the shadow of its much-praised predecessor, "Mafia: Definitive Edition." While the original "Mafia II" had its charm, this remaster fails to live up to the expectations set by the stunning remake of the first game, resulting in a product that feels lackluster and underwhelming.

From a graphical standpoint, the game is a letdown. Despite being labeled as a 'Definitive Edition,' the visual enhancements are minimal and do little to bring the game up to modern standards. The textures, character models, and environmental details show slight improvements but are far from the complete overhaul seen in "Mafia: Definitive Edition." This discrepancy is jarring, making "Mafia II: Definitive Edition" look outdated and lackluster in comparison.

The gameplay mechanics also suffer from a lack of refinement. What was once acceptable in the original now feels clunky and outdated, with combat and driving sequences that are more frustrating than enjoyable. The game misses an opportunity to modernize these aspects, which would have been a significant improvement for the remaster.

One of the more critical flaws is in the narrative itself. The story of Vito Scaletta, while a classic tale of crime and betrayal, feels overly stereotypical and lacks depth. The linear storyline, devoid of any meaningful side quests, contributes to a sense of monotony and missed potential. Unlike "Mafia: Definitive Edition," which managed to breathe new life into its story, "Mafia II: Definitive Edition" seems content to retread familiar ground without any significant additions or improvements.

The absence of side quests further diminishes the game's appeal. In an era where open-world games are rich with side narratives and additional content, the lack of such features in "Mafia II: Definitive Edition" makes the game feel barren and unengaging. Empire Bay, though aesthetically consistent with the period, lacks vibrancy and fails to encourage exploration, making the game world feel static and uninviting.

Additionally, the soundtrack, while authentic to the period, does little to compensate for the game's other shortcomings. It remains a lone highlight in a game that otherwise struggles to captivate or impress.

In summary, "Mafia II: Definitive Edition" falls short of delivering a satisfying gaming experience. It is overshadowed by its superior predecessor, lacks significant graphical or gameplay improvements, and suffers from a clich√©d and uninteresting story. For those seeking a compelling and modernized take on the Mafia series, it would be advisable to look elsewhere, as this edition does not do justice to the potential of a full remake.

This would have to be my favorite of the 3. Vito Scaletta & Joe Barbaro are an effective duo. The pacing of the chapters are terrific and game play is simple yet raw, which makes it complicated at certain points as you progress. Vantage points, cover, & conserving ammunition are essential. Shops, guns, and vehicles are all elegantly designed and while I really enjoy the upgradability systems, if I had to pick something I wish they had expanded - it would be the customization. Empire Bay is beautiful and the city succeeds in subconsciously creating a false sense of nostalgia for a time and place that doesn't exist - just as it did with Lost Heaven. The payoff of the connective tissue established at the ending of M1 weaving into this installment was done brilliantly.

Grand Theft Auto: The 'original' open world sandbox, rooted in questionable realism. It's identity? A reinterpreted reflection of our society with a focal point on the illusion of the 'american dream'. Overly-heightened. Flamboyantly grounded. Gliding on the fine line between nonsensically absurd & realistically resonant. Every story is driven by complex characters bound within ridiculously intuitive mechanics, rich environments, cityscapes, and vehicles. At it's core, Grand Theft Auto is the universal story of the underdog. The ones who refuse to stay under. Who by any means overcome adversity, trial, and tribulation. Usually ending with joyrides that ascend - to close the sun.

Saints Row: Like GTA, the SR franchise is equally (if not more) self aware. It's identity? Nothing more & nothing less than a mindless parody. A parody of what? Everything. What started as a solid satire alternative rival to Rockstars behemoth of a property; Saints Row slowly morphed from a structured, somewhat respectable sandbox - into an unhinged fever dream. Ironically what initially was it's biggest strength became it's tragic downfall. Becoming a caricature of itself as the games evolved. The original two games had the potential to bloom into something significant if Volition decided nurture their consistent tone. A bit wacky no doubt, but serious enough when need-be and stakes were felt nonetheless. The intricate customization of the structure of your character & faction was something unique (and exciting) to SR. As well as building relationships and infrastructure while climbing the ranks throughout the city. All things that are present in the newer entries - only thing missing is the emphasis on a contained linear structure to the story that the original two had. I'm all for bigger sequel stakes and insane sequences but they should feel tethered to what came before. A natrual progression should be felt and seen. When you go from taking over a city to fighting an alien invasion with superpowers from the white house as the president of the united states - somethings off. A few wrong turns were taken. Off a cliff. Everything after 2 was outlandish in every way but they had their moments. Increasingly ridiculously bizarre (and honestly cringe worthy at times) but still manages to retain the mindless fun. The mindless parody.

Mafia: Not only is the Mafia franchise the most realistic of the 3 but IMO, it's also the most successful when it comes to immersion. It's identity? Realism. Mafia is driven solely by it's story. I'd argue that the period piece elements of each installment are not only one of their most important narrative devices but they're kind of unseen characters - establishing the look, feel, & framework of the protagonists lives moving forward. While Saints Row & GTA's characters usually have many gray shades layered within them - Mafia's characters on the other hand are black and white. Self accepting monsters. What separates Mafia from other similar IP's is the ever growing looming dread and brutality throughout the story. Whether it be Tommy, Joe, Vito, or Lincoln - the angels on their shoulder took vacations. Their drive is fueled by their shadow, and the warped desires it bares. 

Grand Theft Auto is where I go when I want to explore.
Saints Row is where I go when I want to escape. 
Mafia is where I go when I want to experience. 

There's probably a better way to word that but that's the best I could convey the separation that exists between them. Mafia I's 'Lost Heaven' was based on Chicago. Mafia II's 'Empire Bay' was based on New York. Mafia III's 'New Bordeaux' was based on New Orleans. If the next one doesn't use an already established 'revamped' version of a map we're familiar with I'd love to see a city based on either Washington, DC or California. 

Modern Day Mafia 4 is a no-brainer.

Let me start by saying that the game itself is pretty good. It has aged pretty well and is still fun.

Great story, great characters, great music, really good setting and atmosphere. The game has a lot of nice touches and attention to detail that a lot of other city based open world games do not have. The shooting mechanics are decent however some of the guns feel very weak and inaccurate especially from longer range.

The AI of course can snipe you with a Tommy gun from 100 yards away even when you're in cover but you couldn't hit a wall from 10 yards, it can definitely get frustrating, but again not a deal breaker as most of the time it does work.

However, this being advertised as the "definitive" edition is where the game fails. It is riddled with bugs and audio sync issues. Constant stuttering in and out of cutscenes. Frame drops are constant, lots of pop in, and the game crashes quite a bit. The graphics themselves do look better, and the lighting is improved over the original, but again the performance issues are absolutely noticeable and do interfere with game play especiallythe driving. I'm not going to lie I have still been having fun with this game as its not entirely unplayable, but if you're sensitive to the performance issues you will hate it.

There is no way to defend this game, this "remaster" is an absolute slap in the face to fans and the fact they're charging money for a game that performs worse than the original is unacceptable. Game itself is solid, the performance however, is terrible and I cannot recommend this game whole heartedly as I would like to because of performance.

Either wait for a sale, or until the issues are fixed.

Just finished playing Mafia 2 for the first time and I'm in awe.

I played the remake of Mafia 1 a couple years ago and it was fantastic, my first entry into the Mafia series, heck my first time even really hearing about this series was when I checked steam and saw "Mafia 1 Definitive Edition", I had no idea what I was in for.

The ending of Mafia 1 left me wanting so much more even though It was very sad.

Enter, Mafia 2 with Vito and Joe.

A game from 2009 with a remaster that doesn't do it justice. While Mafia 1 got a needed ground up remake, 2 got some graphical improvements but at the cost of missing content in the main story.

The graphical improvements are noticeable however for such a legendary game it not getting a ground up remake is disappointing.

Nonetheless the game still holds up pretty well in 2023 for a 2009 game. The movement, car mechanics, and other things do feel clunky at times but it never makes you want to stop playing or enjoy the game less.

The story is amazing. Taking place in two different settings where one has snow and more retro cars, outfits, and radio songs while the other is the spring and more modernised in many different ways. 

The characters, voice acting, and dialog/writing is top notch. A story that has all the moments you'd want in one.

Characters play off of each other well, Joe and Vito especially, the main theme of the game is one of the best in gaming, and the ending like Mafia 1 is extremely sad.

My only big complaint with the game is how many missions there were where you have to drive across the entire map while watching out for cops and not killing yourself by crashing just to do something small that plays a little part in the story and then to drive all the way back to your home, go to sleep, and continue the story usually by doing that over and over again. It got repetitive and annoying due to how many of those types of missions there were.

Aside from that this game is amazing.

The music, graphics, voice acting, characters, sound design, story, dialog, and city all come together to make a fantastic game that still holds up well in 2023.

[i]My opinion might be clouded by two decades of "fog", but the original Mafia seemed like an excellent game. The story came across as very original. The individual episodes and missions had a ton of variety. The world felt massive and alive. The main character was sympathetic, because he was drawn into the criminal life, basically, against his will. The exposition captured attention from the start, and the ending was a grand crescendo. [/i]

Now, about Mafia II: 

On its own, maybe this game would be considered OK. But as a direct sequel to Mafia, it really looks dull. 

- The [b]main character[/b], Vito, is a dirtbag who, we learn, actually aspired to live a criminal, predatory life starting from his childhood. He pretty much deserts from the army in the middle of WWII. He does time in prison for a technicality, but he actually deserves to have done a lot more time. He is given the chance to work a respectable job, but sees himself as "too good" for actual honest labor. His living family is always an afterthought to him, because his own wellbeing is his highest priority. 

Contrast him against the main character from the first Mafia -- a meek, working family man who is unwillingly sucked into the criminal world by evil, unfortunate circumstance, and who struggles against his lifestyle throughout the whole story. The player is deeply moved by this character's inner conscientious fight, while Vito's conscience is flat-dead, and his "struggle" is purely external, material. 

- Joe, the main character's mission [b]partner, friend, and literary foil[/b], is a stupid, loud-mouthed, annoying, shallow walking stereotype. I was actually surprised when the credits rolled, because I was certain the game couldn't end without him betraying the main character -- Joe appears to be the kind of sleazy, greasy, oily scheisster, that he is obligated to stab all his closest friends in the back. 

Contrast this with the previous game -- the two characters who partnered with the protagonist there were both unique, distinct personalities with original backstories, and until nearly the end of the story, it appeared that they would all be faithful to each other. The characters in that game were much deeper and multi-dimensional than the lazily written, profane, stupid supporting character of this game. 

- The [b]game world[/b] in Mafia II is, frankly, lackluster. It's a bit disappointing when you're immersed in running from the cops, crash your car near the elevated train station, run up the stairs to board the train, only to realize that there are no working trains / subways in this game like there were in the original Mafia. Nor are there the closer-to-realistic reactions from the traffic cops when they see you running red lights, speeding, driving dangerously, etc. A great game makes the player feel "in the game world" enough to behave realistically, rather than goof off, which Mafia did, and Mafia II doesn't. 

- The [b]main story arc[/b] was simply lacking the entire length of the game. We learn from a cutscene that the main character wanted to live the "thug life" from childhood, and saw it as his ticket to easy street. We have one quick, silly mission which serves as a tutorial / backstory. After that, it's a string of missions which are all pretty much in the same format (drive from A to B, pick something up, something goes wrong, shootout, chase, run, go back to base, mission complete). 

There is zero character growth here like there was in Mafia when the main character meets his woman, gets married, and has a child over the span of years. 

There is no "breaking point" in this story, where you see your character's life turn upside down and start to unravel. In the first Mafia, there were clear pivots, wrong turns, which set the dramatic end of the story, such as it was, into motion. 

There is no climax in this story, and the ending was so "level", that I was confused and nonplussed upon reaching the end of the game. In Mafia, the ending was ambitious, grandiose, out-of-control, accelerating, fatalistic, rapidly depriving the main character of options in life. It left the player with an emotion like the main character was on the steep downward slope of a roller coaster coming up on missing tracks. 

I wish I could recommend this game, but if you had the pleasure of experiencing the first Mafia, this one will undoubtedly be a letdown. Don't let this game spoil your impression of the first installment.

Mafia II is pretty good. I was extremely hyped for this game when it first came out in 2010, but felt a bit underwhelming after the original Mafia, still enjoyable, but not really able to capture what was so great about Mafia I. With the remastered edition, the age of the game starts to become an issue however. Mafia I now is a shiny modern remake of the original and is mostly top notch, but the remaster of II is only a very superficial overhaul of the original release, in which you can barely spot the differences with the original. But worse, there's still a lot of bugs and glitches in this version of the game. Outfit issues, missions that can't progress because a police barricade from the previous mission didn't despawn, horribly deformed faces in cutscenes, enemies that get stuck in a hallway, leaving you to wonder why the mission isn't progressing and tons more... Still needs a lot of polish.

This game now comes with all the DLC for Mafia II wich is a blessing, but also a curse; I have an issue with the outfits and cars that are dumped on you because you have enabled a DLC outfit pack or car pack. This is all good and well, but it ruins some of the most important aspects of a game like this; progression and immersion. You want to unlock these items somehow, because why bother collecting any other car when you start out with some of the best cars in the game? Make these a little more difficult to obtain throughout the game. It requires a bit of balance, but there's a better way than outright unlocking them at the start. Also, having a car and outfit from Mafia III in the game is a bit too immersion breaking in my opinion.

The driving is not bad in Mafia II, I've never felt the intrinsic motivation from the driving however, not like in other games, like the original Driver for instance; behind every drift corner is a car waiting to interrupt your flow. On every straight piece of highway is a car that decides to change from one empty lane to another to ruin your speed and your car's bodywork. On every crossroads there's a car that decides to take a left turn even though you're fast approaching. After having played through all of Mafia II multiple times, I still don't feel like I'm able to satisfyingly speed through the city. Which is half the game, so it's bothered me quite a bit.

Another gripe I have with all driving games like this is the navigation system. In Mafia I, you were told to take the Giuliani Bridge or other landmarks multiple times, so after a few missions you were fairly familiar with the area around that bridge. You had to be, there was no line to follow on the mini map. In the original GTA III or Driver you were running around the map so much that in the end you knew it through and through. I've played the original Mafia I all the way through probably around 5 times and I know Lost Heaven like my own backyard. When I'm driving in the original Mafia I or GTA III or Driver, I don't need to look at the map apart from getting an idea of the destination. I knew every back alley, every shortcut, every fastest road. In Mafia II and other driving games that rely on this navigation system, you're constantly looking at the minimap to see when the next turn needs to be made, which inevitably makes you run into something because you're not looking at what's ahead of you. Studios spend so much time making these large beautiful worlds and you spend half the game looking at the bottom corner of your screen staring at a somewhat more dressed up version of "snake". It's a real shame that every game is resorting to this and I might feel old saying this, but people can't navigate streets anymore. I wished you could turn this off in the settings. In Mafia III there was at least a different approach to this but it's still the easiest way to disconnect you from the map.

The shooting is pretty good in the game, nothing too special, but enjoyable nonetheless. I liked the variety of weapons, the shooting etc... Only a more accurate long range rifle would have been good, possibly with a scope.

Then there's the Jimmy DLC; The Betrayal of Jimmy and Jimmy's Vendetta are some of the worst DLC I've ever played. In an effort to quell the critiques from comparing Mafia II with GTA IV, Hangar 13 decided to add an open world mission based system resembling that of GTA. Which to me is really unnecessary. It might have worked if done at least a little bit decently, but it feels like a very cheap copy paste of what other games had and it made me lose a bit of respect for the Mafia franchise. There's elements of the GTA system that I prefer over that of Mafia's but they had their own more immersive approach and I've always appreciated Mafia I and II for this. If the missions in the DLC would have been polished, more original and possibly contain some dialogue, cinematics, etc... they would have been passable, but in the end it's just a collection of point farming missions in the hopes that people would want to replay these for some reason. But the worst thing about the DLC are the achievements. I like to unlock all achievements, but for this one I might leave it at 97% completed. I've played through all of the Jimmy's Revenge DLC, finished all but two achievements and I still need to drive 820 miles to get to 1000 miles driven for the second to last achievement? Are you kidding me? Some achievements are difficult, but this is just horrible grinding. There's a glitch to get these last two achievements, which says enough, if there's an urge to find a glitch to get these last achievements, they must be unreasonably grindy to obtain.

The Joe's Adventures DLC is a lot better. It's lacking the relative polish of the main game and is basically 4 missions with some more point farming side stuff in between, but at least there's custom content, some new areas and interiors to explore, little things, but definitely a welcome addition. I particularly liked the mission on the frozen lake and the shootout in the strip club. 3 DLCs like this would have been great. Also the achievements for this DLC are fun and manageable, some are difficult, but definitely doable. Nothing like the ridiculous please-play-my-game-some-more achievements from J's Revenge.

Creative, fun, and action pack are just some of the adjectives I would describe Mafia 2 Definitive Edition as it recaptures the nostalgic experience of the original with some new paint. The story is just as amazing as the original, it houses some of the most impactful twists and turns while the players second guess themselves into predicting what might come in. Vito is an enduring protagonist that is only as great as the supporting character in the story that bounces off of him.

However, there are still some new and old issues that plague the definitive edition. The gameplay is still just as frustrating and the gunplay is just as uninspired as when it was first released. It's a stiff mess that requires too much of the player's attention to pull through ridiculous missions. Even the new improvements in weapons sounds can't save the gameplay.

Overall, besides some minor faults, the experience of Mafia 2 is still present within the definitive edition and offers up the same adventurous game for a broader audience. It's a solid game. If you're ever bored and want to experience a beautiful story, give this game a try. Just avoid the DLCs. They're awful, all of them.

Mafia 2 was a pretty good game. The story is quite solid with plenty of little twists and turns. Lasted maybe 15 hours and didn't feel repetitive at any point. Voice acting is good. Gunplay is pretty good. It pushes the player to use cover rather than running and gunning, and the enemy AI behaves the same way. Enemy AI is quite impressive for the game's age, though they will occasionally get stuck in place. Only saw this a few times, so no biggie. The game has a shocking amount of environment damage, like tables, pillars, etc. all visibly losing chunks of material when shot. It's a cool effect when in a gunfight. The driving in this game is better than pretty much every new game. The cars feel truly heavy, and not many games pull that off. I'm very impressed. Graphics are well, 10 years old. They hold up well, but don't expect to have your mind blown there. My biggest issue is that stuff that forms as a result of large gunfights like debris and casings do not despawn when they hit a certain count. As a result of this, I've had my frames drop from a stable 60 down to 15, which is not fun in a fight. I looked briefly at the DLC in the game, and it seems kinda bland.

All in all, would recommend!

Mafia 2 is an exceptional game that takes players on an unforgettable journey through the criminal underworld of the 1940s and 1950s. With its gripping narrative, richly detailed world, and immersive gameplay, it stands as a testament to the brilliance of storytelling in video games.

Set in the fictional city of Empire Bay, players assume the role of Vito Scaletta, a war veteran drawn into a life of organized crime. The game masterfully portrays the rise and fall of Vito, weaving a compelling tale of loyalty, family, and the consequences of one's choices.

One of the strongest aspects of Mafia 2 is its attention to detail. The developers painstakingly recreated the era with period-authentic cars, fashion, and music, immersing players in the vibrant, gritty world of organized crime. The city itself feels alive, bustling with activity and providing ample opportunities for exploration.

The gameplay mechanics are well-crafted, offering a blend of action, stealth, and driving sequences that keep the player engaged throughout. 

What sets Mafia 2 apart is its commitment to character development and storytelling. The game explores themes of friendship, betrayal, and the price of power, providing players with a narrative-driven experience that resonates long after the credits roll. The voice acting and dialogue are top-notch, bringing the characters to life and making their struggles and triumphs feel real.

Mafia 2 is a standout title that combines an engrossing narrative, immersive gameplay, and impressive visuals to deliver a truly unforgettable experience. Whether you are a fan of crime dramas or just enjoy a well-crafted game, Mafia 2 is a must-play. Prepare to be enthralled by its compelling story and immerse yourself in the richly detailed world of organized crime.

A Timeless Masterpiece - Mafia II: Definitive Edition

I've just finished playing Mafia II: Definitive Edition and I'm thrilled to say that it's been an unforgettable journey that completely exceeded my expectations. This edition takes a classic game and masterfully revamps it, taking full advantage of current generation hardware to truly make this title shine.

From the onset, you're immersed into the post-war world of Empire Bay, a city brimming with life, diversity, and period-accurate details. It's a setting that is both intoxicating and unforgiving, perfectly capturing the romantic yet brutal essence of the 1940s and '50s.

The game's narrative is its biggest strength, showcasing a captivating and deeply personal story of survival, ambition, and the undeniable allure of the Mafia lifestyle. The protagonist, Vito Scaletta, is a character who's realistically flawed and relatable, bringing depth to his journey from being a war veteran to an ambitious gangster. The supporting characters are just as compelling, each one contributing to the intricate, morally complex tapestry of Mafia II.

In terms of gameplay, Mafia II: Definitive Edition manages to find a good balance between driving, gunfights, stealth sequences, and narrative sections. The gunplay is tight and responsive, with a cover system that feels intuitive and keeps firefights engaging. The driving mechanics have also been refined, providing a good sense of weight and momentum to the various period-appropriate vehicles.

Graphically, the Definitive Edition shines with its impressive visual overhaul. From the detailed character models to the atmospheric lighting, this game is a visual treat. Empire Bay looks stunning in all its glory, with beautiful day-night cycles and weather effects adding a sense of realism to the world.

Perhaps my only gripe would be that some of the original game's flaws still persist, such as the occasional AI mishap and the lack of variety in side activities. However, these minor flaws are easily overlooked in light of the game's strengths.

The original soundtrack and exceptional voice acting also deserve a special mention. The developers have curated an atmospheric soundtrack that perfectly complements the era, while the voice actors deliver convincing performances that breathe life into the characters.

In conclusion, Mafia II: Definitive Edition is an exemplary remaster, staying true to the spirit of the original while enhancing every aspect of the game to meet contemporary standards. It's a testament to the timeless appeal of a well-told crime story, coupled with engaging gameplay and stunning visuals. This game deserves to be in the library of anyone who appreciates narrative-driven games and the noir charm of the Mafia setting.

A must-play classic, definitively.

After playing this game to completion alongside the Mafia: Definitive Edition, I can thoroughly say that you'd be wasting both money and disc space by purchasing this version of the game over the original Mafia II. The performance is probably worse than the original with the controls feeling exactly as they did in 2010, which isn't for the better. What you're paying for in essence is 35GB of enhanced textures, which at least playing on a 1080p monitor on the highest settings, I barely found noticeable for how much disc space is being demanded. 

I think the story and characters of Mafia II are compelling for the time that it came out, and definitely worth experiencing just once. They manage to make horrible human beings by all moral accounts still likeable in personality, leaving you both disgusted by the people that you do come to care for in the narrative. However the DE has also no changes to the story, you will not be experiencing any new or remade content- which I think is the only thing that would've saved this game for me as a stand-alone product. 

I would say buy the original Mafia II but unfortunately as per usual from publishers nowadays, they make it impossible to buy the original games in favour of forcing the new versions onto consumers. Even on GOG you can only buy the classic version of Mafia I which the Definitive Edition has for all intents and purposes become a far better version of in every way. So I suggest either obtaining the game through 'other' means or watching a playthrough on Youtube for the full experience of Mafia II nowadays. It is not worth paying anything above $10-$15 for the original game, let alone pay full price of the DE to experience a game that still belongs in 2010 in this form.

I have to caveat this review - the Mafia games passed me by the first time around. I bought this as part of the Mafia Trilogy. Having played [b][i]Mafia: Definitive Edition[/i][/b], which is a remake, I was blown away. That is a 2020 game with a story that feels 2020 worthy, absolutely excellent. Mafia is [b]so[/b] cinematic, [b]incredibly[/b] engaging, it was hard to move away from, and I was sad that there was not more to explore in this wonderful world that the developer created.

[b][i]Mafia II: DE[/i][/b] is a very different prospect. A remaster not a remake. I can see why, the game is a huge open world, reasonable narrative, and plenty of entertaining missions too. I'm sure the original Mafia II was much closer to a modern game than the original Mafia. However, the Mafia [b][i]remake[/i][/b] is better than this Mafia II [b][i]remaster[/i][/b]. 

I have no regrets playing it, for the value for money it's terrific in the bundle, with a reasonable story, and good, albeit not great, graphics. I do recommend this game, just far less strongly that Mafia: DE. That sadness and longing that I felt whilst leaving Mafia DE behind is simply not  present with Mafia II DE. In fact, there are DLCs that I have started but have no intention to finish. On to Mafia III now...

First of all, if you want to play this game get it on sale ONLY for the classic version(to my knowledge you get the OG version for "free" with this). This game is really something special the game plays out really well and is super well paced, it never feels like the missions are dragging or anything you do is super forced for the sake of padding or other reasons, the voice acting is great and the story is a classic mafia story that for someone like me, a big fan of Godfather, Goodfellas etc... just hits all the right spots. The characters are fantastic and Vito surely deserves his face on the mafia's Mt. Rushmore. Driving controls and camera are kinda wack at times though.
 HOWEVER this review is negative for all the reasons everyone else is saying, I personally didn't notice any bugs until about half way through(besides the stuttering) and only then it was a few minor bugs, but after chapter 11ish the bugs came rolling in, some I remember from back in the day when I played it on 360, It stutters like a mad man on crack if you don't cap the frames to 60 or whatever your system can handle, (probably 60fps regardless), 
visual bugs in the cutscenes started appearing(vito's hair, eyes getting stuck etc...), and even worse the infinite loading screen is back in chapter 14, along with Joe and his *** getting stuck in chap. 14 as well.
The "Improvements" are nice but not really well done and not worth the terrible buggy mess we got, sure the lighting is better in some scenes but it also blinds the **** out of you too! Sure the reworked character models are nice, but they only worked the story characters and no one else(and not even the outfits in some cases, so you get higher res faces and 360 era suits on 'em), I mean they still used only 3-4 models for all the npcs on the sidewalks, background etc, THERE IS LITERALLY ONLY ONE ASIAN MODEL FOR THE CHINESE AND ONE COP MODEL! And yeah the textures are nicer too even if shop awnings float around sometimes. The camera for driving still sucks, the performance is garbo, and only some city textures were updated. Its like a WIP mod made by one guy and this is just a preview except it screws the whole game over and now you gotta buy it to get the older more superior version of it.
I really love this game, but 2k did all of us dirty with the "DeFiNiTiVe TrIlOgY". Don't support this game or if you must buy this game, get it on sale.

TL;DR - Buggy, half-***ed "remaster" not worth the time or money, classic version is goated though.

P.S. I think GOG has the classic version for like 10 bucks.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding Gordon Ramsay's Beef Wellington recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingridients:
2 x 400g beef fillets 
Olive oil
500g of mixed wild mushrooms (don‚Äôt forget to clean them!) 
1 thyme sprig, leaves only 
¬Ω kilo puff pastry 
8 slices of Parma ham 
2 egg yolks, beaten with 1 tbsp water and a pinch of salt
Sea salt and recently ground black pepper

For the sauce: 

 olive oil
 200g beef trimmings (these can normally be requested at the butcher when ordering the fillets)
4 large shallots, peeled and sliced 
12 black peppercorns 
1 bay leaf 
1 sprig of thyme 
Dash of red wine vinegar 
1 x 750ml bottle red wine
 750ml beef stock

1.) Wrap each fillet of beef in plastic wrap (make sure it is tight to set the shape!) and leave it in the fridge overnight
2.) After removing the plastic, sear the beef fillet for 40-60 seconds, ensuring the outside is brown while the inside remains rare. Remove the beef from the pan and leave it to cool down.
3.) Cut the mushrooms finely and fry in the frying pan with olive oil, the Thyme and a sprinkle of salt and pepper. Continue to fry over a high heat until the excess moisture is gone and you are left with a paste like consistency. Remove this paste and leave to cool
4.) Cut the puff pastry in half and put  each piece on a lightly floured surface. Mold each piece into a rectangle big enough to cover your beef fillets and place in the fridge
5.) Lay a sheet of plastic wrap on your cooking surface and put 4 slices of your parma ham in the middle, slightly overlapping in the shape of a square. Spread half of your mushroom paste evenly on this square
6.) Season one of your beef fillets and use the plastic wrap to envelope the ham around said fillet. Roll and tie the ends of the plastic wrap to get a satisfyingly even log. Repeat step 5 and 6 with your other fillet and chill both for 30 mins 
7.) Move the beef from the plastic wrap  and nvelope the beef fillets in the pastry. Coat the pastry in the whisked egg yolks and wrap with plastic wrap. Leave this in the fridge for 30 mins
8.) While waiting, now is the time to make your sauce. Heat the olive oil in a large pan and fry the beef trimmings until golden brown. Add the shallots, pepper, thyme and bay leaf, stirring frequently until the shallots are also golden (around 5 mins) 
9.) Pour in the vinegar and boil until almost fully reduced. Now pour in your wine and let it boil until the same effect is achieved. Add the beef stock and bring back to the boil. Let the sauce simmer for an hour, removing any foam from the surface. Strain the sauce and add seasoning where necessary.
10.) When you are ready to cook the Beef Wellingtons preheat the oven to 200 degrees Celsius/ Gas 6. Slash the pastry with a blade or a sharp knife to allow it to expand during baking and bake for 15-20 mins until the pastry is golden and cooked through. Allow to cool for 10 mins before carving 
11.) Reheat the sauce and serve as an accompaniment to the Beef Wellington.
12.) Enjoy and reflect on how much of an awesome chef you would be in 1800‚Äôs Colonizers Britain

The protagonist answers to the name of Vito Scaletta, who was born in Italy but soon moved to America with his family, represents the stereotype of the young man who emigrated overseas in the early decades of the 1900s. Poor family, debt-ridden father and bad friendships are elements that lead him despite himself to be caught in the act during a theft, resulting in his being brought back to Italy to help in the liberation of the peninsula during World War II. Returning to America because of a gunshot wound, he will find a way to be discharged from the army forever, hoping to resume a social climb that will make him forget his modest origins.

From this plot unfolds a story some 15 hours long and divided into chapters. Marked in the middle by an additional long passage of time, useful to tell the story of Vito's psychological evolution, as well as the radical social change from the postwar period to the economic boom of the 1950s, reinforced by the abandonment of the wintry and snowy climate in favor of a milder and more lush one.
Mafia II is, like its siblings of the same name, a work that pushes hard on the emotions, wanting to tell a raw, adult story that spares nothing and no one, as life has taught the protagonists themselves. Vito is a man of low lineage who, as is so often the case, is willing to get his hands dirty in order to live with his head held high among the greats. He will discover the joys and sorrows of his choices, until a bitter but somehow just ending. A plot that never reaches the splendor of the first unforgettable chapter but that still, ten years later, will be able to give you some moments of the highest stage value.
Mafia II received several high praises upon its release. We have already analyzed the period of its arrival on the market, and undoubtedly the boost of the memory of the first chapter helped quite a lot in the general reception, both of the press and fans. As time went on, we realized, despite ourselves, the major issues and difficulties encountered in making a highly linear game within an open world.

The difficult coexistence with GTA, which at that time had reached its fourth chapter and was able to showcase a beautiful and enormous Liberty City, evidently weighed on the minds of the guys at 2K, to the point where they decided to work even more assiduously on their vision of the open world, which, unfortunately, never really worked.

Mafia II is a schizophrenic title, throwing the player into a series of missions that punctuate the passage of time between waking up and resting again. There is never any real sense of freedom of movement, dictated only by a city that is rich in detail but reduced in size and deadly dull. Aside from a handful of restaurants, clothing stores and workshops, the rest of the interiors are relegated to campaign missions that circumscribe the area solely to that specific moment. Forget about the freedom to choose which mission to undertake, just as it will be useless to try to think about finding secondary assignments (here called jobs and reduced to the bone).

From this point of view Mafia II fails miserably in its purpose and, what is most infuriating, is that it does so out of the one and only need to please a market that would not have accepted it otherwise. As if that were not enough, this displaces a shooting system and a driving model that are capable of setting the standard even now within the genre.

Mafia II was one of my favourite games growing up. And it didn't deserve the rough treatment this "Definitive" Edition gave it. I was expecting much better after playing the first instalment of the franchise - Mafia: Definitive Edition. That felt like a definitive edition, this on the other hand, felt like the same game from 10 years ago with the 'definitive edition' label strapped to it. 

It feels like they did the bare minimum with this ''definitive edition'' and I would almost say the legacy version is better. The graphics hasn't changed one bit and looks just about the same as the legacy version, but with more bugs. 

Everything was running smoothly at the beginning, until I got in deeper and deeper into the story chapters. I started noticing characters' faces messed up and cut scenes with broken segments, Characters speaking over themselves, and repeating themselves, on the SAME conversation (even in the final encounter)
The list of bugs just goes on and on.

Now the DLC is another can of worms on its own, and is absolutely disastrous. 
Why in the fuck would you make EVERY SINGLE mission a time trial? 
Playing the DLC felt like a chore more than anything else. 
Drive there, shoot everyone, return. Run here, steal a car, return. Over and over. 
Not to mention the story is almost none existent with cutscenes telling you NOTHING. 

So, don't let the title fool you, this Definitive Edition lies in the Classic Mafia II version. Not this remake.  It runs better, looks just as good (even better in some aspects) and doesn't have these annoying issues.

Mafia II is definitely worth playing, but make sure you don't rob yourself out of an enjoyable ride with these technical issues. Play the Classic version instead, and skip the DLC.

So, I recently played the Mafia 2 Definitive Edition, and I have to say, it was a pretty mixed experience for me. As someone who's already played the original Mafia 2, I was excited to see how this new edition would improve upon the game.

First off, the graphics were definitely a step up from the original. The environments and characters all looked more polished and detailed, which made the game feel more immersive. However, I did notice some glitches and bugs here and there, which was a bit frustrating.

In terms of gameplay, it was pretty much the same as the original. The shooting and driving mechanics were solid, but there weren't really any new additions to the gameplay that made it feel fresh. It was just more of the same, which could be good or bad depending on how you look at it.

The story was still the highlight of the game for me. Mafia 2 has always had a great narrative, and it still holds up in the Definitive Edition. The characters are well-written, and the voice acting is top-notch. However, I did feel like some of the pacing was a bit off. Certain parts of the story felt rushed, while others dragged on for too long.

I would say that Mafia 2 Definitive Edition is a decent remaster of the original game. The improved graphics and solid gameplay make it worth playing again, especially if you're a fan of the original. However, if you're looking for a completely new experience, you might be a bit disappointed.

There is no denying that Mafia 1 and 2 are staples in the libraries and backlogs of most gamers that appreciate a good story... I loved these two games back in the day on the Xbox and I only just now revisited both of them. 

Truthfully speaking, Mafia 2 is not as good as Mafia 1, but it is certainly a gem and a "must-play" for everyone - I highly recommend playing through the two games. With that said, I bought Mafia 1 and 2 on sale and I would NEVER buy either of the two games at full price. 30 bucks for this port that has a lot of bugs (which we will talk about) is just not acceptable. I paid 5 and I felt like that was a reasonable amount for this old port. 

Took me about 10.5 hours to finish the game on Hard difficulty, so let's talk about the good, bad and ugly. Starting with the bad and ugly, 

‚Ä¢ Stuttering gets progressively worse throughout the chapters - started off relatively fine, but by chapter 12-15 the game stuttered an insane amount to the point where it felt semi unplayable. By then I was too invested and had to just endure the terrible performance. 

‚Ä¢  [b] SLIGHT SPOILER INCOMING![/b] Chapter 14 is bugged and has been for years. If you decide to rob any stores during chapter 14 or rob stores in order to get enough money for Bruno, the ending cutscene will not show up and you will have to re-do this mission (which is quite long, might I add). The simple fix is to take the $22.000 when you kill Derek and then crush cars at Bruski's. 

‚Ä¢ Way too expensive. 30 bucks for an archaic and bad port like this is outrageous. Don't ever buy this unless it's on sale. 

‚Ä¢ A lot of visual bugs... Faces, cars, screen blinking, etc. 

‚Ä¢ Dialogue bugs. Repeated lines and delayed lines are common. 

‚Ä¢ No ability to free-roam? Seriously? Why was this never implemented. Even Mafia 1 had this. 

‚Ä¢ Cops in this game are useless - you can massacre the whole city and all it takes is to speed a little bit up and they will never catch you. Massive downgrade to the cops in Mafia 1, which I found to be brutal on Classic mode. 

All in all, you can get past the bugs and enjoy the game, none of them break the game completely and I played through the whole thing without a single crash. Let's talk about the good...

Mafia 2 is a game that executes the 1940s and 1950s theme perfectly... Everything from the cars, Empire Bay which sets the tone for a fictional take on New York brilliantly, the weapons and most importantly, the characters and overall story-telling. These are without a doubt Mafia 2's strongest points. I can't praise the story enough, it is enthralling and captivating and you become heavily invested in the characters of the game, to the point where deaths in-game are felt on a personal level. It's just one of those games where you have to play through it to see what it's all about - trust me, it's worth it.

Oh, and they also give you naked Playboy women to look at throughout the game and I can shamelessly admit that I collected every 50 of them. Oops.
