Having played both MAFIA (the original) and Mafia: Definitive Edition, there is only one word that can sum up this sequel: BORING.

First of all, the story: The first Mafia game had a great story, it's what drove the gameplay. You had unique, memorable character design and introductions, great voice acting, and a plot filled with interpersonal drama that actually develops like a movie. Mafia 2's writing feels so watered-down by comparison, with bland characters in service of a generic plot. 

Also, taking place only a few years later than the events of Mafia 1, you would expect the game's story would take the opportunity to tie into Mafia 1's rich legacy and characters - but as far as I can tell, it doesn't at all. And I'm not spoiling anything when I say: The game actually punishes you for completing the first few missions by sending you straight to prison! Which brings me to my next point...

The gameplay: I don't know what the real difference between Mafia 2's "Definitive Edition" and the original Mafia 2 is, but I don't think it matters - because it would seem the developers took complaints about the driving and shooting challenges of the first game to heart, and made this game completely about beating the brains out of every knucklehead you encounter with your bare fists. 

There's actually very little action in a lot of the game's levels before the third act - and the majority of it involves clunky 1v1 fist-fights with AI opponents in instanced events. This would be fine if the fighting mechanics are on par with a decent brawling game, but this isn't. Wooden, at best, is how I would describe the controls, and most fights quickly devolve into button-mashing trash. It's only after slogging through this that you get the chance to really play the game...

As far as the gunplay goes - it's not bad. It's about the same as Mafia DE; the cover action is pretty smooth, and there's some room for experienced gunslingers to take shots that wouldn't be possible on other cover-based 3rd person shooters. Shooting goons in this game is really fun. Same goes for the driving physics - the quicker 40-50's era muscle cars are a blast to drive, but there's only a few missions where you are actually put to the test driving anything. 

On top of that, there's a lot of points in the game where you get your money and weapons taken away unexpectedly, so there's no real point in earning money or visiting shops to access new equipment in between story mission save points... the open world function is basically useless. Correct me if I'm wrong, but this game lacks all of the side missions, secret vehicles, and characters of the first game, besides some soft-core pin up art!?!?

Overall, it pales in comparison to the 1st Mafia, and the 1st Mafia: Definitive Edition. If you can get it for less than 5 bucks it's a fine time waster. Even on hard difficulty, it's a game that you can play at your leisure, as long as you get used to the checkpoint system. But if you're expecting the story and action of the 1st Mafia... well I don't know what to tell ya, champ. Go back to Lost Heaven.

To clarify some things: this review is a summary of both my original impression of the original Mafia II, combined with my thoughts re: this "remastered" version specifically.

This game, especially after Mafia III release, got a positive reputation, most of which it does not deserve. In short, there are two reasons: utterly empty and repulsive characters and a lot of technical issues.

The protagonist, Mr. Scaletta, is a descendant of a deadbeat Italian man, whom along with their family, immigrated in States in mid 1920s. From the start, there's a stark difference between Vito and protagonist of Mafia I, Tommy Angelo -- whilst Tommy got into the criminal business by chance, and although ultimately he got fully integrated with family, did so with some reluctance, Vito is a different story altogether. He's an unpleasant arrogant hood boy whose only motivation, as he states during exposition, is to have the most money and carry the least of the responsibility and consequences.

Comparing to Tommy, to whom I can, to a degree, show some sympathy and compassion, I hate Vito. He's stupid, dumb and witless, triggers absolutely zero compassion, and to be honest, doesn't deserve his second chance. Just like a piece of dumb dumbness, he floats along the coasts of the plot, with no back thought, effort or even a blink of initiative taken. Steal a car? Not his idea. Sell drugs? Not his idea. Shoot these random guys or execute someone? Not his idea. He just does what he has been told. Even Joe is more to my liking: although he's not in check with reality and is constantly being borked over his delusion of grandeur, he shows some initiative, character growth, even some emotions.

But Vito? Nah, I'm just a lonely dumb gopnik from Italian ghetto, and I want more money, thanks.

There are a lot of holes in the character development, their motivation and the plot in general, but the main, ahem, "protagonist" is the worst of them, in my opinion.

The plot as a whole has some issues with pacing, and the ending -- well, don't even start me on that. Let's just say that this is the most anti-climatic ending in a mafia-themed game I have ever seen. Especially after the build-up that the game does just a few minutes before the credits.

Now, to the the other stuff. The original game was an impressive, but a bit dated experience. Driving and shooting mechanics, in my opinion, felt clunky even at the time of the original release, graphics were impressive but the engine was not optimized very well, and whilst the game positioned itself as a next-gen experience, the muddy textures and very strange facial animations looked questionable at best, along with cloth simulation. The only truly impressive things I can remember which looked great in 2010 were particle effects and destructible environments, albeit at the cost of the performance, which wasn't great to begin with.

Now the remaster tried to address some things, but let's be honest: devs didn't do much apart from fixing deal-breaking compatibility issues and updating textures and some of the models. All of the bugs you might remember from the original game -- they are still here. Broken scripts, broken driving mechanics, questionable stealth and AI behavior, it's all still here. Now what they've brought new are some unexpected stutters here (frame pacing is all over the place), broken particle effects (during diner shootout scene FPS dares to drop to mid-teens on a RTX 3070 Ti -- how about that?) and other performance issues, and a few new cars from Mafia I and Mafia III for character to use, a taxi cab and a muscle car.

To sum up: there's nothing "definitive" in this "edition". It's just a rather old game with its own issues, which was very cheaply bumped up to the "running on Windows 10" state, bundled with a few new bugs and a new price tag.

I've bought the whole "remaster" pack on a sale for a very low price, so I can't really complain about price-to-entertainment ratio here (plus to that, Mafia I re-make is great!), but on its own, this game is not worth its asking price, and I would've preferred the original any day of the week, especially considering that community fixed most of the original's bugs and performance issue on their own.

Oh yeah, you can't buy the original anymore. How meta.

P.S.: 2K Launcher is a piece of garbage, even more so than Rockstar's.

Mafia II is a game made with allot of love and hard work from its developers, While one can reminisce about the countless hours of cut content due a to rapidly approaching deadline, The game dose a lot right the cut content makes certain areas of the game like Vito's phone call to Franny and the reference to features that no longer exist in the game awkward. That being said Mafia II is probably my favorite game of all time having played it since childhood, Vito Scaletta's story felt real it was exiting it was engaging and in the end it was somber. As all media relating to the mafia goes there is no such thing as a perfectly happy ending (until Mafia III if u can count the rule together ending as happy) Joe's fate is left as ambiguous (until III) and Vito's narrative in this title doesn't end as him being some wise guy Capo at the top of the food chain, Vito leaves as a 26 year old with a slightly better idea of the mob and with the thought is best friend is going to die because of him. I have a lot of love for this franchise that being said they're some issues with the Definitive Edition, If your expecting a from the ground remake of one of your favorite 2k titles that's not this game but it's probably in the works by now. Sometimes Vito's feet glitch through Marty's bed sometimes cut-scenes will cut themselves off if you've seen the community tab then you've probably seen some of the more glaring almost game breaking ones, The Definitive Edition also dose not bring back any cut content for the game in a substantial way. That being said if your looking for a remastered Mafia II in 2023 than the Definitive Edition is worth buying in my opinion, I had plenty of fun playing through both the main story and the following DLC's. In fact the DLC's bring back the Supermarket, Cat house, Frank Vinci's Mansion, the Warehouse, ect. as playable area's as well as allowing you insight on whats happening inside Empire Bay outside of Vito. All things considered though the game has its Flaws the Definitive Edition of Mafia II is a game worth playing for both Veteran fans and New players.

Mafia II has a wonderful sandbox environment. Lighting and weather are a marvel to experience; you need gameplay though and overall, I would say that I quite enjoyed the DLC. I don't usually like driving in games, but I kinda got to like it in Mafia II. Just as well, there's a lot of it. The DLC are not wonderful or great, they are just about good. The problem is there's too much repetitive grind and overall they often lack challenge in the missions. They just about kept me hanging in there with occasionally varied tasks to complete the end story, but it was always only just enough, not awash with thought and planning. Joe's Adventures are the worst of the DLC though, jarring arcade elements are introduced and the missions are far too much of a grind with little variation. However the base gameplay is good enough to keep you going through the DLC and there are just about enough lengthy, complex shooting missions with the added challenge of being against the clock to keep up the interest.

A good base game that handles driving very well and does a reasonable job of character development. The fps element of the game is a solid cover shooter that allows for multiple routes to targets and makes good use of the environment to destroy, hide and explode to your advantage. This is highly enjoyable. There are varied weapons that sound, reload and feel different and obviously do different levels of damage. ammunition is plentiful (I played on medium difficulty) and the draw distance and collision detection is generally excellent so get your sniper skills in actions because enemy AI is distance triggered and this allows you a hack in some of the more open moments.

I would recommend the game, but you won't be missing out if you passed over the DLC.

100% my favorite game of 2022. The story in this game is better than most big budget Hollywood movies nowadays. I heard the remastered  version was bad after I played and tbh it ran like butter no issues bugs slowdowns or freezes for me.

Mafia II has a wonderful sandbox environment. Lighting and weather are a marvel to experience; you need gameplay though and overall, I would say that I quite enjoyed the DLC. I don't usually like driving in games, but I kinda got to like it in Mafia II. Just as well, there's a lot of it. The DLC are not wonderful or great, they are just about good. The problem is there's too much repetitive grind and overall they often lack challenge in the missions. They just about kept me hanging in there with occasionally varied tasks to complete the end story, but it was always only just enough, not awash with thought and planning. Joe's Adventures are the worst of the DLC though, jarring arcade elements are introduced and the missions are far too much of a grind with little variation. However the base gameplay is good enough to keep you going through the DLC and there are just about enough lengthy, complex shooting missions with the added challenge of being against the clock to keep up the interest.

A good base game that handles driving very well and does a reasonable job of character development. The fps element of the game is a solid cover shooter that allows for multiple routes to targets and makes good use of the environment to destroy, hide and explode to your advantage. This is highly enjoyable. There are varied weapons that sound, reload and feel different and obviously do different levels of damage. ammunition is plentiful (I played on medium difficulty) and the draw distance and collision detection is generally excellent so get your sniper skills in actions because enemy AI is distance triggered and this allows you a hack in some of the more open moments.

I would recommend the game, but you won't be missing out if you passed over the DLC.

The good part: the story is kind off fun, but definitely feels a bit rushed at some times. 
The bad part: The game is really kinda bugged, cut scenes automatically skipping while there's still a scene or 2 left, monologues being stuck and replaying themselves over and over again, cop cars and traffic being spawned upside down or blocking the road. 
Also the DLC's are a terrible arcade style which I couldn't put myself to finish.

TL;DR
Good but rushed story, very bugy game, DLC's are bad.
Sometimes it is time to stop.

Yo, so you wanna know about Mafia II, huh? Alright, let me give you the lowdown on this game. It's a ragin' rollercoaster of a ride that'll have you laughin' and cryin' and blowin' away bad guys like it's nobody's business.

In this game, you play as Vito Scaletta, a wannabe mobster who's tryin' to make a name for himself in the world of organized crime. You start off as a small-time hustler, workin' your way up the ranks and takin' down anyone who gets in your way.

The graphics in this game are insane. The city is so detailed and realistic, it's like you're actually there. And the characters? Forget about it. They're so lifelike and well-written, you'll feel like you're hangin' out with your real-life goombahs.

But let's talk about the real star of the show: the action. This game is chock-full of shootouts, car chases, and all-out mob warfare. And let me tell you, it's a blast. The controls are smooth and responsive, and the gunplay is satisfying as hell. Plus, the game's got some really cool set-pieces, like a prison breakout and a casino heist that'll have you on the edge of your seat.

But don't get me wrong, this game's not all guns and explosions. It's got a deep and emotional story, too. Vito's journey from small-time hood to big-time Mafioso is packed with drama and heartbreak, and you'll find yourself really gettin' invested in his struggles and triumphs.

Overall, Mafia II is a damn fine game. It's got everything you could want in a mobster epic: action, drama, and a whole lotta style. If you're a fan of the genre, you owe it to yourself to give this game a spin. Just don't be surprised if you find yourself up all night playin' it. It's that good.

Mafia II is a game I‚Äôm so slowly becoming obsessed with. I only have five hours on it so far, but the original release is pretty good! However, it‚Äôs very much a game from 2010 with jagged anti-aliasing and Xbox 360 vibes. So out of curiosity, I wanted to check out the remaster to see if it ran better and looked a little more clean‚Ä¶

But remember, kids: Most remasters are slimy, cynical cash-grabs that ruin everything we love about old games. 

Mafia II: Definitive Edition is a mistake born out of laziness and piss poor optimization. All the care and love that went into the remake for the first Mafia is lost here. Just slather some hi-res textures and bad saturation and call it definitive. What a mudda fwuckin‚Äô joke! 

First of all, it‚Äôs a major downgrade visually. Yeah, the original wasn‚Äôt much of a looker even by 2010 standards, but this issue was remedied by great retro filtering, the level of detail found in the streets of Empire City, and the utilization of physx particle effects. The remaster has all of that, but the aesthetic is completely ruined by over-saturation and the loss of graphical nuances (fabric physx and character animations). Yet, textures are overhauled significantly with some improvements, but they are so insignificant to the overall experience. 

Secondly, the game is a glitchy mess. Like more so than the original game! Flickering effects and performance issues are still prevalent 2 years later. The original Mafia II had fps drop, but the fact that it wasn‚Äôt patched for a modern release is the pinnacle of laziness. Those 50GB didn‚Äôt do  nothin‚Äô!

This game is a literal waste of space. Even though I got it for free, I would trade it in for a refund. Keep playing the original.

Here's my detailed review of Mafia 2: Definitive Edition (TL;DR: Fun game, great story, a bit on the buggy side though.)

Graphics (7.5/10): Not spectacular, you can tell it was a game made in the 2010s. the textures (while improved) still aren't the best, and there are times where bloom is excessive.

Performance (7.5/10): It takes some tweaking to get this working perfectly, at least for me, make sure the priority for running Mafia 2 is "high" (not "Realtime.") and also set PhysX to medium as high is extremely resource intensive. after doing those 2 things I averaged 150fps. This game is rather buggy too, nothing really game-breaking, but it's definitely immersion-breaking, there are quite a few outfit related bugs. and there's major graphical bugs during a couple of cutscenes in the chapter "Balls and Beans." Also due to how this remaster was done, many of the bugs from the "definitive edition" are also made present in the "classic" version which comes with the game.

Controls (10/10): Controls are snappy and responsive, you will rarely find your character being too slow to do what you want. going in and out of cover is smooth, you have 3 different walking speeds even on keyboard.  Driving feels really good too, and it's weighty, as it should be while driving these giant chunks of 40s-50s steel.

Story (8.5/10): Very good story, believable characters, good humor, some of the best f-bombs in history. You are an Italian immigrant by the name of Vito Scaletta, who was drafted into WWII in 1943 as they needed people on the Italian front. after getting shot you're sent back to the US and your friend gets you out of the war. However your family needs money to pay off a loan shark, so your friend gets you set up with some jobs that keep escalating further and further. That's about as much detail as I can go into without spoilers.

Final score: 83.7%
This is a solid game, and I really enjoy the story, but a multitude of bugs and lack of polish keep it from being better. People coming to this after the incredible Mafia 1 Definitive Edition will most likely be disappointed that this game didn't get quite the same treatment. However if you do like Mafia: The Lost City of Heaven, or its recent remake, Mafia: Definitive Edition, you should definitely give this a shot.

TL;DR Fun car stuff. Mediocre gun stuff. Action packed mafia stuff. Pr0n. GTA in the 40s and 50s. Amazing plot, with a world and score that fits. One of my all time favorite games.

An excellent story with memorable characters set in a city that never sleeps. This is the story that turned Vito into the stone cold mobster he is. He goes from poverty and oppression to war, and then into the criminal underworld with Joe. Everything, with the exception of the middle point of the game, is done with Joe. The ending with Joe shook me and my girlfriend. Poor Vito. Must play, and get Joe's Adventures DLC to get the full experience. Also, 50 pieces of pr0n scattered around the world to collect.

Joe's Adventures take part during the middle part of the game, so I recommend starting the adventures after completing Chapter 6 (Time Well Spent) in Vito's campaign. There are 19 more pr0n collectibles to find and "spend time with"
(no srsly there is a stat for time spent viewing the pr0n)
I feel like this shouldn't have been a DLC, and more of a intermission character swap. But you can thank the publisher for that BS.

The Betrayal of Jimmy and Jimmy's Vendetta both take place during outside of Vito and Joe's story lines, and is not cannon to either. Jimmy is just a random dude doing missions for some mob guy, and other than that the story isn't really important. Hell, Jimmy's last name isn't even mentioned. Ever. At any point in the game. What does matter is that Jimmy's story lines are a free roam action movie with guns, cars, and plenty of shootouts. I recommend playing it after finishing the story line of Vito and Joe. By then, you should be able to deal with the noticeable difficulty bump in Jimmy's campaigns.
Even though I talked more about Jimmy's campaign than Vito and Joe, I must emphasize that Jimmy is extra. There are no new pr0n clips or collectibles added, and only 1 car is added. Get this if you want more of Mafia 2, but don't expect the same wow out of Jimmy's "story line."

Onto the common points.
The music on the radio as well as in the game is phenomenal and makes the world feel like its in that time period. Perfect.
The radio personalities also add to the game and make if really feel like there is much more going on in the world.
The voice acting is great.
The driving is something you will do a lot, and I love it. There are plenty of cars to choose from and enough customization to make it fun to hoard cars. (A tip, hoard the culver empire and smith custom 200. IMHO they are the best all round cars with enough speed to get anywhere in a hurry without using too much fuel. There's a reason why the cops use them. The houston wasp isn't a bad choice either.)
The shooting is not so great. The cover system works against you constantly, and more often than not the pistols and the shotgun will be much more useful than the 50 round tommy gun. Which greatly saddens me because mafia shootouts and tommy guns are supposed to be together, man. When you eventually get your hands on the MP40 or .38 machinegun, there will never be a need to use the tommy guns. Also, you can't gun and drive, so there goes your power fantasy of wanting to drive-by  a bunch of goons with a tommy gun, like in the movies. The sound effects for the guns do the job.
The graphics are good enough maxxed out at 1080p on my PC, however I remember playing this on my PS3 near when it came out and thinking that there was no way a console game could look this good and be this fun. The streets and alleyways are full of NPC's, and there never is a shortage of cars on the streets. (looking at you  GTA <.<)

There is enough content here (if you bought the DLC) to keep you entertained for at least 20 hours.

10/10

2022 edit: This game is incompatible with my dual monitor setup. I have to run only one screen at a time or it will default to 1080p. My main monitor is on a rtx 3070, and i run most games at 1440p. Disabling the dual monitor setup via windows key + P  works. My guess is the game is loading into only 1 api per boot, so it defaulted to my 5700g graphics chipset's optimal settings.
Gameplay is great, but graphics engine messes up all the time.  Still an offer you can't refuse.

The game itself is not bad at all, but compared to the remaster of Mafia 1 it scores very low.

The story is really good, I like the progression in the game and all of the challenges the main protagonist has to face. The music is also nice and you can enjoy a nice cruise around the city while listening to the radio. Another thing they nailed is the map itself, very unique in my opinion, which is interesting to explore. There are the different vehicles, guns, and shops which also add to the games' charm and not the mention the magazine collection ;).

Aside from these positive features, there are some key elements that are ruining the experience for me.

There are a lot of visual bugs & glitches which I usually tolerate in any game, since its impossible not to have such, but in this game there is a bug in every possible mission. A very annoying part of every mission is going to your bed/home just to finish it. I had to replay several missions like 10+ times (not exaggerating), and some chapters even, because the characters AI would break and you cannot finish them.

Another issue is with driving 100 km/h besides the police and they don't give a damn, but when I drive 41-42 km/h call all units....like what the heck. Somehow when you're on 3 or 4 stars and there is no police following you, they still manage to shoot at you from somewhere, they are not even behind you or visible on the map. 

Aside from this there are these invisible edges, specifically on the highways, when you are too close to the railings, you somehow hit an edge and instantly die, this is if you drive fast enough, but I thought it's ridiculous. 

Another thing they could have focused on is the day and night spawning NPC's. Why is there the same amount of traffic and people in both day and night, this makes no sense to me, it is nothing game breaking, but a personal critique I guess. 

One last complaint regarding the progression in missions and the re-spawn points if you die during the mission. I don't remember in which missions exactly, but upon dying you are brought back almost in the very beginning of the mission. I believe that transferring you relatively close to where you died would be better and not being forced to replay almost the entire mission, just to die from one bullet in the head and reset it again...

I am not complaining that the game is hard or anything like that, this is just my experience with this game and some people may disagree with what I am commenting. I like the game overall and the challenges it sets, but having to replay missions because of issues in the game and all these bugs/glitches just totally drain the fun I was expecting to have while playing the game.

I'm sorry, but they should have done a better job with this remaster...

"Mafia II: Definitive Edition" is a bad, cheap, lazy, and unnecessary remaster of [i]Mafia II[/i].

To add insult to injury, it is carrying more bugs than the original and is demanding a whole 50GB of your real estate (compared to ~8GB for the original).

I received this for free when it released because I already owned the original game. Which is "fine", but should also be telling [i]you[/i] something about the amount of differences there actually is to be found between the two products (and how much 2K is actually valuing this one). Visually speaking, there is barely any differences to really speak of between the two versions of the game. Yes, the characters faces and textures are slightly higher in definition, which can be nice in the cutscenes, but in no world nor reality does this justify for me the additional 42GB of storage space required and the bugs.

You should make up your own mind about it, and I am under no illusion that most people will not fall for the fallacy of "Newer = better" (that is to say, I do expect most people to fall for that fallacy), but perhaps try to keep in mind that [i]Mafia II[/i] is fine as is, and that not only is this "Definitive Edition" almost entirely redundant and unnecessary, it is also making for an overall worse player experience.

Frankly, I wouldn't be surprised if someone were to tell me that the only reason this even exists is to forcibly expose players to the 2K Launcher everytime they try to start the game (so that 2K can nag you for your personal data and target you with advertising).

This game is trash, first one is much better.

The driving is the worst in any game I've ever played. The combat leaves a lot to be desired. Realizing it's a game before the modern era of gaming, it is has frustrating checkpoints, sometimes being closely spaced and sometimes not happening until after several mission objectives have been reached.

The difficulty is purely based on the abysmal health system. 3-4 hits and you die. Health regenerates partially, but the only way to fully regenerate is to eat food, food which is not available in the middle of a mission. Similarly you will frequently die while driving, having a car turn into your path with no ability to dodge it. Then one accident and you're dead.

On top of all of this the story is more or less a simple rehash of the original. Be a guy, get noticed by the mob, join the mob. All the while, driving to an objective to A. Watch a Cutscene, B. Shoot a guy. C. Fight a guy. D. Walk to a thing and press X. Then you get in another car and drive to another thing. Once you've done that, you get to drive home and sleep to go to the next chapter.

That's the game. You can steal a dozen cars for a guy. You can rob some stores or buy some clothes. All that is for nothing though because about every 7 chapters the game deletes your money and your wardrobe so the game can continue making you go to work.

This is more subjective, but the world doesn't feel complete. It feels like the Joss Whedon Justice League, where everything was supposed to be dimly lit and atmospheric, but then it got the color saturation pushed to 11 and brightness pushed to 12. So the whole world feels like it was made for a different game.

this one is significantly worse in quality compared to mafia 1 definitive edition
its technically more stable (it only crashed 1 time and it bluescreened my computer so that was very cool) but performance remains fairly bad, with the game struggling to run at certain sections, frames are never stable and often drop significantly at random, even in fairly unremarkable enviroments
the audio mixing in this game is also some of the worst i have ever heard in a game, i have never heard anything like it in a serious product

the story is a bit so and so, it has higher highs and lower lows compared to mafia 1.
its not so much that its particularly compeling, your guy waits all of 1 second before being alright with killing 100 guys for 50 dollars and doesnt actually seem to care a whole lot about what goes on around him, but the story at least tries to take him to varied places and "do" more

the gameplay is overall fairly bad
cars have somehow worse controls than the first game, with the wheels of every car having the grip of a bar of butter on a frying pan (something like the racing section from mafia 1 would had been literally unplayable in mafia 2), movement and cover is weirdly stiff compared to the previous game (but is offset by weapons being MUCH more accurate and lethal) and you spend an absolutely inhuman amount of time driving from place to place

driving in itself isnt so much the issue, its that it often feels meaningless and like some way to pad out the gameplay, as you'll often be asked to drive across town multiple times per mission for really trivial reasons, so you spend what feels (or might very well be) half the game just driving, usually in complete silence
another thing the game does is have a variety of what i assume are meant to be immersive actions as part of some missions, we're talking things like "move this box extremely slowly to this place" or "walk to the box and grab the cigarettes to give to the guy very slowly" and so on, which could just as easily had been relayed in the form of a small cutscene which it DOES DO sometimes. it feels really inconsistent and like the game doesnt really respect your time

its not that id want more combat and less driving/actions though, combat is fine? i guess? but with weapons being so accurate and lethal its really just a thing of sitting behind cover and burst firing your smg at enemy heads (which kills them instantly), its not particularly hard or engaging, at most you feel mildly frustrated or inconvenienced over having to redo a fairly long section against enemies that can kill you in as little as ¬Ω a second. i think one of the major issues is that you have so many weapons, you are never made to choose what weapons to bring or pick up, or be careful with how you spend ammo, you are never at a danger of running out of ammo, once enemies use smgs you never have a reason to use shotguns and pistols, and so on

the last gripe i have is that car customization and gun stores are pointless, just as pointless as money is
you'll rarely if ever be allowed to actually use your own car for things, and the game will super frequently take all your weapons away from you. as in, take them away and not give them back.
so you can go to the army surplus guy, buy an smg thats fairly rare, and then 30 minutes later the game just yeets it and insists you use the semi auto pistol. you may as well not even have had these things, but i do remember that the game came out in an era where a bunch of companies really wanted to have gta mechanics and features in their games so eh

dunno though, its a game that exists, play through it once and forget about it

I only give this title a thumbs up because the main story is intriguing and they improved the visuals of the characters (minor, more facial textures in this version). Overall, if you've played Mafia 1 (Classic or Definitive Edition), Mafia 2 maintains the vibes of its predecessor (content, action, etc.). If you want to continue the Mafia series, this version is worth purchasing. However, Mafia 2 DE appears to have more bugs than Mafia 1 DE in my experience.
Spoiler alert: [spoiler] Remembering the mission where I had to follow Luca to the hideout, that moron crashed into other people's cars without my interaction, and the game failed me because "Luca didn't get there"? Or when I went to see the arsonists who set my house on fire and he crashed into two cop cars just to get out and collaborate with the other cops to shoot me down? I'm losing my mind with these cops, it doesn't even make sense. I didn't take a screenshot, but they're literally standing next to each other, guns drawn, pointing at me. [/spoiler]

BUT for the love of God, I would strongly recommend you to leave these 3 DLCs alone as you complete the main game, just don't even bother consider playing them and move on with Mafia 3 or something rather than wasting your life on these like me. First and foremost, Mafia 2 DE includes three DLCs (2 for baldie Jimmy and 1 for Joe). These arcade games have a timer and, in my opinion, the missions are patched together and repetitive, making them unworthy of playing. I'm not exaggerating, but stay away from them if you want to keep your sanity. The majority of my time in Joe's Adventure is spent doing repetitive arcade quests, driving around, and picking up floating icons just to drive to another location to do some boring stuff. The cops must be the most irritated, as they are both stupid and racist. Every mission, I had to change outfits, and it feels like they could hear your gunshot from 500 kilometers away and still recognize your appearance and car plate. Oh, and there are no checkpoints in each mission; if you fail at some points in one quest, you must restart from the beginning.
Spoiler alert, again: [spoiler] There is a mission in Joe's where you have to drive to ABC Hills (ABC = Something i cant remember) to steal a luxury limousine with 3 thus guarding it. Even if I wait for the cops' cars to drive away to began the shootout, they still can performed impossible things like issue a wanted posters and my car plates. How could I even complete this mission when they require me to keep the perfect condition yet the cops are like magicians appear from nowhere. Yes, I did double check if there are any blue-shirt morons wandering around both on mini map and outside. [/spoiler]

Overall, this game is worth playing if you are interested in the Mafia triology. Just dont bother with the DLCs. Hope these help. Ciao.

This edition also had some "bugs" like big ones, one time Vitos head practically was collapsed in on itself, another Joe was COMPLETELY invisible during a cut-scene even though it played out like normal, sometimes you could see through your player models (for sure if you wear Lincoln Clays combat fatigues, textures popping in and out, and sometimes doubling/overlapping dialogue. Mafia 2: Definitive Edition is a solid single player title and a great sequel to Mafia. The characters are well written and the story is written well and very satisfying to play. The action scenes are pretty fun as well and driving around Empire Bay is always a treat. I highly suggest you give this game a try if you enjoy action games or enjoyed Mafia: Definitive Edition.

The story is the only reason to play this. It didn't get a remaster, just a release ngl. The gameplay is okay at best. Half the time you'll be pissed off at a bug or getting pissed off that a guy you shot point blank with a shotgun didn't die. You're better off playing the 1st or 3rd if you want good gameplay. But I did like the story. If you liked the story of the first one then try it out, if you didn't you might as well skip to the third. The only reason I played was the story. Everything else about the game annoyed me, the combat is awful. You can't blindfire when in cover, so every combat encounter has you either waiting for an enemy to peak (Which they do very rarely) Or rushing them which results in a 50/50 chance of them dying with 1 shot or them taking 200 bullets like they're iron man. Also no grenade hotkey (Which isn't horrible lots of games don't have it) But it becomes such a pain in the ass to scrolls through 10 weapons just to throw a grenade. The driving is also a pain, which you do a lot (No one can drive themselves you have to drive and get shot at pray to the gods your AI buddy can fucking aim) Also you can't shoot while driving, which baffles me because you end up in car chases (Alone) while getting shot at! So you have you either hope they miss or dodge the fucking bullets. Cops are also so inconsistent they sometimes pull you over for going 41 miles an hour but will let you go while you're going 200 miles an hour. They are also just pains in the ass, which may be what they're supposed to be I just get annoyed with them easily. But what I think is one of the most annoying things is how many times this game just takes away all of your guns and money and never give them back. But then in the next level give you 20k. It's like this game couldn't pick a direction. Like if you wanna take all my shit then take it don't act like you took it then give it right back. Although you never get your weapons back which is bullshit (I bought a Kar then they took it in the next level lol) I think this game should only be played if you liked the story. No other reason the only reason why I'm giving this a positive review is because the ending was kinda good imo and wasn't very straight forward (also don't play the dlcs please fucking god don't)

[i]You take a long drag from your cigarette.  Acidic smoke fills your lungs as a numbing calm washes over your body. [/i]

Mafia II?  It‚Äôs a name you‚Äôve not heard in some time, maybe too long to be safe.  How was it?  Well, It‚Äôs certainly not the life for everyone.  As it should be.  If everyone had the stomach to do what you did society would fall apart at the seams.  Maybe it already had.

You swirl the glass of brandy in your hand.  Its soft brown features glisten off the dimmed desk light, waiting to reach your lips.  But it feels heavy in your hand, so far out of reach, the endeavor of drinking it seems to be more effort than it's worth.  Your sins weighed too heavily on the drink.  Frankly, you couldn‚Äôt blame it.

It was all hubris in the end.  The shining city was alluring to all who entered, who wouldn‚Äôt want to take it for themselves?  The streets are alight with neon signs, each corner is carefully crafted after the rockin‚Äô punk of the 1950s.  A new age with new ideals.  The fidelity and detail was breathtaking.  A diner at every corner and a crooked cop at every other.  Whether they pulled you over for a ticket was a fickle thing.  But it‚Äôs the only time you ever stopped to appreciate the world around you.  You were always in such a rush running around the city it became mundane, flashing past you like a moving picture you were only half paying attention to.

The cars were beautiful, the women even more so.  The fancy clothes, the guns, the respect, for a time it was all yours.  You can see moments, flashes of the good times.  When you had everything and you felt unstoppable.  But those times were always fleeting, always destined to be faint memories lost in the dredged mud of regret.  Cause at the end of the day it's not the good times that stick with you.  It‚Äôs not the drunken sex parties that keep you up at night.

Your drowsy eyes linger on a glimmer in the corner of your shabby apartment to the only clean thing there.  An old nightstand with a Colt .45, fully loaded with the safety off.  It always sits by your bed, always, just in case.  In case it's your door they come bursting through this time or if it's all just‚Ä¶

You shake the thoughts away.  Taking another drag of your cigarette.  Smoke permeates the room again giving the whole room a gray, misty atmosphere.  It smells terrible but it's comforting in a way.

But your eyes don‚Äôt leave the gun.  You don‚Äôt clean it the way you do cause‚Äô of the dust and grime.

It‚Äôs so vivid, as clear of a picture as you could print.  You can see the three pinned site in front of you, you see the burst of flame and the shocked look on the boy's face.  Christ he couldn‚Äôt have been over 18.  There were waves of them.  Nameless people one after the other gunned down by your hand.  Sometimes it felt like a shooting gallery, like one arena after the other.

But with your arsenal it never posed much of a problem.  From pocket pistols to submachine guns you‚Äôve used it all.  Even MGs at some points, shredding through people.  After which you‚Äôd stop off at home, wash the blood off your suit and be off again to the bars and shops.

But maybe you could live with that, they chose that life same as you.  You see them every once in a while.  In the reflection of windows and at the corner of your darkened room but they don‚Äôt haunt you.  Not like your friends do.

You can‚Äôt quite imagine them now.  It‚Äôs still there but their faces are foggy and hard to make out.  Sometimes you almost see their smile.  On the grassy plains of central park drunk off a bottle of champagne, but still it's hard to make out.  It‚Äôs like an echo, coming back distorted and broken from the mountain tops.  There‚Äôs only one clear image you have left of him, one seared into your mind forever.  His broken and contorted body lying motionless on the ground.

You see his face.  Emotionless, eyes clouded over, staring at nothing.  You have a hundred memories of the two of you and only one keeps you up at night.

A far off siren blares through the night air, no other sound permeates the air until you put your burnt cigarette out on a nearby ashtray with its brothers, producing a soft hiss.  You slam your drink and stagger over to your bed, sitting down on it.  The rest is short lived as a knock wakes you from your thoughts.

[i] Brap Brap Brap! [/i]

The wooden door echoes and goes silent.  No one calls to you from outside and you don‚Äôt call back.  You casually grab your pistol by the nightstand, in no real hurry, and bring its sights to rest on the door.  You stagger a moment, the bourbon fogs your vision for a second and you threaten to topple over.  But you rally and hold yourself up.

Your focus should be trained on the door but your eyes can‚Äôt help but wander back to your nightstand, back to a singular framed picture.  It's a picture of you and‚Ä¶  Him.  You're both smiling and waving, standing in front of a car, it‚Äôs red with a white stripe down the middle.

For a moment you forget about the constant dread and fear.  You're back there in the car park and you're happy.  Not for the car, or the money or even the fame.  You‚Äôre just happy to be there, with them.  As much as you try to hold onto it it starts to fade away like a pleasant dream in the darkness.  

You hear someone whisper to another behind the door and the unmistakable click of bolt falling in place.  It seems like things are coming to an end for you.

And maybe‚Ä¶  Maybe that‚Äôs not such a bad thing‚Ä¶

[h1]Decent idea, questionable execution and WAY too much bloom[/h1]

I've been a fan of the series forever and with II being my introduction, it's also my favourite. Which is why it's a shame that the "Definitive" Edition is a tad underwhelming. It's not all bad, some extra cars & suits are neat and I don't have any complaints about the sound changes but when the file-size is almost a whole gigabyte bigger than the remake of the first game, it [i]does[/i] raise some eyebrows as it's hard to see how that 25GB or so of assets are utilised. 

Granted that the textures and models look notably better, but corners have been cut quite a bit and some of the post FX choices are questionable. One thing you'll notice almost right away is that just about every light source is significantly brighter and it's not uncommon for sidewalks to be glowing on a sunny day. It's a shame to see them pull a Rockstar and have a smaller dev team "remaster" one of their older titles but at the very least, it's still playable and isn't [i]too[/i] unpleasant to look at.

Would I recommend it over the original? Not really but at the very least, you get the option of sticking with the original as well.

[h1]Definitively Recommend[/h1]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2363382893 [b]NOTE: I have not played the classic version and this was my first playthrough of Mafia II.[/b]

[h2]Story[/h2]
Takes place in 1945 where protagonist Vito Scaletta returns home after serving US Army to avoid prison time for a committed robbery. With the help of his partner in crime Joe Barbaro Vito tries clearing the debt tolled upon his family of a mother & a sister by his late father from a loan shark. He then begins to make gain contacts & perform jobs that leads to his involvement in mafia. There are many interesting characters you will meet & work with for the length of its gripping story. I loved every bit of it & Vito Scaletta is a name I'll never forget. 

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
Majority of gameplay consists of you going from point A to B and sometimes C.  This gets repetitive very quickly & sucks the strength of it's ongoing storyline. Hence driving obviously fills up majority of my play time. Driving feels decent. You can customise your car with a few options in areas of paint, body & wheels then store 'em in your garage. 

Fueling / Cleaning / Repairing cars,  buying clothes from various stores around the map, consuming food from the fridge at home & buying weapons remind you that this is an open world game. All these activities are totally optional & you can finish the game without ever knowing any of these. Some achievements are tied to specific activities which apparently is needed to be done before the accepting the final mission because you cannot roam freely after the credits roll without starting a new game.

The world is beautiful, there is a part in campaign when [spoiler]we transition to a few years later scenario where the world is changed on a large scale.[/spoiler] This moment felt very fresh & appreciative when I experienced it for the first time.

[h2]DLCs[/h2]
They do offer interesting stories & cutscenes featuring characters from the campaign but at the the cost of doing repetitive strips of generic mission more than once which is boring as hell. Just finishing a DLC mission alone is a rare achievement because it requires so much will power to go through all three of them. 

[h2]Opinion[/h2]
It looks amazing, especially with ReShade. I found no bugs, no issues with anything & it was a smooth experience till the end. Thought it is a definitive edition I would've loved some extra features addressing issues mentioned above like a fast travel option or the ability to roam freely after the final mission but I guess that's not how mafia works.

I disagree with the reviews presented here, this edition works great but If you're convinced by others, try the classic version because this is a legendary game afterall, definitive or not.

I've never truly appreciated the 40s or 50s.  Yeah, some of the cars were cool, but it's not something I cared about.  When playing this game, though, oh man, I fell in love.  Gameplay was good, gunplay was great, story was great, but the overall atmosphere of the game is what had me addicted. I spent a lot of time driving around and admiring the world, admiring the cars, etc.  Mafia 2 really opened my eyes to the glory of the 40s and 50s car wise.  There were so many I really loved.

One small detail that I really loved was if you had a passenger in your car and ran a red light, your passenger would call you out on it.

I really loved all the radio stations and the on air djs.  It was very relaxing and entertaining not only to hear old songs, but to hear the djs talking about world events.

I really appreciate the devs giving us a junkyard and letting us take cars there for money.  I was doing that for hours just to extend my time in the game because I didn't want to quit.

One gripe I had was with the police. Holy crap were they overly aggressive when in a pursuit!  Was a bit much at times.

The saving system in this game was really confusing and weird.  It never explicitly said "sleep in a bed to save", but it also didn't say if there was auto save.  Closing the game was like gambling, you never knew if you'd be at the spot you left off at or an earlier point.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game.  There were a lot of small details and quality of life things that GTA would never, ever have.  Also surprised about the playboy mags actually showing naked chicks. LOL

This game used to be really good, but unfortunately it has been updated and now comes with malware known as the "2K Launcher" with no easy way to disable it. There is an option ingame called "disable launcher", but that does literally nothing and keeps resetting to default if you change it. If you start the game, you will be greeted by a the 2K privacy policy, there's no way you'd ever hit "accept" if you read and understood all of it. You don't have to accept the privacy policy to play the game, but if you refuse it, you will get nagged by it every time you start the game. The game also keeps nagging you to create a 2K account, which again you don't have to do to play the game, but if you don't do it, the game will keep annoying you with it every time you start it.

If you buy Mafia II Definitive Edition, you will also receive Mafia II Classic, which is the superior version as it has neither of these anti-features added later. There is no way to buy the original version individually on Steam anymore, so you'll still be paying $30 for an 11 year old game. If you really want to play this game, get the original version via retail or whatever, but don't buy the Definitive Edition.

After the initial release bog had settled, and many bugs worked out, I'd like to give a more accurate review on this title.

For all intents and purposes, I will not be reviewing Mafia 2, rather, it's Definitive Edition release.

The impact of Mafia 2 is not often mentioned in games today; simply because triple-A titles today do not respect much of the ideals that Mafia 2 was developed under, as they have no such need for depth today. in a few years from now, we will come to appreciate gems like Mafia 2 as they may not exist by then.

That is why we need the Definitive Edition Remaster. There are sacrifices - such as the weird color correction choices, more reminiscent of Fallout 3 SweetFX mods from 2010. However, 10 years after it's release, it is a good thing to see a title still recognized and updated by it's publisher. Most companies would want to snuff this game out of public eye, especially around the time of a new release, as to ensure sales on their new title. 

Just thankful this game hasn't been left behind yet.

Mafia 2 and the DLC it has are fantastic games. The story isn't a Shakespeare novel but its definitely not bad (id give it a 7/10). The visuals are great and match the theme of the game with the dark grittiness of the mob mixed with the gritty of the 40's in the early game and the brighter parts in the 50's with cars having pastel colors. The sound can be troublesome at times with what seems to be echo or delay in foot steps especially when inside buildings or on quiet areas. The gun play could be a bit better but considering this is a remake i wouldn't knock it. My main gripe is that for a remake while it stays true to the original game (don't get me wrong that's a good thing) I hate that it has the 2k account integration every time you open the game to the title screen. I also wish that when remaking this they'd included an option for first person view since that's better than the over the hood view when driving and would make an already detail filled game even better. The music included in the remake is good and matches the period (although i cant say if they removed anything) and doesn't seem to have the issue games like GTA 3, Vice City, San Andreas, and IV have with music getting removed over time due to licensing problems.

Mafia 2 is awesome. The problem is certainly not here.
This "enhanced edition" shows everything that you should NEVER do when you release a remaster or a definitive edition.
Ugly antialiazing conflicting with soft shadows, no modern PC games options, bugged dialogs, missing characters during cinematics, VERY LOW framerate when physics are wild (do you remember the bar destruction with thompsons ? When you give this kind of project to a dev team, you should chose engineers and mathematicians. Not juniors and graphists.

Never do that again, please.

This version is a quick cash grab by the publisher and developer and shouldn't be supported.

The entire Mafia Trilogy has been a favorite of mine and the Mafia II is a beautiful 2nd Volume.  Vito Scaletta is an immensely likable guy and a great protagonist.  Empire Bay is beautifully rendered though honestly I wish it was a little bigger.  The DLCs are great add-ons and way better than the ‚Äúfreeride‚Äù in Mafia, though honestly, The Adventures of Joe is more enjoyable than Jimmy‚Äôs two DLCs.  Probably because again, Joe is a likable guy, loyal to his buddy Vito, and smart in his own way.  Jimmy however, is mostly an enigma.  He doesn‚Äôt appear in the main game, and has no interaction with Joe either.  He is also much less likable, and I don‚Äôt really care if he lives or dies. Joe and Vito, I cared about.

One of the best things about the game is all the cars you can drive around.  Though Hanger 13 gave them fake names, they‚Äôre almost all based on real cars and a little bit of research will reveal that they did an exceptionally good job pulling them all together and rendering them pretty accurately, considering.  The Body Shops that are available and the opportunity they give you to upgrade your car is super cool.  This has to be one of my favorite parts of the game.

There are a large amount of weapons available and you can carry one of each type. Hanger 13 was also mostly authentic with the weapons basing them on real weapons and keeping the names relatively close the real thing, for example, the 1911 pistol, from Colt, is described by Joe in one cutscene as a 1911 ‚ÄúCole.‚Äù Still, I appreciate that they stayed mostly true to the real weapons with a few minor errors such as the 1911 firing with the hammer forward instead of the hammer back and the same with the M1A1 firing from the closed bolt (bolt handle forward) vs the open bolt (bolt handle to the rear).

I hate that you can‚Äôt save the game when you want to save the game.  It automatically saves at specific points and always during ‚Äúchapters‚Äù of the story.  So if you go out trying to build up your garage of cars, using the money in your bank account before it disappears (because you will lose it all in a specific chapter), you had better finish that chapter so it saves.  I once went around grabbing cars, painting them and stashing them in my garage, only to get killed and lose all the cars I had paid for.  It does not save when you park a car in a garage.  And since the game is so linear (not as bad as the first Mafia) it is a trick to find the time to get some cool cars in your garage.  Plus, it never really explains any of the side missions.  You have to figure that out on your own or research it on the internet. Seriously, there are about seven cars I stole, upgraded, painted, and parked in my garage that I lost because I didn‚Äôt hit a specific checkpoint save before I got killed. That‚Äôs usually when I quit for that session. Very frustrating.  But I learned my lesson and now only get cars when I complete a mission and before I go home to end it.  Though, this is much easier to deal with in the DLCs.

One thing I really wish they had is user accessible folder where I could drop in MP3s of my favorite songs from that era that would automatically play on the radio along with all the songs they already have.  Hanger 13 always selects an excellent variety of music but that variety is limited enough that you will hear the same song within an hour.

Minor things that bugged me in the beginning is Vito getting off the train carrying a suitcase.  Soldiers, like him, whether on leave or discharged, would be carrying a large dufflebag of the their personal gear.  That was the suitcase for anyone in the military (Marines and Sailors would call theirs a ‚Äòseabag‚Äô).  Also, the jump wing on his uniform are way too big.  His unit, the 506th Parachute Infantry Regiment (PIR) is a real unit that was one of the regiments of the famous 101st Airborne Division (represented by the ‚Äúscreaming eagle‚Äù patch on each shoulder).  This is the exact same regiment of Easy Company of the famous ‚ÄúBand of Brothers‚Äù book and miniseries.  The only problem here was that the 506th first saw action in Normandy, not Italy.  Ideally, they should have made him a member of one of the PIRs from the 82nd Airborne.  Those guys did see action in Italy.  Should‚Äôve made him a paratrooper in the 505th PIR!  Those guys were the only ones that got 4 combat jumps in WWII.

So my complaints are minor and I very much recommend this game.

I played Mafia 1 back in 2002 when it came out. I didn't know what to expect and other than the racing part, I loved the game! Back then I skipped this one, since when you can only afford one or two games a year, stuff gets sorted away. I later read about Mafia 3 in a gaming magazine. I was curious about a Mafia game where you played as a black character mixed with the carpo system, but I never got to play it, since the release date was about a year away or so when I read about it. And time flies.

"What the heck are you going on about?!! How is this relevant for Mafia 2???" you might scream in a rage fit about now, and I'm sorry for the exposition. Here is my point. I saw Mafia 3 was on here on sale and got the full package since, why not?

I then played Mafia 3 first, since that was the game I was curious about. The gameplay got a bit boring with 3 around the end but the story! OMG, that story!! Mafia 3 is the perfect revenge story in the universe of Mafia set around the Vietnam War. The controls are the same as in Mafia 1 (except for the speed control since at that age apparently speeding is not a big deal)

Then I played Mafia 1, to see if I remember what the fuss was all about back in the day. And once again the story is just amazing! You get to love and feel every emotion of the characters in your path, and everyone feels alive! The Racing still sucks, which was about the only thing I remembered outside the ending, so I had really high hopes for Mafia 2.

Mafia 2's turn then came and the first thing you get introduced to is a new fresh interface and control system that sucks all the ass that it can suck. It's clunky and slow, and I can't count how many times I died when I tried to equip a weapon. 

Then we have the story... yeah I see people who are praising the story and I have no idea what they are talking about. There is NO character growth. I had no shits to give anybody in this game, and it kinda seems like the game felt the same way. Even Vito's family didn't give me any emotional reaction, because they are just there once in a while.

Spoiler rant

Of no importance. Just... meh!

Hold on ... the game is not bad.

The game has an amazing story (excluding the end). Mission writing is equally good to the first mafia game. Gun-play is equally good, while the world's atmosphere albait a little stale, feels nice. 

The problem with this game, is it's gameplay. The way the story is laid out, makes you feel more like a taxi driver rather than mafia guy. From the 15-20 hours you are gonna need to finish the game, more than half of them you will spend them inside a car of yours, going from point A to point B. At this point, I think i can go to Joe's place with my eyes closed, from any point of the map. The game unfortunately doesn't offer a "teleport" option (like in Mafia I) either, in order to skip a few known and boring rides.

And if that wasn't enough, the game has awful checkpoints as well. The developers have put very few checkpoints during missions, which is not necessarily bad, but they have put those few checkpoints at very awkward places as well. Meaning that if you die, you might need to re-drive back to the mission's location, re-watch (thankfully skippable) cut-scenes, and sit back during scripted portions of the missions. In general if you die during a heated mission, you usually have to waste a few minutes to go back to where you were.

Additionally, I would like to talk about the game's "remastered" aspects. The game has a bunch of glitches, some of them that seem to have been transfered straight from Mafia II classic as well. Additionally, character graphic glitches are prevalent from time to time as well, breaking any immersion that you might had at the moment. In general, it's not a good "remastered" game. The developers treated this remaster as a cash-grab, since they just did a reshade, repacked the game with zero changes, and shipped it back as something new, which is totally a fucking lie.

Finally, what the hell did they do to my boy [spoiler]Joe[/spoiler]? The ending was pretty bad and inconclusive, leaving you with a cliff hanger, which is implied, but never going to be clearly laid out. Everybody can think for themselves what's gonna happen to both  [spoiler]Joe[/spoiler] and  [spoiler]Vito[/spoiler]. It's a linear game, therefore I would have liked a linear and straightforward ending as well.

To conclude, playing this game is not going to be a very happy journey. Especially after the second half of the game, in which you are going to start getting frustrated more and more with some of the stupid game mechanics. Nevertheless, if you really really want some mafia dose in your system, make sure you have played Mafia I first, and then buy this (ON A SALE) as well.

Fantastic game from a time when writers weren't afraid to tell a story.

+/- Light remaster. This is not a complete remaster. Its only upgraded textures and additional post processing. Sometimes certain PP effects don't work well.
+/- Semi open world. There is no free roam at all. Any time you are alone without a timed objective you are free to explore the city. There isn't much to do besides grab collectables. Much like the Mafia 1 it just facilitates the story.

+ Great story with memorable characters.
+ Voice Acting is very good.
+ Immersive world design
+ Vehicles are well designed unlicensed recreations.
+ Driving physics are interesting on simulation. Attention to detail with effective transmission modelling and tire compression under these heavy vehicles using old tire technology. Descent damage modelling.
+ Combat is well made with focus on realism. All weapons are one shots to the head. Just consider magazine size and dispersion for the best results. Hand to hand combat is okay. It takes a little getting used to. Particularly on hard difficulty.
+ Music selection is descent and adds to immersion.
+ GPU accelerated physics/PHYSX. Works wonders for this game(and most other games its implemented in). A surprising amount of deformation and particles breaking off of objects makes environments more believable and interesting.
+ Collectables. For once they are contextual and relate to the games world rather than being random meaningless objects(granted they still don't actually do anything). Real images from early playboys and wanted posters are the exploration collectables. The others are progress based.

- Post Processing. Some of the new effects don't work correctly. Such as blinding lens flares/bloom in certain lighting scenarios.
- Particles. Some physics particles accumulate without being deleted until going out of range causing massive lag spikes in a few specific scenarios.

[u]What I liked about the game[/u]
[list]
[*]	I liked the cover system. It made the combat so much easier, especially compared to the first game. 

[*]	I liked the new things they added into the game, like cloths shops and being able to customize the players car. I always liked the little things they added like refueling your car, getting your shoes shined, or being pulled over by the police. 

[*]	Loads of collecterables, like Play-boy magazines and wanted posters. As you progress through the game you will also unlock artwork. 

[*]	Vehicles handle better this time round. They are still sometimes tricky to handle; which is to be expected from vehicles of that era, but they aren‚Äôt as bad as the first game. 

[*]	The voice-acting and cut-scenes are stellar. The game had some really likeable characters like Joe and Leo. 

[*]	A good selection of weapons from that era. 

[*]	Interesting story. The story is similar to the first game; basically you start of as an associate, then you become a made-man and then you fuck it up.  I also really liked the WW2 section. 

[*]	The hand-to-hand combat is very fun and enjoyable. 

[*]	I thought the stealth sections were pretty good. You are able to dispatch enemies quietly.

[*]	I like the amount of destruction you can cause in each level.  

[*]	Good soundtrack. 

[u]What I disliked or was disappointed with[/u]

[*]	I remember in the first game that once you completed the game you unlocked free-roam extreme were you could complete challenges to unlock unique vehicles. There is  no free-roam mode or extreme . 

[*]	There‚Äôs no countryside to explore, like in the first game. 

[*]	 I wish there was a larger variety of shops and gimmicky stuff.  Overall I felt the game needed more content. 

[*]	Shame you couldn‚Äôt fire weapons while driving. 

[*]	No melee weapons. 

[*]	The game is too short. 
[/list]
[u]Conclusion[/u]

Overall I enjoyed Mafia 2. They have made a lot of improvements compared to the first game, like a cover-system, good hand-to-hand combat, and improved vehicle handling. The game has a nice selection of fire-arms from the period. The game has likeable characters, Like Joe. The game isn‚Äôt as generous with content as the first game, For example no free-roam or free-roam extreme , and I wish they added a country-side to the map . If you enjoyed the first game then I highly recommend you buy this game.

- Statement
Some would call Mafia II: Definitive edition a hot mess, or that It needed a lot more content and graphics upgrades to be considered "Definitive". I've looked at over 100 reviews of this remastered game, 98% of which are completely wrong and unfair. Half the people never gave it a chance and never looked into the smaller details or took notice of anything. The other half are bagging on it because others are too, to the point where people are making up lies to make the game seem worse. This is my complete "REAL" review of Mafia II: Definitive Edition. (Note: I won't be covering the story, I'll only be covering the improvements and changes that make this version better than the original).

- Quality Improvements
People argue that the definitive edition looks worse then the original, mind you the original was made in 2010. If anything the definitive edition is 10 times better, adding on 34 extra gigabytes worth of upgraded content compared to the original 8 gigabytes in the original. The game improved hair. Characters now have individual strands of hair instead of the blocky textured hairpieces from 2010. And the game is now rendered into a 4K resolution with massive texture upgrades and improvements such as walls and floors. Faces now have dimples, holes, scares and wrinkles that make the characters more realistic. Throughout the Definitive Edition game-play I only encountered 1 bug in an entire 11.7 hours of game-play, which involved a 1 seconds clip of a face being stretched.

- Gameplay 
(Nothing has changed in the gameplay, I'll just mention some great features and a few flaws that were carried from the original)
Mafia II has decently realistic vehicle mechanics. It's the small details that count, such as the tires bouncing and going flat when going up and down hills and bumps. The gun-play is also very smooth, fairly easy when in gun fights, nothing really presents a challenge. The Fighting mechanisms are absolutely amazing and smooth, with various different fighting techniques, Styles, strengths and finishing moves depending on the objects closest to you. The cars are accurate for the times, but unfortunately the world doesn't feel as lively as it should be. 

- Conclusion
I 100% recommend this game to anyone who's looking to spend 12 hours immersing yourself in a decently mature story from the time your wake up to when you go to sleep, then this is the perfect game for you.
Weather you prefer to play the 2010 original or the Definitive edition it really doesn't matter. You get both when buying the Definitive edition anyway.

TL;DR: The upgrades the game got were decent enough to be considered definitive, I'll give the game an 8/10.

It started out alright but the further I played, the more issues showed up. 

To start theres some positives.
The new graphics are for the most part nice. Especially if you have a 4k display. Mouse and keyboard controls aren't bad. The main story is still one of the best. It comes with all dlcs, and gives you the original version of the game with its dlcs. You get new outfits and vehicles for having Mafia 1 and 3 DE and for linking a 2k account. The playboy magazines are in tact. 

So whats wrong with the definitive? Well for starters physx is gone unless you delete a file, and even then it only works for your character. Your hat can glitch into your face in certain cutscenes. Characters eyes can be stuck in a certain spot. And dialogue in one of the last chapters play all at once over each other. Every time you go into Joe's apartment complex the cops describe what you look like, acting like they're trying to find you. Some cutscenes have people talking but their lips aren't moving. Major fps drops in shootout areas. Distance pop in is way too close. Objects on the ground kept flickering unless I messed with the anti aliasing settings. Smoke effects run at like 2fps. Seeing a pop up notification saying I've lost connection to the 2k servers got annoying. You're required to have the game run alongside a horrible 2k launcher that's also a resource hog. (You can play without this launcher by launching from the games executable file instead of directly on steam.)

All in all you're better off playing the original version with some mods if you want better visuals. I thought maybe this was a bad remaster because 2k rushed its development, but, given D3Ts previous and new lazy remaster work, I think its a rush job by both studio and publisher. We were promised fixes for this and Mafia 3, but they never came. It's a shame because this franchise deserves better...

It was a bit of an interesting choice by 2K to make this sorta deal. You remake the entirety of Mafia I from scratch, putting Hangar 13 on the deal to do so. You do a slight spit shine to Mafia III, unlock all the DLC and such and add your lovely DRM that works so well that you grenaded your own game and then you did this. You took a game from 2011 that looked pretty alright, gave it the world's most VAGUE spitshine of a remaster and called it a day. Oh and the DLC's no mortal man bought.

You are lucky I love this game 2K, because I will still give this game a positive review. ONLY because you allow people to play the Classic Edition through this. Take this new review as more of a talk about Mafia II (Classic) than the DE, because beyond a few hundred bugs, it's still the same game.

Mafia II is the game that got swept over in the fanfare about GTA IV back in the day, and most people just sorta shrugged at it as a result. Mafia as a franchise has been perpetually stuck playing second fiddle to GTA and being judged for it. The ol' Crowshaw meme of "CRIME DOES NOT PAY" does fit this game like a glove, but in comparison to the 19 other games that tried to do that, Mafia II actually decides to make that concept work and matter by giving you actual stakes to lose.

You play as Vito Scaletta, a slightly DIFFERENT first generation Italian immigrant to America who initially falls in line with his best friend Joe Barbaro into the seedy underworld of crime in the city of Empire Bay. Through a world war and back again, you follow the pair as they attempt to pay for Vito's fathers debts by any means necessary. Quick, simple and with enough points for the plot to throw wrenches in it. And with a fun 1950's world to explore, various old cars to steal and destroy and a very fun and basic gameplay system to it, Mafia II is a modern classic. Like the original, it's simple in regards to most of it's actual parts, but that simplicity works in delivering the story. 

Are the plot points super deep? No. Do I care? No. I still remember most of this game and I can't remember like 95% of GTA IV so who's winning here, Rockstar?

I bought this game while it was one sale, around the time when Grand Theft Auto Definitive Edition was being released to great fanfare. Initially I treated it with a lot of caution: having played GTA over the last 17 years, I was afraid I had grown too accustomed to its universe and that I might therefore become unable to enjoy comparable games.

My fears were overcome after I gave Mafia 2 a few tries. It is a strong title with a very good storyline and characters as well as great graphics. When you drive around you absolutely do feel as though you are in an East Coast American city of the 1940-50s, 2K Games and Hangar 13 deserve great credit for how they recreated this kind of urban environment.

Their attention to detail is further evidenced by the level of detail of the vehicles. The player can find out various information such as the vehicle's top speed and power when it comes to vehicles that have been stored in the lockup. Also unlike GTA, vehicles kept in the garage remain in the player's possession; you don't have to fear about losing them in random missions.

I played the main story on Medium difficulty and felt it was just right: not so hard to the point of making it impossible to enjoy yet challenging enough to keep it interesting. The combat and shooting modes are impressively realistic. You won't see stuff such as heads exploding when you shoot at targets. Also depending on where you aimed you may need more than one shot to finish off an enemy, which brings added realism. There are not many missions, however this is offset by the complexity of the missions and the time required to complete them.

Vehicle handling is a lot like in Grand Theft Auto IV: the vehicles feel heavy and therefore convey the feeling of being behind the wheel. Car crashes have been replicated quite well: they won't suddenly turn into trash or catch fire as in some of the GTA games.

A common criticism I have read of this game is that it is not truly open world: you have to follow a specific sequence in completing the missions and do not have total freedom to explore Empire Bay. I did not find this to be detrimental to my enjoyment of the game and I certainly do not think it should prevent others from enjoying it for all its other aspects.

Decent game with decent atmosphere. Very story-driven. The open-world is kind of just scenery filler. Once you've seen it, there's not much point in it other than your progression through the story, meaning there's not much to do in this game outside of the story, sadly. Some clunky gameplay, which becomes particularly relevant in combat situations or when you get caught by the police, who will fire on you non-stop for merely chipping someone's vehicle or even when you're the victim of NPCs attacking you (at least, as far as they know) lol. 

Examples of clunky gameplay are:

1. Sometimes your guy might switch to the wrong side of cover when you're trying to aim the opposite way
2. There may be times where your guy doesn't switch to his weapon on time in the heat of the moment, getting you killed.
3. NPCs may take cover in front of you before you do. In this situation, it can be difficult to get them off on time, and you can get lit up by gunfire as a result of this.
4. When you pull someone out of their car, the game won't automatically put you in the car, but instead force you to press the action button again to get in it. Might be a personal choice of theirs, but seems counterproductive to the idea of stealing people's cars and can negatively affect you in a heated situation, especially if you forget how it works.
5. Molotovs will sometimes hurt you when their effects are physically nowhere near you, which can get you killed, obviously.

The game design is quite outdated in those ways and can be quite frustrating.

Also, be mindful that the checkpoint system can be quite bad too, and set you some ways back if you happen to die at a certain point (this can be especially frustrating if you played on Hard difficulty like me).

Overall, these gripes are annoying but fairly minor for the most part. There are only a few situations where it might impact you greatly, unless you play like an absolute madman. Otherwise, the game is a reasonably fun, atmospheric story that will take you through a variety of interesting scenarios. I think it's worth experiencing once. Not much replayability though, unless you like collecting magazines and cars but hadn't done so already in your first playthrough. It's a reasonably short game if you just go through the story the whole time.
