[h1]‚ÄúYou know what capitalism is? Getting f***ed!‚Äù
~[i]Tony Montana, Scarface (1983)[/i][/h1]

‚ÄúThe Definitive Edition‚Äù. What do you think of when you hear those words? Well, technically, you can think of pretty much anything. Just because those words mean nothing. Publishers can literally sell us anything and call it ‚ÄúThe Definitive Edition‚Äù. And [b]Mafia[/b] is a perfect example of that. At the point I write this, there are three games in the series. All of them have ‚ÄúThe Definitive‚Äù editions and all of those editions are absolutely different. The first [b]Mafia[/b] got the best treatment. [b]2K[/b] asked their division called [b]Hangar 13[/b] (which was already merged with [b]2K Czech[/b], creators of the original game) to create a proper remake and gave them enough money to do a good job. [b]Mafia III[/b] didn't get any treatment at all. They've just released a free update that was supposed to improve graphics (spoiler alert ‚Äì it failed and almost broke the entire game) and called it a day. Now, what about [b]Mafia II[/b]?

For [b]Mafia II[/b], [b]2K[/b] hired a little (about [b]100[/b] employees) British company called [b]d3t[/b] and asked them to do a quick overhaul. So... yeah. Unlike the first [b]Mafia[/b], the ‚ÄúDefinitive‚Äù edition of the second one is not a remake, but a quick remaster. Remember what we had in [b]Shenmue[/b] remasters? Well, it was [b]d3t[/b] who worked on them. If you've played modern versions of [b]Shenmue 1[/b] and [b]2[/b], it should give you a general idea 'bout what to expect here. Take the old game, sprinkle it with some modern technology and voil√†, that would be [b]$29.99[/b] (note how price of [b]Mafia II[/b] remaster is exactly the same with the one of [b]Shenmue[/b]). At least, that was the idea.

Because while [b]Shenmue[/b] was a console title, the one that only [b]DreamCast[/b] (and [b]Xbox[/b] in the case of the sequel) owners were able to play (as long as we're not talking about emulators, of course, but that's a different story), [b]Mafia II[/b] was a multiplatform game that was already presented in [b]Steam[/b]. And obviously, asking money for such a basic overhaul would have make a lot of people angry. So, [b]2K[/b] decided to play it smart and sold the new version only for console owners. Didn't make much sense for [b]Xbox One[/b] owners who still had their [b]Xbox 360[/b] discs on them (backward compatibility, ho!~), but for those who didn't have the game yet and, of course, for [b]PlayStation 4[/b] users it sure did. So, that's how it was about selling this version, while in [b]Steam[/b]? In [b]Steam[/b] everybody who already had the original version in their libraries got the new one for free, while for the rest of us the new version just replaced the old one in the store (more about that later). So... we've got an updated version and we didn't even need to pay for it. Life's good, right?

Well... technically ‚Äì yes. Yes, it is. On paper. It comes with all [b]DLC[/b]s (unlike the original version, cosmetics in the remaster will unlock with time and won't be available at the beginning of the game), the textures were replaced with those of higher resolution, there's an [b]MSAA[/b] ([b]Multisample Anti-Aliasing[/b]) support, there are improved shadows and light, new technology was used for both hair and foliage, etc. Some sounds (like sounds of shooting) were also improved. In other words, like I said, on paper it's pretty cool. Unfortunately, only on paper. Because it looks like due to limited monetization, this remaster got very limited budget. And as the result... yeah. You know how it is about those quick and cheap overhauls. Instead of fixing and improving things? They just make everything worse.

First of all ‚Äì nobody cared to fix the old bugs. It's not like [b]Mafia II[/b] was the buggiest game ever made (thankfully, [b]Todd Howard[/b] wasn't involved in its development in any way), but it had a series of well-known bugs that pretty much everybody who played the game before knew very well. It was only logical (yes, you can call me [b]Mr. Spock[/b], thank you) to fix those in the remaster, but like I said, nobody here bothered. Quite the opposite, it looks like the game became more buggy now. At least, while playing the remaster, I've experienced way, [i]way[/i] more weird bugs than before. One of cutscenes with [b]Harvey Epstein[/b] is broken too and looks like a mess. The color palette was changed and looks way more cold than needed, while ‚Äúretro‚Äù effect was completely removed, which makes the game to look... weird. Especially for those who remember playing the original. New hair and  foliage technologies are half-broken and come with tons of visual glitches (remember [b]Cyberpunk 2077[/b]? That's the stuff.). New light looks totally out of place and may even cause troubles. Etcetera, etcetera, etcetera.

In other words, we've got the same exact game, only worse. The ‚ÄúDefinitive‚Äù edition of [b]Mafia II[/b] is one of those cases, when it's actually a better idea to stick with the original. Sure, the original didn't have high resolution textures optimized for [b]4K[/b], but honestly, I didn't feel bad playing it on my [b]4K[/b] TV. The remaster, on the other hand, felt way worse in many ways. There's a little ‚Äúbut‚Äù here in a form of the exclusive [b]DLC[/b] that adds suits and cars from the other two [b]Mafia[/b] games, though. We've got [b]Tommy[/b]'s [b]Shubert Six[/b] taxi and gangster suit to remind us about good ol' days in [b]Mafia 1[/b], while from [b]Mafia III[/b] we've got [b]Lincoln[/b]'s [b]Samson Drifter[/b] (which totally breaks the balance, by the way) and army coat. Sure, it's nothing big, but... it's there and some die hard fans may be interested in it.

All in all, though, it's still a no-no. [b]PlayStation 4[/b] owners don't have much choice, but for everybody else out there it's way, [i]way[/i] better idea to stick with the original. Which... unfortunately you can't buy in [b]Steam[/b] anymore. Well, technically you can, but to get access to it you should buy this crappy remaster first (it comes with a free copy of the original version). Because, like I said, that's what crappy remasters do. They just make  everything worse. One way or another, that's pretty much it. You already played the original game before? Just forget about this remaster. Nothing good here. Totally no reason to bother. You haven't played the original yet? Wait for a good discount and pick this one up, [i]but[/i] play the original that comes with it instead. You're on [b]Xbox One[/b]? Go buy the [b]Xbox 360[/b] version. And if you're on [b]PlayStation[/b]? Congratulations, you're screwed. Dixi.

[h1][b]Remastered Empire Bay[/b][/h1]
[i]Mafia 2 is for many a favourite game and some cursed it. 2K decided to make a remaster of it with all DLCs in one pack called Definitive Edtion. Let's take a closer look at it.[/i]

[b]The Main Game[/b]
The main game has a very good story. Maybe it could be longer, but I'm fine with it. You will visit many interesting places in Empire Bay city. You will play as Vito Scaletta who came to the USA with his parents and sister to start a new life. You will want to be a real gangster, but later you will see it isn't as easy as it looks. I play it in the Czech language and I must say dubbing is perfect. There are many funny buzzwords and smile situations.

[b]DLCs[/b]
DLC pack will double your playtime. It's not like the main story. There are arcade missions where you go destroy stuff, hijack cars and kill some guys. What I miss in DLCs are cutscenes. Before nearly every mission you have only text without dubbing. Joe's Adventures has 4 story missions but Jimmy's Betrayal and Vendetta have fewer missions with cutscenes. I would appreciate it when mission descriptions have dubbing at least. Overall DLCs are fun to play. You have free-roam where you can do anything that you want.

[b]The Main Game and DLCs[/b]
The game has very good music. You can listen to the radio in a car with many nice old songs from the 40s and 50s that make you feel you are really in the 40s or 50s years of the 20th century. Also, the cars list offers pretty cars and the game has awesome car handling. Not awesome, it's one of the best car handlings in open-world games. When you choose simulation in options you will need to drive really carefully if you don't want to end in a tree or wall. Mafia 2 offers a good selection of weapons. You can find here classic Thompson 1928 or Colt 1911, German rifle Karabiner 98k or Italian submachine gun Beretta Model 38. There are a lot of toys to play with.

The graphic is better than in the original game. There is no that a quite strong bloom effect. In the 2010s it was fine but nowadays I'm happy it's not here. Textures are better and the whole Empire Bay looks updated.

Both the main game and DLCs have quite a lot of bugs. Sometimes face is bugged in a cutscene, people are doing stupid on street things like jumping over a fence without reason. Another bad thing is optimization. There are some FPS drops if you have NVIDIA PhysX enabled. Also, the game crashed a few times during my playthrough. And there is one thing that is not a problem of remaster but Mafia 2. Devs should make more missions in the 40s in snow. In the main story, there are only a few missions in snow and in DLCs, there is only one in Joe's Adventures. Snow is well made here and fun to drive. Cars feel like they are driving on snow. The devs didn't use the potential of snow.

[b]Ok, let's conclude. I think this remasted should be better, but it's not a disaster or bad. If you have played the original Mafia 2 before and you want to replay it, you can try this remaster. If you haven't played Mafia before I recommend you to play it. Yes, it has some bugs and optimization isn't good but it's playable and fun. You can enjoy a good gangster story, with many funny quotes and with Joe and Jimmy you will turn the city upside down.[/b]

[h3]üéµStraighten up and fly right, straighten up and stay right ‚Äî cool down papa, don't you blow your top.üéµ[/h3]
[b]Mafia 2[/b] is as close to a modern classic as I can think of, maybe not as much as the first Mafia as that got an outright full-on remake and this didn't. But I've never played classic Mafia 1 or the remake. Mafia 2 was my introduction to the Mafia games.

[b]So what's different about the Definitive Edition?[/b]
Well, you can't buy the classic version anymore for starters. Additionally, this version [i]technically[/i] speaking, looks nominally better with higher resolution textures and improved lighting and weather effects. But it also suffers from an immense amount of technical failures that the classic version never had. More on that later.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2695557172

It also features the additional episodes (scored arcade style for replayability) ‚Äî The Betrayal of Jimmy, Jimmy's Vendetta and Joe's Adventures.

[h3]Made Man[/h3]
You'll play as Vito Scaletta coming back from the war after being arrested and given the option to enlist instead of serve time. The game is based in Empire Bay, a fictional city that is based on New York City. As you may have surmised by the title, you join the Mafia  ‚Äî where a number of low level robberies, criminal mischief and other more serious offenses take place. Such as the manufacturing of corpses and their disposal. Some might call it business. As I've stated, I never played Mafia 1, but I have played the more divisive Mafia 3 and I understand why it's so polarizing. I happened to enjoy it. From my experience, you don't need to have played any of the other games to enjoy Mafia 2 or 3, but you'll get more out of them if you do.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2695615949

[b]Mission Structure[/b]
The game is actually [i]extremely[/i] linear. It's more like a movie that just happens to take place on an open map. There's never any choice as to what mission you can do next. Some missions don't give you the best equipment but because the map is technically open in between objectives, it allows you the agency to go get better stuff or not. Either by buying better weapons, stealing a better car or upgrading one you've already got. The only significant side activity you can do is to bring cars to the scrapyard for extra cash, otherwise the only side activities are shops ‚Äî whether you engage with them as a normal customer or just rob them is up to you.

It's one of the only open-world games specifically about crime where the police will come after you for minor traffic offenses e.g., speeding, fender benders with non-police cars. You can actually turn on a speed limiter to prevent you from going over the speed limit. Oddly, the police are not concerned if you enjoy driving against traffic provided you don't make contact with any of them. Of course, they'll also come after you for the [i]real[/i] crimes being committed throughout the game as well. Speaking of, being wanted by the police has separate ‚Äúmeters‚Äù, one for if the vehicle (license plate) is wanted and one if they're looking for your physical description. You're able to essentially hide if you switch cars while unable to reach someplace to change your clothes. But the police will notice if you drive too close.

[h3]Anecdotes[/h3]
Given the advantage of a retrospective viewpoint, you may pick up on things this time around you didn't the first time, such as Dave Fennoy voicing some of the radio dialogue ‚Äî he's in a lot of games, but most notably, he's Lee from Telltale's The Walking Dead. And I'm almost certain I heard Mike Patton of the band ‚ÄúFaith No More‚Äù voicing some random NPCs, though I can't find any credits for him. He also does a lot of voice work including his more known parts like ‚ÄúThe Darkness‚Äù where he voices... the Darkness. As well as Nathan ‚ÄúRad‚Äù Spencer in the 2009 Bionic Commando re-imagining. 

[h3]TechSmech[/h3]
I ran this game using a Ryzen 5 5600X and a 6GB GTX1060 and it ran relatively fine beyond the much higher temps that a much more demanding game would typically run on this system. There were also sequences where a lot of fire or environmental damage would cause the game to drop down into the 40FPS range. I was running it at 2560x1080@75Hz as that is what my monitor's refresh rate is, I didn't test it at higher resolutions or frame rates, though there is a custom FPS limiter in the options.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2695567581

The 5600X, in my testing, draws about 35W when it's basically doing nothing and I use stock Wraith Stealth cooler so it tends to run a tad hot in the first place. However, in my Prime 95 stress test at 100% usage, it pulled 75W while never exceeding 83¬∞C at stock settings. So despite the shown CPU temp seeming relatively high for what's it's doing, it's well within its normal range. It's just... a lot higher than more demanding stuff ‚Äî I'm left to believe that something is simply [i]off[/i] regarding this game.

There were glitches regarding facial animation and 'headpieces' to include hair and hats being set [i]within[/i] the head during cut scenes. Sometimes ‚Äúambient‚Äù dialogue would repeat. And I don't mean like it simply ran through all the available recorded lines throughout the course of the game or sequence, I'm saying it'd repeat the line immediately after finishing it while cutting off other lines. It only happened in a few places, however.

[h3]The Gist[/h3]
It's unfortunate that this ‚ÄúDefinitive Edition‚Äù is riddled with technical issues. But I feel the narrative is strong enough to pull through those more [i]dicey[/i] moments. It's the type of game that will get remade for the next 30 years, even if it's called something else.

To start things off, for a definitive edition there really isn't anything definitive about it.  The only difference I saw from the classic was a couple graphical updates to some textures and that was it.  Heck the classic edition had more starter outfits, though you get more in the definitive edition once you progress much further in.  I guess what I'm getting at is this feels like a lazy port instead of an actual definitive edition of a game.

The story is alright, although there are some story beats that you can see coming from a mile away which can kind of take you out of the experience.  I really enjoyed Joe and Vito, they came off as best friends throughout the adventure and even looked out for each on multiple occasions.

However there are issues, one of those things being that this game is very buggy and it becomes quite noticeable once you are further in.  Most of the time it's down to pathing where you can watch someone just run themselves into a wall and keep walking.  This one was the most prevalent.  During certain cutscenes the mouths just stop animating and it's like the character is trying to be a ventriloquist(This is the second most prevalent one i've found).  For some reason it didn't really start cropping up for me until the butcher level.  The game does use a physx engine which can be turned off.  I recommend turning it off because for some reason it will tank your framerate to a very noticeable degree in certain areas.  When I turned it off, the framerate drops disappeared and I saw no real change in the game, as if nothing actually used physx.

Ambient Occlusion will always reset itself to "Medium" the next time you boot the game up if you try to set it to "High".

The sound is decent, though I believe it's because they used the same sound files from the classic edition with no actual changes.

All told Mafia 1 Definitive Edition felt like an actual definitive edition of it's game and did more to claim that title, while Mafia 2 Definitive edition just feels lazy and didn't improve on anything other than a few textures and is somehow buggier than the classic version.

This is the worst "definitive edition" of a game that I have ever played.  You get sharper textures, some of which look great but what you gain in sharper textures you lose in numerous bugs and instability.  facial animations stop working, collisions are off, exploding verts and melting NPC models.  The cut a couple songs and for whatever strange reason the radio keeps playing the same songs over and over again.  The original had a ridiculous soundtrack and radio songs but it appears broken in this version.  Some audio overlaps and cuts off early.  This is a real shit show.  The game itself is pretty rough and demands you like to drive.  Still it's a very good story, I am not looking forward to playing Mafia 3 but I guess I should since they gave it to me for 79 cents in their desperate bid to get people to buy it.  Anyways, long story short, I think you get the original game with this purchase so go ahead but I don't know what to say if you're on the fence about what version to play. Mafia 2 is severely underrated. The gameplay is fairly similar to GTA but it is way better than GTA V. The police will chase you and fine you for speeding, when police see you commit a crime you're wanted until you change you clothes, if you are caught stealing a car or escaping in a car that car becomes wanted and you have to change the plates, damage to cars is permanent, and you actually can run out of gas (its not annoying though because it doesn't happen often). The story is also significantly better than GTA V's in my opinion although it does end somewhat abruptly and leaves more to be desired. My only complaint is that there isn't very much to do in the game outside of the story and that is something GTA V does better. If Mafia 2 had more open world elements I think it would be remembered as one of the greatest games of all time and could have possibly rivaled GTA.

Not as lazy as the Dark Souls remaster, but it is by no means a great remaster. All that's been changed is textures which do make characters and environments look better, but the game overall looks very similar to the original Mafia 2. Not only that, but this game has a huge problem with objects popping in, as well as the FPS tanking in larger firefights. Some characters also have problems with their eyes during cutscenes, as they'll not even be looking at the player but rather off to the side, and it's quite noticeable. 

While I enjoyed Mafia 1's story more than 2's, I did have fun with the game. Combat feels OK, though a bit generic, and the whole semi-open world execution is nice as it allows you to explore the city as well as allowing you to feel like you're progressing in the world (in terms of cash and cars). The soundtrack is pretty banger, and though I felt many characters paled to those of Mafia 1, there were some that I did really enjoy.

I'm only giving this a negative review because the remaster is so obviously just a re-release that claims to be a remaster, yet is so lazy in actually remastering the game. If you do buy this it comes with the original Mafia 2, and my recommendation would be to install that version unless you really want to play with some slight visual improvements.

Ok, I'll address the Definitive Edition (DE) situation straight out the gate. People need to settle down, it's not that bad. If you already owned the original, you got it for free and vise versa if you bought DE first. Even so, the only difference is that there are some 'up-resed' graphics, that's it. This is definitely not the same as Mafia 1 DE (so... maybe some false advertising in that regard). Considering all that, this is the first time I have reviewed Mafia 2, so how does it hold up?

Visuals are pretty good especially for the time it was originally released. Great sound, fantastic voice acting and a banging 50's soundtrack. Overall, the open world just oozes atmosphere, the attention to detail is magnificent. I know one of the big criticisms of DE on release was the bugs, but they must have been ironed out. All I really encountered was some rare asset drop ins and some weird cosmetic issues, but almost never.

As for the game-play in this open world, everything else is very solid too. I had a ton of fun with the gun play and driving, both hold up fantastically. Each chapter/level design is unique and interesting which latches on to the story so well that I was kept on the hook from start to finish.

The story itself though? The first game really took you on a journey with a man who was forced into the life of a mobster and dealing with the woes that came with it. But this one is about two guys who have completely embraced this life, regardless of how brutal the Mafia world can be! It was so much fun to revisit these characters and take in how much they love being a gangster, no matter what is thrown their way. Seriously, one of the best open world stories ever, let along mob stories.

I played Mafia Definitive Edition some time last year and had a good time. I had some time to burn and figured I may as well give Mafia II Definitive Edition a go too.

I'm happy to announce that I'm enjoying it about as much as I enjoyed Mafia Definitive Edition. 

One of the reasons I generally dislike definitive/remastered versions of games is it is never apparent what was actually changed. I never played the original Mafia II so I've no idea how this stacks up to that, but from what I understand they mostly added bugs. I have, however, only stumbled upon one of these bugs so far and all I had to do to get around it was to backtrack a couple of steps to shoot some dudes in order to progress. Not too bad. 

A lot of reviewers also criticize the game for not utilizing the open world elements a lot, but to me this is not really an issue. It just means that the creators had focus and they knew where they wanted to spend their time. In this case, they had spent their time on making the story and the gameplay around it feel as fleshed out as possible. I think more open-world games should follow this approach. Having an open world is great, but do we really need the open world tower grind that were popularized by games like Assassin's Creed? Mafia II proves to me that you really don't. Focus on what makes the game good and spend less time on content for the sake of more content and I'll be a happy camper.

Anyway, that's it from me. I can definitely recommend this game and I fully intend to finish the main story at least before putting it down.

I completed a mission that was mostly just boring driving from point to point. But I stopped before I went back to the character's home, so the mission never marked as complete, even though I had done the work. When I came back to the game, I was right back at the beginning of the mission.
Later, I went through some pointless conversations, fought a guy, had a whole cut scene during which days passed, did a short tutorial on a new combat move you get for some reason, then decided to go to bed. I turn the game back on today and I'm all the way back to wandering around having pointless conversations.
I don't know how the original version was, but if you're going to remake a game, update quality of life stuff like this. I suppose I'll settle for uninstalling and hoping that they did a better job with the third game.

Mafia II is one of the best games I've ever played.  However, Mafia II: Definitive Edition while being graphically superior to the original (not massively, but it's a nice bump from the 2010 version), it contains so many bugs I would recommend playing the original version.  It's extremely buggy, and while I cannot say what bugs other people ran into, I could not keep it steady.  I have a 2080 TI and an 8-core CPU with 32 GB of RAM, so I should have no trouble playing this.  But it seems to crash my system when loading out of cutscenes.  I checked the integrity of game files, I uninstalled it and reinstalled it, and it still does it.  I finally made it to the end of the game (fun to play again almost a decade later), but in the final game cutscene it crapped out again and now I can't even load into the game anymore.  It only loads into a black screen.  I can't even run in windowed mode, they screwed up the game code that badly in the haste to get this out to market.

They've had a while to patch it, and 2K clearly has no interest in patching it, so while I do recommend playing this game, buy the Classic version and play that instead.  This is just awful.

Overall, Mafia II: Definitive Edition tells a story that is gripping and while it may not be largely unique in the span of Mafia lore, it‚Äôs one of the best available in video game form. I genuinely cared about Vito and the terrifying criminals that surrounded him. I grew to love their antics and laugh at their quirks, and feel sorry for the situations that they found themselves in. I think it‚Äôs a little unfair to class Mafia 2 as an open-world game, because the city does nothing but offer the setting for the story to g from point a to point b. If you‚Äôre looking for a city that is brimming with side quests and random activities, you won‚Äôt find them here. What you will find is a bittersweet, interesting period piece that looks at time that is not often explored in video games, and it‚Äôs a pretty damn memorable one at that.

Here's the thing. It's a good crime story, one you'll already know if you've seen The Sopranos or any Scorcese film. But as a game...this is about as painfully average I've played. Rudimentary combat. Stiff, clunky controls and animations. And the most pointless open world that only exists to pad game length. You drive to a mission, you complete a series of thinly linked together gameplay sequences, and then you drive all the way back. This commute adds nothing but time. Atmosphere, soundtrack, voice acting, is all great. But the game holding it all together is lacking, and restrictively holds your hand worse than any Rockstar title. I get that people love this game, because nostalgia is a thing. It definitely doesn't hold up today.

Mafia 2: Definitive Edition was an incredibly solid game with a super engaging story that is about two up and coming gangsters who quickly get over their heads with a web of bad choices and wavering alliances leading to a climactic ending with tons of betrayal and drama. While the story is seemingly simple and kind of drags in the middle, it is still pretty great with an excellent ending that was super satisfying and I respect that the game takes its time in certain missions for key character building. The gameplay is more on the average side with a mediocre hand-to-hand combat that is used far too much for its own good, however the driving and shooting are pretty good if unremarkable in the genre. While not giving the same gorgeous 2020 makeover as the first Mafia game, the sharper textures and improved lighting for this remaster still makes it look undeniably better even though it still looks pretty good today. Unfortunately, the optimisation can feel pretty bad and it is sad to say that it wasn‚Äôt uncommon to see massive framerate dips and pop-in that would really hurt the immersion of Empire Bay with otherwise looks great with some great attention to detail even though it is ostensibly almost as barren as Mafia: Definitive Edition. I would totally recommend this game for it‚Äôs great story and gorgeous cityscape and I will probably replay it at some point in the future and do it‚Äôs DLCs which are included in the Definitive Edition.

Mafia II is set in a post world war 2 New York City. You play as a spaghetti slurper named Vito who goes through a lot of shit in this game. He returns from the fronts of WW2 and finds himself broke and jobless. Afterwards he does what the game promises in the title, he joins the mafia. 

 First ~10 chapters are awesome and really sell that Italian mafia feeling, last 2 chapters felt a bit rushed and didn't enjoy the same detail as the rest of the game. Nontheless, Vito is a well thought out character you can sympathise with. Also his long-life friend Joe is one of my favourites. There are some cool twists and turns in the story that keep you engaged, despite the relatively monotonous up and down driving you sometimes have to do to get from mission to mission.  [b] All in all the story is the soul reason you play this game and I rate it a solid mom's spaghetti out of ten. [/b]

If you're less into story and more into driving 'n shooting there's plenty of that too. Gun handling is meh but it's fun, and shouting [i]'you wanna mess with my family uh?' [/i] with an outrageous Italian accent whilst blasting a dozen of guys with a Thompson never gets old. However, don't go into the game expecting a GTA V style gameplay, it is not that kind of game. I found the car handling to be a bit 'slippery' but nevertheless also pretty solid. I have read of some people who don't share this sentiment, so that may be something every person has to decide for themselves. There's not a lot of RPG elements in the game except clothes shopping (which do look fucking awesome mind you, if I could i'd wear fedora's + raincoat IRL), and car customization. [b] At its core,  game mechanics are enjoyable and serve their purpose but they are not the reason I binged this game for four days straight.[/b]

Overall: 7.5/10

Story: 9/10
I had heard good things about Mafia 2‚Äôs story before I began my initial playthrough.  The fans were 100% correct.  The story itself is captivating, the tone and character interactions are reminiscent of the film Goodfellas (one of my favorite gangster/mafia movies of all time).  The story is what really makes this series stand out.  Joe and Vito‚Äôs relationship is charming and believable.  I found myself invested in the outcome of a lot of these characters.  Some of Vito‚Äôs acquaintances lack a certain depth or uniqueness to make them memorable and takes away from the story and immersion when I can‚Äôt remember who is who and what role they play exactly.

Graphics: 7/10
The game itself is quite beautiful, especially the environments.  The environment is colorful and lively and provides a nice change of pace from more of the dull open world environments we see nowadays.  Facial animations are still a bit rough.  I‚Äôve encountered the occasional visual bug.  One example that comes to mind was Vito‚Äôs hair clipping in unnatural ways during a cutscene.  The lip sync is rough at times, perhaps the remaster could‚Äôve gone further to polish some of the less than stellar animations. 

Sound: 6/10
The soundtrack is immersive and is one of the highlights of the game.  The radio stations play music accurate to the 40‚Äôs and 50‚Äôs.  My biggest complaint comes from the lack of variety in the game‚Äôs radio stations.  There really isn‚Äôt much going on and I found myself turning the radio off to avoid hearing the same song for the 10th time in an hour.  Audio bugs were more frequent than visual bugs.  Most notably there were a few missions in which the same dialogue is repeated 2-3 times in quick succession which made it hard to understand exactly what is being said.  Overall bugs and lack of variety leaves a lot to be desired.

Gameplay: 7/10
Mafia 2 plays a lot like a cover shooter with some stealth elements.  Playing with both keyboard and mouse as well as an Xbox One controller felt responsive, and I have almost no complaints with either.  The KB+M bindings can be configured to your liking if you find the default control scheme awkward.  Very standard third person open world gameplay.

Mafia II: Definitive Edition is honestly a poor example of definitive edition. Such editions of a game should be bug free and and should provide good quality touchups. In Mafia II's case, the latter is nicely handled but the former is neglected aspect. 

Character models are definitely improved with relatively high fidelity textures for the characters. But you tend to see the bugs in this version which were not present in the original version. That is where it was bombarded with negative reviews. 

For some people the playing experience was very bad. In my case, the playing experience was not that actually that bad. I experienced weird physics or mesh based glitches a couple of time in my whole play through. And very few moments where I experience FPS drop but this can vary with other users.

The good thing is that this version came up bundled with all of the DLCs, which can be extend the content for some but for me they were simply fillers and nothing more. Another thing is that on purchasing the definitive version you will also get classic Mafia II free. So that is a plus.

Anyways, my few complains are only for the version of the game. The game itself is beautiful. The storytelling, the character development and even the missions are beautiful. If you have never experience Mafia II before then you must.

I would highly recommend playing this game but for the issues mentioned about the definitive version I'll suggest to buy during sale.

This was one of those games I started over and over again throughout my gaming career but never finished it. It was mostly due to the fact that had never played the first one so I didn't feel right playing this one. Now that I have, I was finally able to sit down and finish it. Let's see how it goes.

The story follows a brand new protagonist, Vito Scaletta. He's an immigrant who comes to the US as a child with his family and hits rock bottom early. His father works a job at the docks, but spends a lot of the money gambling and so he's always struggled. He became friends with a kid named Joe and they get into lots of trouble together doing petty crimes. One day, when they got older, they get busted for a crime. Vito gets caught and has to do time. He gets enlisted in the army and gets his first real look at the power of the Mafia. While doing a mission, he and his team are about to killed, when a Don comes in and just ends the war, no killing required. Vito returns home after some time and runs into Joe again. Joe is doing much better now that he has new "connections" and Vito needs to make money to pay for his father's debts and to get his life in order so he doesn't end up working a dead end job like his father. That's where we come in.

Mafia is an Open World adventure game that plays sorta like GTA. You'll be driving cars, handling missions, etc. The narrative is what really excels in this game. Just like the first game, I really enjoyed the story. Seeing Vito go from petty crimes to get into the family. His best friend Joe is such a great comic relief/ best friend foil to the story. I will admit the story was a lil hard to follow in some points since there are so many mafia families as opposed to part 1 where they mainly focused on two of them. However, I was still able to enjoy it from beginning to end....for the a lot of it (we'll get into that in the gripes section).

Just like the first game, I will always praise this series for keeping the player straight on the path of the story. There is never any, "Look for this guy on the map to start the mission" kinda deal. Soon as the chapter starts, you drive to the location and the mission starts. When you finish the mission, you are free to roam around the city and look for collectibles, or just go to bed and proceed to the next chapter. Absolutely respect that and wish more open world games adopted this. The music is top notch in this game, I loved driving around listening to the soundtrack. Some songs I knew, and most were new to me. 

But now for gripes, and I have plenty of them. This game look snice for a Definitive Edition, but it is filled with bugs. Random trash with the texture wrapping gone, characters walking through things in some cutscenes, there were some cutscenes where Vito's head was caved in a bit (that was jarring to watch), graphical slowdowns, my game crashed once, etc. I was able to finish it, but for a "Definitive Edition" I have to say this was rather bad. Just like in the first game, I cannot stand the fire fights in this game. I feel like they're worse in this one because the checkpoint system is so bad, enemies sometimes have the ability to one shot you, and sometimes enemies don't load properly into the game so when you think the coast is clear to continue, you walk through a door and a whole bunch of them are on a stairway instakilling you. It was a frustrating slough to deal with. I wish the auto aim feature was as strong as it was in the first game's because the shootouts are the one thing I literally dread in this game. It sucks going through a whole building only for the last enemy to get a lucky shot on you and now you have to do a long section all over.

Final verdict? Check it out, especially if it's on sale. Despite my gripes, I really did LOVE the story and characters. It's what pushed me to finish the game because I really enjoyed the story being told. I still despise the gun fights and I always will, but the driving and everything else made up for it in spades. If you enjoyed the first Mafia, you should play this one...just be ready for a bumpy ride, graphically. Thanks for reading!

A retrospective view to Mafia II --- A potent shot of wine

It's 2021. The open-world game has been undergoing constant shifts with the more sophisticated plotline, like Red Dead Redemption 2, or bigger worlds with more events and stories where you can travel with a cup of coffee(Talking about Just Cause 4, Days Gone). But also with lovely buggy cities where you can make your choices, do some trading, shot some deadbeats, and --- jump into the water without creating a water splash, yeah, that's our Cyberpunk 2077~. It seems that the larger the world becomes, the more freedom the player gets. But marvelous as it looks, players may fall into the voids if handled wrong and feel lonely once the world becomes repetitive. Once players reach this threshold, the game has several ways  --- introducing MMOs, DLCs, rogue-like self-replicating missions, even some history lessons, etc.  --- to stretch its life cycle of engagement for a week or two. That said, people keep pouring their wallets in exchange for fun!  

Gargantuan and bulky as those games become, I can't help but feel overwhelmed by tons of distractions like random I-DGAF missions or trivia that have nothing to do with my engagement with the game mechanism or the storytelling. After months of gaming in the Assassin's Creed series, I've come to realize that the scale of the world and its logical complexity has its sacrifice, its potentness.

While Red Dead Redemption 2 still gives players the chance to go on a killing spree once in a while, nullifying whatever the personas built by hours of storytelling, the Mafia series takes a different approach. In Mafia II, though you can drive around aimlessly across the city, there are no meaningful objectives or collectibles like all those to-do lists in Ubisoft games, pushing players back to the track of the plot.

I would give some spoiler-free introduction to the story and protagonists for those who haven't played the Mafia series. In this game, you play Vito Scaletta, an Italian American, a war hero back in WWII, the son of a lower-class family bullied by evil capitalists. With Mafia's help, Vito managed to get back on his feet and face reality with his close pal, Joe Barbero, in Empire Bay.  

Since the Mafia Definitive edition is out, maybe consider playing them in tandem if you haven't touched them before.

Presentation 8.0: Engaging story with just the right amount of flexibility, a vivid, beautiful Empire Bay
Gameplay 7.0: A bit clumsy, feeling of greasiness when driving, punching looks repetitive
Graphics 7.0: Even though it's been years, the graphic still holds up.
Audio 9.0: One of the best OSTs I've ever heard!

Verdict 8.0: If you're looking for a potent shot of wine, here's your poison!

This game is for some unknown reason highly revered by a lot of people. I don't understand. They say the story is great. But there's a massive plothole that basically makes the whole last 30% of the game redundant.

TL;DR and for people looking to buy, don't. Just play Mafia 1.

SPOILERS

From the beginning, Vito says he doesn't like his dad. Okay, fine, understandable. Now we fast forward to near the end of the game. Henry is dead. We need money to pay Bruno. Go talk to Derek, help him out. Suddenly, we find out that Derek basically killed Vito's dad. AT NO POINT PREVIOUS TO THIS HAS VITO EVER SHOWED ANY RESOLVED FEELINGS TOWARDS HIS FATHER! Now, Vito is mad, and ends up killing Derek and Steve. Why? Yes, he is your dad. However, you have explained several times to several different characters that you don't like him and don't want to end up like him, in fact, that is Vito's entire motivation to be in the Mafia to begin with. So why are you pissed now? If you hate your father so much that you roll your eyes when your mother talks to you about him, what do the circumstances of his death matter? I feel like in a real situation, after taking that oath to join the family, that yes, of course you would be mad, but you wouldn't just fucking kill your friends because of it. More than likely, you would say that he is a dick for not telling you before and you could hold a grudge, but straight kill him? For something they hid from you for good reason? I don't understand how people seriously think this game is "a masterpiece". Not even to mention the bugs. And the graphics. Fucking Christ. This game came out last year and it looks like GTA IV. 

And the gameplay. Driving? Fine. Shooting? Fine. Level design? Awful. You can't blind shoot over the walls like in the first game, or like GTA which is clearly the inspiration or base concept for this series, so you're stuck waiting for a solid 30 seconds while 15 guys shoot at your cover, and sometimes your cover doesn't even protect you! You still take damage! What's the point of the cover if it doesn't do anything? The enemies run out of nowhere, you have no time to react, there's even a point where you turn a corner, a grenade drops down and it literally explodes before you have time to go back through the door, meaning you are almost are guaranteed to die there and have to do the section all over again. You require knowledge of what is going to happen before it happens. Not to mention the ending which is horseshit.

There are only two good things about this game. Number one is old playboy magazines. Number two is your friendship with Joe. That's it.

Shit game. Don't buy it. For any price. Ever.

Also fuck you if you think this game is a masterpiece.

Good enough story for me, to keep me entertained. And the "feel" of the 40s and 50s is certainly there. Unfortunately, these are pretty much the only positives.

But there are quite a few negatives:

- The description says "presented in stunning HD detail". Well, the graphics is one of the worst parts of the game, imo. It doesn't look good at all.

- Bugs/glitches. Haven't enountered many, but have had a few annoying ones. Like having your parter stuck in doorways, preventing progress, and having to restart missions. And cars getting stuck in something invisible on flat ground.

- Game world. They made this large city, but apart from the main story, there's almost nothing to do. And the little there is, isn't fun. Stealing a few cars for cash gets boring VERY quickly. And collecting over 180 (!) wanted posters isn't going to happen.

- Following characters is always a negative for me in games, and it's A LOT of that here. It takes away the freedom to do things your way. And there are also far, far too many "taxi" missions, meaning driving people around.

- Absolutely no replay value. This game is for the story, nothing else.

Since I actually had a good time with the main story, I'll give this one a thumbs up. But if it was possible, I'd give it a neutral rating.

So I played 23 hours of this version of the game and let me tell ya, great game, terrible port. I have a fairly high end setup, a GTX 1070, i7-2600 and 20GB of RAM, which is more than enough to run the game, in fact, the GPU and RAM are both significantly higher than the recommended specs. The issue however, is that while the game generally kept a steady 75 FPS, there were times the game struggled to even stay in double digits at all, making the game super slow and chug to get to a new area. I'll keep it brief, but in general, there were a LOT more bugs in this version than I ever remember in Classic Edition, the graphics are said to be remastered, though I couldn't tell a difference (however I haven't played the CE version in a while so take that with a grain of salt, it just didn't look terribly great), it came with 2K's launcher that it didn't tell me about, and at some points I've been made aware there are game breaking bugs that plague this version and not CE. If you can choose between the versions? DO NOT BUY DEFINITIVE EDITION! Capiche? Is it worth the struggle? ... At times, yes, I'd say the game is 100% worth a try no matter what, but if you have the choice, stay away from this version. I DID receive this version for free, thankfully, HOWEVER, it just kinda, appeared in my Steam library long after I bought the original, so I assume they were pushing for it to be the new normal version but it didn't cut it and I see why.

Pros:
Upgrades from Mafia 1 Definitive:
-Better shooting
-Better melee
-Better story
-Added Customizations to appearance and cars
-Fixed ragdoll problems

Cons:
Downgrades from Mafia 1 Definitive:
-Worse checkpoints
-Worse driving mechanics
-Skipping unnecessary drives was removed, adding an extra couple hours of wasted time to the game
-Removed medkits, meaning you have to wait for your health to recharge to 3/4th after any bullets you take when playing on medium or higher. Sometimes you'll just outright be instantly killed if you don't take the correct cover at the correct time.
-Dialogue glitches in a couple of missions

Overall still worth playing despite some glaring problems with the game.

I recommend Mafia 2 "Definitive Edition" only to those new to the game and at a heavy discount. Apart from graphic improvements, some bug fixes and the addition of more tedious collectables, its  the same as the original version of the game. 

The main story is worthwhile as it delves into memorable characters, chapters and world setting. This is where Mafia 2 shines. 

The DLC, on the other hand, is an abomination that should never see the light of day. the DLC  is a soulless mix of arcade themed missions which emphasise maximising speed and scoring the most points. My main gripe with the DLC is how immersion breaking the lack of cut scenes are combined with the inclusion of large start and finish markers.

Okay, if you haven't got the original version and if you're wondering whether you should get the original or this one, here's an honest and thorough explanation based on my personal experience.

The only thing that's definitively good about the definitive edition is better textures. The payback is that it's four times larger now (35 GB vs. 8 GB), but it's not that much of a problem today. Oh yeah, there's probably one more good thing: that nasty bug where PhysX could cause a crash is probably fixed (at least, I haven't encountered it).

Now, about the bad things:

1. With new textures, most faces now look older and uglier (in my opinion). Everyone's hair became too shiny as if it's covered in grease or is just made from plastic. Also, the 4K-textures seem to abruptly end just below the neck. If someone's wearing a shirt with their chest partially visible, It's very noticeable, and it looks... bad.

2. There's a whole bunch of graphical glitches now, like flickering pieces of textures or some floating pieces of glass "attached" to your car. Sometimes, the character's mouth won't open, and sometimes his eyes are looking in the wrong direction. (and PhysX for Vito's clothes is glitchy, too) This looks either bad, funny, or just stupid.

3. The new graphics will lower your FPS in a lot of scenes. Interestingly enough, the benchmark showed some great increase in FPS when there's no shooting or anything, but in the action scenes, it dropped so low that the average became worse than in the original.

4. Weirdly enough, the game managed to corrupt my DLC save file once, so that each time I reloaded, there was nothing but an empty gray screen with a minimap (I could move, but I couldn't see anything). I managed somehow to reach my apartment using the minimap, and when I opened the apartment door, the problem was gone. This never happened in the original version. If I weren't lucky enough to solve it, I would have to restart the whole DLC (which was 84% complete at the time) because there's always just one save file! This just isn't right.

5. In DLCs, the briefing pictures are now either missing or censored for some reason, which is not nice either. Also, some of Jimmy's lines were redubbed for some reason, and the original ones sounded better (in my opinion).

All in all, there are too many cons. I wouldn't even say that the new textures made the game look better because the difference is not drastic and, also, it's pretty obvious they weren't originally intended. I mean, it looks obvious, as if they don't belong. The original faces look more attractive and more natural, and system requirements are lower, too.

Mafia 2 is a game that slipped my radar forever and I finally got around to playing it. The story and characters are great and it manages to tell a compelling story that will have its action packed moments and its more somber character focused periods. The combat is fine and while its nothing special, it's at least serviceable. The 1950s atmosphere is great with its array of licensed music being played in the period appropriate vehicles. However, issues arise on the technical aspects. There are various visual bugs and glitches such as flickering smoke, weird physics etc that still haven't been fixed. 

Something that I haven't seen mentioned is how immersion breaking the open world activities can be. For example, for some reason every single person has a gun in every single store throughout the city and robbing the store at gunpoint will mean that everyone will whip out their guns to shoot at you. The police system is also a bit weird as the police will only stop you for speeding or crashing into people at full speed and will turn a blind eye for running red lights or driving on the wrong side. 

Overall Mafia 2 is a great experience that delivers a great story and atmosphere but is held back by some technical bugs and some nitpick immersion breaking issues.

Mafia 2: Definitive Edition. Just like the Mafia remake prior to it, I was excited to get into this one. The impetus of revisiting this story, actually completing it for once following a couple of prior attempts on the PS3 and the original PC version in the past, with some enhancements to make up for the passage of time to boot, was surely an offer I couldn't refuse... in hindsight. Having finally completed it on my Twitch.TV broadcast in October 2020, and experienced it for all that I personally feel it is worth, It only seemed appropriate that I share my thoughts. And broken down in the paragraphs below, here they are:

[b]Story:[/b] While a fairly short experience by some of today's standards, it's still every bit as good as I remembered from the original Mafia 2. It's not a dyed in the wool classic like Mafia: The City of Lost Heaven, or even the Mafia: Definitive Edition remake. But it's also not an unmitigated disaster of epic proportions that shouldn't have [i]been[/i] made, either. Thankfully, for better or worse, there have been no changes in that regard, and it's been preserved in all of its original quality. Nothing watered down, or sugared up for today's overly sensitive Z generation who have to cry to Twitter every time somebody looks at them cross-eyed.

[b]Audio:[/b] For probably 2/3 of the time I played it, it's been pretty good. However, I have noticed a fair amount of moments in the story where background noise would just be vaporized out of the cutscenes, leaving only the voice acting (which is awkward), or lines of dialog repeating more than once (which can overlap in some instances). This is a bad oversight which has broken the immersion, and affected the overall experience - especially towards the end of the game - and something that I would have to dock points over. Finally, while I understand that licensing issues become a thing after a certain period of time, legalistically speaking, I was nonetheless disappointed in the amount of cut music from the games radio stations. There are remedies for this, but none that I will publicly provide.

[b]Controls:[/b] Dated, and cumbersome. We're not talking PS1 or N64 era, but it's significant enough where I would've considered them an oversight in the remastering process. Had I been in charge of them, there would at least be two options: one for more modern controls similar to GTA, and one for the classic setup. Unfortunately, I can only judge these from the perspective of playing this with an X-Box One controller hooked to my PC, though. So, while I won't dock a [i]LOT[/i] of points, I will still be making concessions here for what it is.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] The hardest ride of them all. The AI can be straight up broken in some instances, and rudimentary actions or events sometimes don't register as they should (like the objective for crashing on Joe's couch never going away throughout the entire playthrough). And these are just a couple examples of the various bugs, big or small, that you will encounter throughout your experience with this "remastered" title.

[b]Graphics:[/b] While they CAN look better than the original game, there's a lot of things here in duality that throw a wrench into the cogwheel. Hats clipping through the player model, eyes not properly tracking, faces literally morphing off of peoples bodies, and various other things of that nature. Play it long enough, and you will discover something to hate. Guaranteed. 

...and while we're at it, a side-note concerning the PhysX: I should [i]never[/i] have to go into the game's root folder, and delete files, in order for rudimentary clothing physics to work properly, either. While not game-breaking, or even a buyer beware-grade issue, it is still annoying. It was just there, baked into the code of the original release, and should've been considered here as more than an afterthought by the developers all the same. Rant over.

[b]Overall Score:[/b] 3 out of 5. It wasn't totally void of fun, and I was happy to have finally seen this game through to the end. Playing the classic, if you can get your hands on a copy (or happen to already have it in your Steam library), I can see where that would be at least a 4 out of 5 experience - one that I recommend you dive into first-hand, wholly, above anything else. However, if your only option IS the "definitive edition", it is almost guaranteed that you will experience the same level of bugs and glitches that I've endeavored (as well as others), and I urge you to factor that into how much you're willing to spend - if you're willing to spend. Personally, I can only recommend it in good conscience at a deep (if not reasonable) sale price across both the PC, and console editions (replacing the latter entirely with a full on rental, if you're one of the lucky few who still has an operational video store nearby). The developers (or management) refused to commit to full-priced quality control with this product, opting to release it in a semi-broken state, and this level of effort should not be rewarded as such. It sets a bad precedent, and only ensures that we get more products like this in the future - an existing trend that I'm honestly sick of at this point.

So for me, this game isn't worth it not because of all the bugs, including graphical issues, dialogue being repeated twice  by multiple characters causing just a word jumble for conversation, or weird freezings. This game definitely has all of that and many more bugs. For me though, I can work with bugs as long as the gameplay and/or plot are worth it.

PLOT (light/mild to no spoilers)

 This game has so many loose ends and unexplored plot points, down to the last mission ending with a sort of cliffhanger/ open ended situation. The actual plot also abandons key aspects that never really come up again. Your sister? Shows up literally twice with no follow ups about that plot. Your family history? Shows up in 2 missions to never be talked about again. This Mafia Commission/syndicate that controls everything, including the leading familes? a Red Herring. The whole Marty thing? Abandoned as soon as its considered a heavy plot detail. The FBI? Nothing ever comes from it. The amount of plot items that show up just to be nonstarters is astounding. I think this game has 15 chapters, and I still really can't find the climax. I genuinely thought that the final mission was the climax until the game went to credits leaving me confused because we've had 0 character growth and 0 consistent plot points. This is not Mafia 1, in which its a Mob movie set in a video game. This is several heavy action sequences compounded with a weak story.

GAMEPLAY

So driving in these games always sucks. For these early open world games, driving mechanics are just awful and unwieldy. This is problematic as the game has you driving literally all across the map all the time (no one else drives???) making driving even more important than in Mafia 1. Combat is also pretty janky. It's so easy to die in this game, which sucks when compounded with the amount of enemies for action sequences. Even on normal you will fight through 15-20 guys, just for someone to one shot you from 10 feet away with a shotgun. Not to mention in some instances you can be shot even though you are in cover. Long story short, this game takes the careful almost sniping pistol practices of Mafia 1 to a Rambo with a Tommy Gun is your best means of success. I say this because I tried the whole, sit in cover, wait, shoot, go back to cover, shoot, and then tried a charge with fully auto guns approach, and the latter was much more successful. Also, the amount of gameplay mechanics that aren't even mentioned until the last 3 chapters is astounding. Did you know you can rob stores and steal things besides cars? No? Neither did I until the game tells you in the final 2 missions. Same with crushing cars for money. Also, this games has at least 2 (maybe 3) instances where you will lose all of your clothes, weapons, and money. Once would be bad but understandable, twice? GTFO.

FINAL THOUGHTS

This review is one that I regret having to write. I can honestly and truthfully say that not only is Mafia II an overall great game, and is tons of fun to play. Now, after reading that glimmering opinion, why the negative review? 

[b] WELL THE GAME DOESN'T ALWAYS WORK, THAT'S WHY [/b]

This legitimately makes me so angry, because every single fiber of my being wants to praise and recommend the game. However, morally I cannot, as there are times where a quest/mission prompt is glitched/bugged/broke or whatever, and as such, a mission cannot be continued even though you are doing everything right. It began to occur around chapter 11 for me. This is a massive issue as it means you have to quit and restart, meaning you must restart an entire chapter at times. For those unfamiliar with Mafia II, that means you might have to start over a half-hour long chapter just because a quest prompt was missing. Also, restarting does not guarantee that it will work the next time. I ended up wasting nearly an hour and a half over one mission. Nah, that's enough. 

Overall, just a massive shame that such an amazing game gets brought to it's knees over one issue.

Mafia II: Definitive Edition.
[b]Reviewing (skip to whatever interests you most):[/b]
1) Similarity with GTA-series.
2) Missions.
3) Cars.
4) Police. 
5) Bugs.

[h1]1) GTA?[/h1]
Someone, who never played Mafia series before (me!), may think it's like a GTA game.
And he'll be 50% wrong. 
There's 3rd person view, driving involved and various cars available, plus missions where you shoot enemies and escape from police. That's about all similarities with GTA.

Free roaming is limited: you play chapters, each containing 1-2 missions. You want to explore - explore during the missions. 
You've completed a mission? Next chapter starts. Plus the only time game saves - once a mission starts, [u]cannot save up manually[/u] (wtf :D )
However, there's not much to explore - [u]the city is small and not used up to its potential. [/u]
While in GTA games you end up fighting in multiple locations, [u]in Mafia II you repeat the same route: safe home - diner - thug factory.[/u]

A character only carries two weapons and any food - any - sandwich or a drink, will replenish all of his health. No need to worry about becoming chubby as in SA. ;)

The only collectibles you may care about: playboy magazines. And they must be picked up during missions. 
No, there is no mini-games like rampage, cannot earn money in taxi, ambulance or catching criminal. Forget it.

[h1]2) Missions.[/h1]
About missions. I can only name few memorable: 
a) dressing up as window cleaners and blowing up the meeting window from outside, 
b) delivering a car with broken breaks from the top of a hill 
c) aaand digging up a grave while drunk.

All missions are quite serious, so tiny-little room left for jokes (there are some, but only a few).

Main game is short. But its 3 DLCs (each!) just about a little shorter than the base game, minus videos before/after a mission.
Heavily love two expansions about Mr. Clean (lol), bold guy citing his kills and drifitng around.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2378749944
DLCs somehow stand out, they played slightly differently, involve new landscapes (snow lakes, more port fights).

[b]Two things I loved a lot: cars (driving) and police.[/b]
[h1]3) Driving.[/h1]
Vehicles! Somehow simple, but authentic physics and damage behaviour. You damaged your ride too bad? 
It will smoke and stall, get out and fix an engine. ... [u]you may also run-out of fuel. [/u]
You can also customize you license plate and colour the whole car.
When drive away with snow - it will gradually melt. But no shooting from a car. Errr...

[h1]4) Cops! [/h1]
They will chase you by two factors: 
a) if witnessed committing a crime in cloth, they run after until you change it. 
b) If spotted stealing a car, driving one in a wanted outfit - its license plate instantly becomes wanted, be sure to change few numbers in a garage. 
[u]The higher wanted level (4 stars max), the quicker they will spot you in a car in a wanted cloth.[/u]
Funny enough, you can hide in covers, behind cars and they lose interest:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2376902031

Oh, police also wants to fine you after a collision or speeding. The later somewhat inconsistent: driving above limits in a city is fine, driving within max on a motorway - is not. Eh?

[h1]5) Optimization.[/h1]
[b]Overall - very smooth and runs perfectly. Nothing game-breaking. [/b] Yay!
However, experienced minor graphical glitches: NPCs walking through textures, blurry faced, or.. this thing D:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2378748540

And yes, I still would recommend Mafia II Definitive Edition. ;)

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[h3](Spoiler-Free Review)[/h3]
[b]Mafia II Definitive Edition[/b] (M2DE) is a remastered edition of the original Mafia II from 2010, set in Empire Bay in a timeframe spanning from 1940s to late 1950s. The game narrates the story of Vito Scaletta, an Italian immigrant which, along with his family, migrated to the USA to find a better life. The protagonist's early years are riddled with difficulties (as most immigrants faced back then), so at some point Vito starts small-time criminal activities - not knowing that this decision will change his destiny forever.

üü© [b]The Good Side[/b]
[list]

[*][b]Can almost smell the gasoline![/b]
The atmosphere and setting of 1940s and 50s are recreated beautifully in Mafia II. Empire Bay proves to be a vibrant, beautiful city - even more so in this remastered version with its updated visuals. Immersion is solid, as citizens will react realistically: for instance, by assaulting Vito after he scratched their car. There is a decent interaction level with the environment (such as buying hot dogs from a cart, for example). Music, mannerisms and ways of speaking are coherent with the times (even Italian ones: I can tell being one myself). Those seeking immersive settings will not be disappointed.

[*][b]Fear & loathing in Empire Bay[/b]
The storyline delivers everything expected by a high-tier criminal drama: violence, betrayals, loss - but also good times, sex, booze, gambling, luxury. Mafia II successfully shows how some people are not driven to criminal life by being inherently evil, but rather by sheer necessity (as in Vito's case) - while in other instances, the opposite can be also seen. The characters are well developed, especially those closer to the protagonist, which have some extent of growth as the years go by. Definitely a solid story with characters matching its quality, that does not betray the franchise's legacy.

[*][b]Not quite over yet[/b]
Mafia II offers a good chunk of additional DLC modes, all included in the Definitive version. "Jimmy's Betrayal" and "Vendetta" both trace the story of a famed hitman that served all the biggest families - while "Joe's Adventures" is a series of missions featuring one of the most important side-characters of the main story. Depending on completion rate, there may be even 10+ hours of content in these "expansions", which is almost as much as the main game. However, don't expect great differences in terms of gameplay from any of them.
[/list]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2388511191

üü• [b]The Bad Side[/b]
[list]

[*][b]What's the point, then?[/b]
This second entry in the series tries to expand gameplay by adding side activities, such as reselling stolen cars or robbing shops, in order to make extra cash to spend. Other than that, it adds a more "interactive" city framework, with gun shops, clothiers, mechanics and more each with their specific function or sales inventory. While these shops can be useful at times, the side chores can be completely overlooked: the main story will always provide more than enough cash for all the guns, ammo, upgrades and clothes one would ever wish for.

[*][b]I never asked for this...[/b]
Certain fights and situations in the main story are unfair or poorly designed. For instance, in some cases combat will start with Vito standing in the middle of a room like a target dummy - on higher difficulties, it's only up to luck if he'll make it to the closest cover in time or not. This can indeed be frustrating. The worst instance is found in a specific chapter, where an enemy can spam unlimited molotovs at the protagonist, making that one a very badly designed fight. Car chases deserve a negative mention: at times the car's frame seems to not shield Vito from bullets at all, making it very RNG dependent.
[/list]

[i]It took me around 12 hours to complete Mafia II's main storyline. After that, for those interested, three Extra Modes are available, which add around 5-9 hours of content in total depending on completion. For 30‚Ç¨ and with overall good quality the selling point is fair enough, so I can recommend buying this game for full price especially to fans of the franchise.[/i]

[h1]In-Depth Breakdown[/h1]
üéÆ [b]Gameplay Analysis[/b]
Gameplay is divided into Exploration, Combat, Quests and Character Management.

[b]Exploration[/b]
Is performed by car over long distances, on foot in closed spaces and vehicle-free areas. Being Mafia II a linear adventure, exploration can only be done in-between those mission phases that have no time limits (most of them). Exploring the world has not a real point, save for finding achievement-related collectibles or exotic cars to add to one's garage. In each story-related location it's possible to hand around a bit more and talk with side characters for some extra lore, find some eatery to restore HP or go to a clothing shop to get changed (which can be done to evade police identification).

[b]Combat[/b]
Plays out in a rather arcade third-person shooter fashion, with Vito being able to carry a true arsenal of weapons in his pockets - ranging from pistols to military grade rifles and even grenades. Weapon handling and damage are quite realistic especially on hard difficulty, with 2-3 shots being all it takes to kill both Vito and most enemies. Headshots are a guaranteed kill on any living thing without exceptions, as it should be. Vehicles prove to be extremely resistant to damage, unless shot in the fuel intake valve or other weakspots. Melee combat is also a thing and uses dodge, counters and heavy / light attack systems to form a simplistic but enjoyable alternative to guns - just don't bring fists to a gun fight.

[b]Quests[/b]
Are mostly related to the main story, and have good variety. Sometimes, special criteria may be in place such as stealth section where being discovered triggers a game over, undercover car chases and other unique situations depending on the case.

[b]Character Management[/b]
Is performed at shops and home. In the former, Vito is able to buy guns, ammo, clothes and upgrade cars depending on the shop type, while the latter is used to restore HP (fridge food) or change owned clothes (wardrobe). A handy garage with a cap of 10 cars is available to collect the fastest rides one can find, each customizable and moddable to some extent.

I'm very familiar with Mafia 2 classic as I've played it for hundreds of hours so I was curious to see how different this remaster is. There's no denying almost all textures look better. I run both the classic and this remaster at 4K and the classic definitely has some ugly PS3 textures left over on fences, some buildings, sidewalk textures, etc. This remaster takes care of most of that and makes the textures up to current standards. I also appreciate the enhanced snow on the ground as before it just looked like a sidewalk painted white. I'm on a POS AMD 8350 and I can still run the game at 4K/60fps for the most part. So the performance isn't atrocious if I can run it with a decade old processor. 

There are some Nvidia Physx issues: I noticed if you turn Physx OFF, Vito's character will have the cloth physics applied to his clothes. But if you turn them ON, he doesn't. It's like they screwed up when they remastered it and somehow coded it backwards. I would say just run with it off to get Vito's cloth Physx to work but then you don't get the enhanced grass/vegetation which are almost required since the grass with Physx off is straight up the flat 2D PS3 texture. So it's a shame they never patched to correct for that. 

Other than that, for a free game, I'm happy. If you didn't own the original Mafia II and are considering purchasing this, perhaps it's worth it on a sale and not full price. I don't think the remaster and it's content are worth what they're asking, as much as I love the game.

A Second Chance to experience this truly immersive 1950's Mafia open world action-adventure game!

Story 9/10: You play as Vito Scaletta, a wannabe gangster and aid and get aid from and to your best friend Joe Barbaro who has been 
there for you for your whole life. You will experience so much together. So much indeed. The city is Empire Bay. Real life New York. So many opportunities, the American dream as they say. Will you accomplish that dream and so many other dreams that Vito has? How will Vito's story end?

Graphics 7/10: Not that much improvement overall. Some of the textures were upgraded. Better lighting and facial structures of the main and sub-characters. Mostly, it's the same look from the Classic version. But of course there are bugs, glitches and lower fps and game performance with this game. 30 fps near many areas, even on strong rigs. The developers might fix these issues sometime in the future.

Gameplay 8/10: The driving mechanics are so realistic! You won't find the GTA driving style here. The driving style here is a more brutal and realistic one, I would say. You get penalties from driving fast or not driving carefully from the cops. The shooting gameplay is rather simple. The weapons are rather impressive. I Like their design and sounds. As I stated above, the gameplay is open word so you can kinda explore and collect collectibles, only this can you do though. The game has achievements also, always a plus in my book, just like the classic version. Sadly, no more stuff beyond the main story missions and collectibles were added.

Soundtrack 6/10: I wouldn't say that I am intrigued or surprised by the soundtrack, only the main theme puts me on chills. Some scenes have a powerful track out on them while others don't. Kinda a miss or hit or done by purpose.

DLC (3 in total) 5/10: Filler in my opinion. With the DE you get all of the DLC with the main game of course, so no losing here, you can play them or not, if you are an achievements hunter like myself you need to complete these and miscellaneous achievements that you can only obtain by playing the DLC's. All the DLC's have a timer on every mini-mission and you have a limited time given in order to complete the missions and do some extra work for the achievements (e.g Drifting daddy 'o', millionaire etc). The best one is Joe's s Adventures which covers the time gap on what joe did after a crucial point in Vito's life.
In Jimmy's Vendetta, well you guessed it: Jimmy's Vendetta!
And The Betrayal of Jimmy: Betrayal. In addition to these, you get various car and outfit themed DLC's and exclusive outfits from past mafia games to the most recent ones. (E.g. The Mafia III protagonist can wear Mafia II's protagonist's clothes and drive his car and so on)

Overall 9/10: This is a nice addition to your Steam Library in general especially if you are a Mafia fan, have already completed the Classic Mafia 2 game, the story, the achievements etc or even a newcomer who wants to try a Mafia game and also get all the dlc included in the price and not independently. Then this game is for you. 100 %
