[h1] SUMMARY [/h1]
"You know something, Carlo? For the last 10 years, all I done was kill. I killed for my country, I killed for my family, I killed anybody that got in my way. But this one? This one's for me" (Vito Scaletta).  An action-adventure game and a sequel to Mafia game, Mafia 2 Definitive Edition is the remake of the 2010 Mafia 2 game.  While worse than Mafia 1 Definitive Edition (that had a great story, great gameplay and better graphics), Mafia 2 Definitive Edition may be a choice for the fans of the series, provided they did not play the original game. Good-buy if on sale.

[h1] INFO [/h1]
- This review is a personal opinion. Try the game for yourself.
- Game was played on max graphics setting and ultrawide resolution.
- This is the definitive, remastered edition of the game and includes all 3 DLCs.
- I did not play the original 2010 game.
- The plot takes place a decade after the Mafia game setting, in the fictional city of Empire Bay during the 1940s‚Äìearly 1950s and follows the life of the Sicilian immigrant Vito Scaletta and his story of climbing the Mafia family ladder, with both larger reward and consequence.
- You can steal and drive any vehicle (including trucks), you can kill anyone (except companions).
- Visit body shops to repair, personalize cars and enhance their performance.
- In comparison with Mafia 1, this game uses a handbrake to help car make tight turns at high speeds.
- You can make use of cash to bribe police and you can use phone booths to call-in a bribe and lose your red wanted status.
- Make use of cover very often (press CTRL near walls or obstacles), it is an essential mechanic of shooting gameplay in this game.
- Obviously, the proper order to play the games is Mafia, Mafia 2, Mafia 3, not the release order (Mafia Definitive was released after Mafia 2 Definitive and Mafia 3 Definitive Editions). Mafia  Definitive Edition remains by far the best game of the remastered series.

[h1] PROS [/h1]
- An open-world design of a large city with parts modeled on New York City, Boston, Detroit, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Chicago, along 19 story chapters plus prologue (15 chapters from base game and 4 more story chapters from DLC), featuring remastered graphics and real-time generated cutscenes. A narrative about family, loyalty, betrayal and greed, a decent story about Mafia.
- The story starts quite slow-paced and you may say even uninteresting, but it gets a lot better at the end of Chapter 5.
- Nice atmosphere and design, a beautiful city and around 50 famous drivable and upgradable epoch vehicles.
- Good soundtrack (and car radio music from the era).
- Good optimization, high fps count.
- Some collectibles (Playboy magazines and Wanted posters) for completionists.

[h1] CONS [/h1]
- Partial ultrawide support (although real-time generated not pre-rendered, cutscenes are pillarboxed).
- The story ends abruptly and very unsatisfying.
- The lack of manual save (the game saves only at the beginning of story missions and at certain checkpoints) may create problems when you and exit the game without starting a new story mission (unless you managed to reach a checkpoint, everything will be gone when you restart the game).
- The remastered graphics do not look quite 2020, some textures and the cutscenes still look old and face animations are not the best around, not much of an improvement over the 2010 original game. Mafia 1 Definitive Edition looks a lot better than this one.
- No side missions available.
- The DLCs are not much of a content. The first 2 DLCs deal with a guy named Jimmy, without any connection with the main story. The third DLC (Joey's Adventures) is about Vito's friend Joe and should have been either part of the base game or deleted.
- Very few bugs, but they are still a thing.
- Cars get damage extremely easy. The fact that you have to repair cars very often (and refuel them), along with feeding your character to recover health is too old style and just a gameplay filler.
- Map directions can be confusing when showing inside doors or building entrances.
- You must dress again every single time you get up from bed (and you must go to bed to progress to the next chapter).
- Gameplay is a bit boring, around 60% of the time you will be driving in traffic (and compared to Mafia 1 Definitive Edition, here you cannot skip driving). Some of the missions are just a waste of time, you must drive around town to sell stamps or cigarettes or whatever. The gameplay also combines too many styles and requirements (shooting, brawling, stealth action, racing, adventure, cars management, evading police, etc.) resulting a GTA kind of mix with Yakuza-like character management (health, weapons, ammo and money). This inconsistency in gameplay actions can become annoying for some players.
- The lock-picking feature is also just a gameplay filler (most of the time I used Q to smash car's windows). You can make good use of it only to lock-pick a few of building doors and cars and one safe-box in the story.

Cons:-

Cosmetically it looks great, it's been seriously overhauled in those terms. It might not be on par with other 2020 releases but overall its a vast improvement on the original. It honestly feels like all the effort (if any) that was put into this 'remaster' was cosmetic. From a technical stand point this game feels more dated than the classic.

Mechanically it's dog shit, there are so many bugs and a few proper game breaking ones; twice I had to restart a whole chapter because I literally couldn't progress as a result of either guys not spawning in that I 'had' to kill or because NPC's dialogue wouldn't trigger.

The AI is simultaneously the smartest and dumbest in existence. Enemies can blind fire from cover but you cant. They know when you are aiming at them so if you try and hold the angle till they peek they never will, that is if they don't kill you when you are about to peek. 

The peek animation for you is so slow that (combined with them clearly knowing you're about to peek) means they will literally peek out of cover like the road runner on speed while you are still in the middle of the animation and gun you down. Rather than duck behind cover while being shot at they will literally tank your bullets and shoot back at you which usually results in your death before theirs. Other times they will literally just rush you and 1. You can't shoot from cover without peeking, so in order to shoot the guy thats now broken past the defence line you need to stand up/out of cover in order to shoot him thus exposing your back to any other enemies 2. Shooting them a second time can sometimes interrupt their stagger animation so thus they can snap back to shooting you like they had a brief moment of alzheimers and forgot they were in a fire fight, except they remembered they were some sort of sniper elite James McAvoy type in war and shoot you with ridiculous accuracy even though their gun is facing the opposite direction.

There is also a little Sam Fisher in them as you will often walk into a room with 0 indication that there are enemies hiding, walk past a box and get shot in the back by the guy hiding behind it, im not sure if they were already there or if the game is literally spawning enemies behind me. 

The destruction of cover is really cool looking with tiny little fragments of the wall you are hiding behind getting blown towards the camera, makes me feel like I'm saving private Ryan. It also means you become exposed to bullets the longer you hide behind cover. This would be cooler if the same thing applied to the AI. On several occasions I had blown their cover to shit, can quite clearly see their head through it but shooting at it just sparks off like they are iron men!

Playing on hard was more about repetition than anything, playing the time loop game of triggered sequences i.e. when a grenade will be thrown and counting how many enemies are in a room so i dont run into the issues above. 

In terms of story it's ok, not as great as i remember. Its very linear and most chapters are 1 'mission'. It gives the illusion of open world but really there is almost nothing else to do other than the story, the only time i every really explored the open world was to get collectables/other achievements. 

The characters are pretty flat in terms of personality, it seems like the are all rehearsing for the same background role in goodfellas 'Angry Italian American #2', I found myself constantly forgetting who any of the people were the main character kept referring to outside of Joe & Leo. 

Overall its ruined any nostalgia I had for Mafia 2 classic. Mostly becuase the mechanics feel dated which suggests they've just taken the coding from the original slapped some flex tape on it and called it a day. Although I could be wrong the original might be every bit as great as I remember but honestly I'm too lazy to find out. 

I think i got this free for owning the classic version, which is the way it should be. Buy the classic and get this puttanata free!

TL;DR buy this if you enjoyed the original and it's going for somewhere around 5 bucks. Otherwise get the original its probably better

I LOVE MAFIA II

...is a odd way to start a negative review, I admit. Mafia II is in itself a really amazing game. Lovely story, lovely characters, a great city, lots of variety, small details and also great music.

So why do I not recommend it?

I have played Mafia II (Classic), which was the game that one could purchase before such a thing as a 'Definitive Edition' existed. While playing Classic, I had close to 0 bugs, that I found odd or noticeably distracted me from playing the game.

However, since Mafia I got a Definitive Edition, which for that game makes perfect sense and I think is great, the developers wanted to make some extra money and made two other Definitive Editions for the 2nd and 3rd game. 

I kid you not that this so called Defintive Edition made this game worse than it was before. 

I encountered graphical glitches, repeating dialogue, repeating dialogue, and in the 14th chapter even a gamebreaking bug (I could not enter Bruno's at the very end of the level), forcing me to replay the entire chapter, which was by far also the longest, which sucked a lot. Based on the community reaction, these bugs have popped up for a lot of people. None of those bugs were in the old edition.

I also argue that the Classic edition looked as gorgeous as the Definitive Edition, therefore there is no major upgrade there.

I received this game for free, as did all owners of the Classic Edition, which is a nice gesture, but if one does not have the game and is considering it, 30 Dollars is a rip-off. One could have obtained the Classic Edition before this Edition for much less and it would be better.

I will change this review, if the developers do care about the game and take care of the well-known bugs. 

Get the game, when it is on a heavy sale or wait until it ultimately gets cheaper, because in itself it's a great game.

For someone who owned the original mafia 2 and finished it 5 or so years ago finding the definitive edition sure was a pleasant surprise. This was and still is my favourite game of all time just because of the story and simple yet remarkable mechanics the game has to offer. 

When I saw the screenshots of the definitive edition I was disappointed at first and wished for a bigger overhaul, but now after spending 10 hours completing the main story and driving around selling cars I am happier with this outcome than I would be with the kind of the graphical improvement Mafia 1 is getting. This style of a "remaster" was one of the greatest things that could happen to a 10 year old game that still looked incredible 5 years ago. Except of the few graphical improvements everything has stayed the same and thank God for that. 

The story has to be the biggest selling point of Mafia 2. It was such a blast replaying some of the most remarkable moments I have experienced in gaming story wise. The incredible and most loved characters like Joe and Vito have a huge impact on why the game is so brilliant story wise. Mostly all of the missions were unique and interesting but have to say the follow missions were a pain in the ass especially because of the speed limit we are forced to obey. I'm not going to spoil the ending but the cliff hanger it leaves on is so well done and thought out it had me shook and made me want to find out more about the story and find an answer to the question the game leaves us with. The overall amount of time it took me to finish the story was about 8 hours which makes more sense as the missions are unique. This is better than Mafia 3 where they extended the story by 10 hours just making the player do the same thing over and over again. I haven't completed all of the DLC content but I am planning to in the near future which will extend the playtime without making the game boring as shit. 

The difficulty level is somewhat challenging even on medium as you don't have much health and the enemies use automatic weapons which could kill you just in a few shots. The game wasn't frustrating because of it but made it more fun and a bit of a challenge which I really enjoyed. 

I experienced some minor bugs and glitches but most were rare and mostly were related to character's faces and clothes. I experienced an optimisation issue which was sudden frame drops which should not happen when using the hardware I use. Some were caused by automatic v-sync which was turned on for some reason but for some stutters I couldn't see why they were happening as they even happened when I tried playing the game on low settings. 

In conclusion, this is a must-play for anyone who has any interest in this genre not only in video games but also movies. If it wasn't for the DLC i wouldn't recommend buying the game for the full price but for all the DLC content and the main story paying ¬£25 is a bargain. Personally, I can't wait what Mafia 1 is going to offer after finishing this game. Now I can truly say this is still one of my favourite games of all time.

The check points are horridly spaced out. They are so far apart that you dare not go exploring during a mission lest you crash or something occur and you have to replay the last 10 minutes of a mission again. Coulda been easily fixed by adding a few more checkpoints.

There are so many police in the game. I understand it's not GTA and I appreciate that but it's a crime game - you can't commit crimes because of all the police. Also the traffic fines are ridiculous - someone hits you and you are charged with hit and run...ugh. Thankfully, they aren't as aggressive as the police in GTA so theyre more of a nuisance. 

There's lots of driving in the game and it looks beautiful but the one issue is there's no option to just explore. You're always in mission mode. The only time I ever drove around and explored was right at the beginning of a mission save that way I wouldn't loose too much progress. It's really a waste ... such a neat atmosphere and you really don't get to play in it due to how it's structured. 

Overall, if you like the Mafia series you could get it. Otherwise, probably pass.

The game definitely has some fun moments and some hilarious dialogue, so it's definitely worth buying on sale, but I would not recommend this game at full price or to anyone looking for that next great game experience. One particularly frustrating thing about this game is the checkpoint saving. There's no option to save the game whenever you want (unless to take the time to drive all the way home and sleep in your bed, which is the only "manual" method for saving). 

This is frustrating because the checkpoint saves can be 20-40 minutes apart which means if a mission fails for any reason, you're having to redo the same stuff over and over, which personally drives me nuts. It feels like a giant waste of time when most games will let you quick save, but not this one. The AI also occasionally does dumb things which cause mission failure regardless of anything you do.

Bottom line. This is a fun buy on sale game. I'm sure I was more enthusiastic about the game when it was first released (the classic version), but in 2020-2021, we just have so many better options and the bar has been raised so high for PC games, this one simply doesn't compete with more modern standards.

To start this up, Mafia II is my favorite story driven game, I have replayed it for years on end and finally got a pc, when I saw it go on sale I decided to pick it up for $15. The storyline, characters, and atmosphere is all the same game I loved, but man do I have some complaints.

In this remastered version, there are plenty of bugs to be handed out, I've experienced faces glitching out, terrible AI, and one game breaking bug ill go deeper into.

     ¬ªThe bug I experienced was in the mission were you are going to the hotel job with Joe, and for some reason the door wasn't opening, he just kept closing it on me to where I couldn't exit the apartment. After restarting the mission multiple times the door finally broke where I could go through, and you can see this in the clip here.
https://youtu.be/Ms7n0UYnr-U

     ¬ªNow for the AI, I have noticed some changes, they seem to be more dumbfounded and unresponsive than I recall, I will be driving and a random civilian will jump into the middle of the road in front of my car, the police don't show up when I rob a store like they do in the original, I can just endlessly rob stores and make money without any consequence, and the police AI was just acting terrible in comparison to the original game. Now for gunfights, the AI just run towards you when in cover, shoot you twice, and kill you, last time I remember they don't all just rush you to where you can't do anything, and it ruined the best gunfights in the game for me.

     ¬ªOther than that I have no other complains, still the same old Mafia I love, I have alot of patience so the bugs weren't a huge issue for me, just the new AI bugs me whenever something happens like I described. 

Overall I would give this game a 3/5. Although it is a great game these bugs and the way the AI act now should've been fixed before the release, and it's still happening now that this remaster has been out a couple months. For $15 bucks you can't go wrong especially with the DLC included. Still just disappointed in how the release was rushed.

Mafia 2 is a great game. i played it a while back on console and decided to play it again as they released the ''Definitive'' edition and because they released the mafia remake i wanted to experience all the games. Don't expect much change with the Definitive edition its the same game with very small improvements and some how buggier than i remember. The story is what shines in this game, well voice acted characters with a well written story that keeps you engaged. The gameplay Is kinda repetitive, in the game there is a bunch of sections where you will have to do a lot of driving and with me having the option to skip driving sequences in the remake of the first then coming back to this game it was a bit tedious at points but the sections with story dialog its bearable. Gunplay is fun but its outdated and feels a bit clunky at times and within time as you play the game, it gets repetitive at points but you don't notice it as much during the more action oriented parts of the story. The world is well designed for when the game was originally released but with really nothing to do within the map other than the story with no type of free roam or side activities other than going to a shop to buy clothes, going to a weapon shop to buy guns and get ammo or going to the bar to buy some food and getting something to eat, it feels empty and i wish they would have done more with it to bring a extra level of fun and entertainment to the game. The soundtrack is really good it fits the era of the game with well picked tunes making them driving parts a tad less tedious. I did experience some bugs within my playthrough of the game such as characters disappearing in scenes and audio cut outs at times and characters model glitching out or the occasional clothing stretching out during game play or cinematics making the characters look weird at times, small stuff that didn't ruin my overall experience. (i don't know if you will have this happen when you play but wanted to mention it anyways) also i would suggest turning of the apex physics option in the video setting cause i would get frame drops in some areas of the game with a lot of physics based stuff happening other than that when i turned it off it ran smoothly. over all i enjoyed the game despite the repetitive parts and the small amount of bugs i encountered. If you can look past them small annoyances and you stick through for the story and characters in the game its a great sequel and mafia game. i would recommend waiting for a sale though maybe $20 or less to pick it up.

I had a few problems with this game: first there's no drive by shooting.  You can shoot while driving in GTA 4, and Scarface: the world is yours, and those games came out before Mafia 2, hell you can even shoot while driving in the original version of Mafia 1.  There's no good reason Vito can't shoot while driving, especially since he was in the army and at least had more experience with shooting than Tommy Angelo.  Tommy was pretty much a cab driver, before joining the mob and he can shoot while driving, so why not Vito? Second, they REALLY, REALLY need to work on the checkpoints in the game.  If you die sometimes you can get sent way back.  Like I lost a fight with Frankie's Husband and instead of me starting where I died or at the very least in the apartment, they really made me have to drive all the way there and go all the way up the apartment again.  Then there was getting killed in a head on collision after chasing the mob guy in the car, and then they made me have to watch the same part over again where Vito enters the Irish bar and hearing the guys who burned down his house talk about how he got away for the umpteenth time.  The least they could have done was start the chase all over again, and not have me go through the dialog and the gun fight all over again.  Third, the control scheme is a little out of whack.  if you're using an Xbox One controller, B more often than not is reload, but for some dumb reason they had right bumper reload.  Third, while most of the story was good, the ending was rather anti-climactic because it felt unfinished.  I'm sure there's probably more story in the DLC, but if I were to play this before I know there would be DLC, then i'd say this ending was very badly written.  The definitive version of Mafia 1 is a much better game than Mafia II: DE

A classic, fantastic game at the time of release (original Classic version) with a good story, rich characters, comedic elements, a bunch of cars with their own characteristics, a beautiful city, and for the most part very enjoyable.
Reviewing this in 2020 as the DE version, it's surprisingly limited in terms of the AI of 'background' characters (just jumping out in front of your car, for instance), it doesn't feel all too 'open' really - the story is pretty much linear, the game is also relatively short (do not expect anything ANYWHERE NEAR GTAV) which I didn't recall it being so but back then it was probably fine, though there is still a good 12-20 hours worth in there.
It does also have a bit too much 'filler' in there when it comes to tedious tasks and should you fail at any point it is likely to throw you back further than seems right at times.
On hard difficulty, it's challenging but not overly so, though losing the police seems a bit too easy still.
Graphically, it looks good, but it does have some glitches - one terrible case of this is with Leo [spoiler]at the end of the game while you are riding in the car with him, his eyes are like a dog looking upwards[/spoiler] which is embarrassingly bad that it made it through ANY kinda of QA process.
The music, voice acting, and all that jazz is superb - it really gives it the right feels in all regards.
[spoiler]It also has one of THE great call-backs in gaming history, imo, when you get to see old Tommy Angelo once again, truly loved seeing that again[/spoiler]

I'd recommend this game still, for sure, but it has to be said - it has it's flaws, mostly just graphical glitches - but it's still as good a Mafia game as anything else out there, though in terms of content it's maybe around 5% of what you get with GTA V, as a comparison.

Just finished the main game and IMO this re-release is great. I got this as I own the original release of Mafia II, and unbelievably, all the DLC came with it free as well, which I never owned before, so I'll be enjoying them soon.

Sure, its got some strange bugs, glitchy facial expressions and some of the achievements don't work (note how I've completed the game but somehow didn't get the achievements for completing certain chapters) but overall the presentation is very good. A lot of hate for the new lighting system, but I personally think Empire Bay at night looks much, much better.

Gunplay is the same, simple, straightforward and satisfying. Driving is fun and varied, and incredibly unforgiving.

Mafia II is short, but the attention to detail throughout the game is insane - from hubcaps rolling off your car when driving erratically, your car getting dirtier the more you drive in the snow, to the way the citizens of the city start the game not knowing who you are, to them knowing exactly who you are. Memorable levels, memorable chapters, memorable characters.

Mafia II is not a very new game and doesn't seem very impressive at most points, the new defenitive edition clearly looks better but I still have to spend more time with it to properly judge its graphic improvements. However, even without this new graphic upgrade the game absolutely shines with its amazing story as well as an impressive and unique setting that even jumps a few years during the story making for a similar but definitely different experience in the later part of the game. The gameplay is not too impressive as well, it does however have a certain feeling to it that other games don't have, being searched by the police is more intense yet realistic compared to similar games and driving feels much more real. For anyone looking for a game with a great story and its own unique way of telling it, Mafia II is a top choice in my opinion and while not new it is definitely nota classic you have to convince yourself to play.

First off I want to say, I really prefer remasters and do not like complete remakes so that is a positive. Mafia II is a pretty decent game and the remaster does look [i]slightly[/i] better than the original but they actually downgraded a lot of things.
[list]
    [*]There are lots of weird flickering/artifacting graphical glitches that I have never seen in the original version
    [*]PhysX does not work like the original, suggesting that they might have ported over a console version instead of upgrading the original PC version
    [*]You can no longer switch the speedometer units to metric. It is bugged. This is minor but still... this wasn't a problem with the classic version of the game
    [*]The draw distance is really short. I am pretty sure it was also short in the original version but it seems like that is something they could have easily improved.
[/list]

Mafia II is one of my favorite games ever made, the best of the trilogy, and the Definitive Edition is a perfect reason to repurchase it. For those who haven't played it, Mafia II is set in the 1940s and 1950s Empire Bay (New York) and tells a Goodfellas-esque story of the consequences of mob life. The Mafia series is more story driven, but Mafia II's semi-open world is the most detailed of any of the Mafia games, with the ability to rob stores, make phone calls, and the many buttons around to push. While not as detailed as GTA, Mafia II's attention to detail and realism elements are the most extensive in the Mafia series, like getting gas for cars, open/close car trunks, light switches on/off, food/drinks to replenish health, get drunk, snow collecting and falling off car roofs when parked/moving, etc. All these details make the world feel really alive. Mafia II has the best law enforcement system in a crime game, including police recognition of outfits and license plates, both of which can be purchased and changed, as well as being issued tickets for traffic violations small crimes rather then the police shooting every time you are wanted. Collectibles like the nude women of the Playboy magazines scattered throughout the world that remind me of my youth. The characters are incredibly likable, the story is fantastic, the 40s/50s music on the radio is great, and the gameplay is a lot of fun.  

As a Definitive Edition from the classic, not much has changed but the graphics. The world is much more detailed texture wise, and everything looks a lot better overall. The game settings can be altered for higher frame rates as well. Nothing new is added to the game at all, not even a free ride mode which the game really lacks and Mafia 1: DE got, which is extremely disappointing. On top of that, there are many bugs and glitches with the graphics, like grass popping in and out and people's eyes getting stuck in one direction, frame rate drops, and crashes. There are also many weird changes like character eye-color, haircuts, and some cutscene NPC face models. 

Mafia II: DE comes with all three DLC. Joe's Adventures fills in some gaps from the main story and is fun to play as a great character. This DLC has its own cutscenes and has a less linear gameplay with missions scattered across the map, and many unique missions different from story objectives. The other two DLCs are about a new character named Jimmy that is unrelated to Mafia II's story. It is more of Joe's DLC but with less of a story and more unique missions. There is a lot of driving in the DLC, probably to drag it out, and it gets annoying over time. There is little interest in playing as Jimmy due to the lack of a proper story and alternate timeline, but it makes for a good "free ride" mode without the mod.

The Definitive Edition of Mafia II is definitely a weird package in the trade-offs regarding better graphics for more glitches and annoying changes, but the best part is that buying Mafia II also gives you a copy of Mafia II Classic for free, so either one or both can be played. Players who had Mafia II Classic before DE came out also received a free upgrade, which was very generous of the developers. Whichever copy of Mafia II is used, this game is a must-play for anyone who hasn't played it before, and a great excuse to play it again.

It's a fantastic game in the genre.  One of the finest, in fact.  The story makes it a must play for anyone interested in a classic rendition of the mafia lifestyle.  From rags to riches, so they say; Characters steadily rise in power, but so do the risks that are often associated within organized crime. 

However, the remastered version is but a shadow of its former self.  The first half of the game is for the most part, okay, assuming you can stomach occasional character clipping.  By this I mean sometimes I would see a character's head literally cut in half upon entering in a room (Other players seemed to experience it much more than me) and textures popping in and out.  A perfect example of these textures not cooperating is after walking outside of your apartment you could see the grass throughout the city look like VERY low quality textures. 

I tried the game on high and highest graphical settings, and what I noticed is 95% of the time the grass looked as if it was stuck on the lowest quality, and occasionally its textures would, at the blink of an eye, revert to ultra quality, then quickly back to lowest setting and basically remain there the whole time.  But guess what, when this did happen, you can bet your bottom there was also a performance hit that came with it.

My fps at points was cut to 35 in several areas.  Driving around the city yielded on average just over 100 fps but certain areas performance just tanked. An example of this is in Chapter 13 when you enter a restaurant; in this area, my fps hovered between 30 and 35 up until the chapter finished.  How on earth do you get 100+ fps in an open world with much more going on than inside a small linear building with at most half a dozen characters on screen at one time? On a 3600x and RTX 3070 with 16 gb of memory no less.

Surely there was no reason to release it half-arsed like this.   Fortunately it was free because I already had Mafia 2 Classic, so I really can't complain but I felt it necessary to offer some insight for those just discovering the game.   Speaking of which, go buy Mafia 2 classic if you can find it for a good price.  Otherwise, wait until this goes dirt cheap and try your luck with it then. Remember, you can always fall back on a refund within 2 hours.  As it stands, I cannot recommend this remaster in any way shape or form.

After playing the Definitive Edition, the remake, of Mafia: The City of Lost Heaven I couldn‚Äôt wait to get started on the second part of the series. Mafia might just be my favorite video game series of all time, with Mafia: Definitive Edition being on spot number 2 in my personal list of best video games ever!

Mafia II takes place between the 1940s and 1950s in Empire Bay. It looks amazing and it‚Äôs a fun world to explore. Thankfully the story of Mafia II takes you around the city so you‚Äôll be able to explore everything throughout the game. Compared to the first Mafia game, Mafia II gives the player more freedom. It‚Äôs an open world game and between the story missions you are able to explore Empire Bay on your own. In Mafia: Definitive Edition you are continuously following the story, automatically starting the next mission right after you‚Äôve finished the other. I really enjoyed the off-story feeling; being allowed to drive around for fun, rob a store to get some extra cash, and legally buy clothes/weapons in that exact same shop you robbed earlier. After each mission you also have to get home first so you‚Äôre able to get some sleep. This helps a lot to emerge yourself more into the world of a mobster, wondering if you can make it through the night without someone killing you in your own house. It is the mafia of course and you‚Äôll figure out rather quickly that not everyone can be trusted inside this business, even though they seem like your friends.

Driving is a big part of the Mafia games. If you have ever played one before you know their vehicle physics are trying to be realistic. It‚Äôs far from the awful vehicle system in GTA games, which might be the reason why I really dislike the GTA series. While the vehicles are a lot easier to control in Mafia II compared to Mafia: Definitive Edition, it‚Äôll still take quite some time to get used to them. One amazing thing they‚Äôve done in Mafia II is to include different seasons in the game. The first few chapters of the game take place during the winter and the snow/ice makes it a lot more difficult to drive. It‚Äôs such a cool detail, I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever seen it in any other game before. Eventually it‚Äôs summer and the world looks so different, it‚Äôs like you‚Äôre in a totally different city. The world looks bright and colorful and makes you eager to explore the same city once again. Now it‚Äôs easier than ever before to drive around in Mafia. No slippery roads, the brakes will actually make you stop now and with this decrease in danger you‚Äôll have no trouble racing through the city with the fastest car in your garage.

I‚Äôm not really into spoiling game content. You‚Äôve got to figure the story out yourself and trust me, it‚Äôs insanely fun to play. My reviews will tell you some gameplay details that I think are important to mention and might make you consider buying this game. I won‚Äôt ever spoil the story of a videogame in a review.

Oh man, what should I even start with‚Ä¶ The game has so much issues. There‚Äôs characters in the game who will sometimes have their face wrapped inside-out, looks terrifying as hell. Other times their arms would stretch around their neck and launch in the air, again; freaky as hell. In a few cutscenes the main character‚Äôs mouth would not move while he was talking. During my playthrough of the DLC I came across a lot of spots with no collision; my character would walk straight into a house or mountain and no, not through a door. Clothing will occasionally clip inside your characters body, especially with longer coats. So I recommend wearing a simple shirt so you won‚Äôt have these weird issues. To continue, the NPC‚Äôs are unable to open doors. They just walk straight into the door and keep walking, and every now and then they‚Äôll try to open the door but it just won‚Äôt budge. They will also keep running in circles when they‚Äôve lost track of your location. Thankfully, in my experience, this wasn‚Äôt all really that bad. Because the game contains quite a lot of comedic moments, these bugs/glitches only made those moments even funnier.

Mafia II: Definitive Editions also includes a bunch of DLC (extra Downloadable Content). The first two packs contain missions for a new character that does not appear in the main storyline. I have to admit those are really awful. Because it‚Äôs a new character who looks too much like the modern hitman and doesn‚Äôt fit in the world of Mafia, I had to quit playing after almost boring myself to death. I also discovered a huge amount of bugs while playing this DLC, already mentioned in the paragraph above.
The third and last DLC pack contains missions for Joe Barbaro, one of the main characters from the story of Mafia II. I Love Joe, one of my favorite video game characters. In the main storyline of Mafia II, there‚Äôs a time gap of quite some years. This DLC fills in what Joe was up to during this time gap and is definitely worth checking out.

So, do I recommend this game? Oh I certainly do. One of the best stories in my video game history. It doesn‚Äôt matter a lot if you play the remaster (Definitive Edition) or the original, both are fun and share the exact same story. The game looks better in the remaster, if it works‚Ä¶ As I mentioned the game is in an awful spot, filled with bugs and glitches. For some people this might break immersion and kill the game for them. I don‚Äôt remember if the original had the same issues, maybe it did and the developers just didn‚Äôt bother fixing it. Make sure you buy the game if it‚Äôs on sale, it‚Äôs worth your time. It took me about 20 hours to finish the story, not bad right?

While I can recommend Mafia II in general, I cannot recommend this Definitive Edition, especially as a stand alone entity.  For someone willing to use even the most simple of mods a modded version of the original is superior in all aspects.  Even comparing both games in their unmodded state the original version is more stable, and there is no excuse for a remaster to be significantly technically worse than the original.  While I was able to get the game to run decently at a frame rate consistently above 30FPS I could only do this by lowering graphical settings to far below what I used in what should be the more technically-demanding Mafia remake.  Furthermore while I played the main story with my only issue being frame rate drops in situations with a lot of explosions or a lot of automatic weapon fire the side content Joe's Adventure regularly crashes on me, and crashes almost every time I am forced to restart a mission (which will be more often than the base game, as all missions in that expansion have time limits that get increasingly strict).

As far as the original goes though again I do recommend it.  Mafia II has one of the finest stories you'll find in an open-world game, and while it doesn't force more cinematic-like pacing like the remake of the first game it still paces itself well and puts the narrative first by having a core narrative completed in order as opposed to tons of side missions.  It still mixes in a small amount of open world benefits like keeping and customizing your cars and having a city that feels a little more alive than the playgrounds of some other titles.  As a part of the trilogy on sale as a package the price is right, but speaking personally I wish I had just re-installed the classic version and modded it up as opposed to playing this version.

Mafia 2 is a third person open world game with a strong emphasis on storytelling. This is the successor of Mafia 1 which was one of the best games of the early 2000s. As we all know by now Mafia 2 was a worthy successor in 2010 but how does the HD Remaster stack up? Lets take a look. Mafia 2 Definitive Edition was developed by Hangar 13 and d3t and published by [url=https://store.steampowered.com/publisher/2K]2K.[/url]

Release Date : 19th May 2020 (Mafia 2, 23rd August 2010).
Last known update: 19th May 2020.


[h1]üéÆGameplay:[/h1]

[b]Are there any changes as far as gameplay goes?[/b]

[list] [*] [b]Mission design and shooting :[/b]
If you think Mafia 2 is just another ‚Äò‚Äôcopy‚Äô‚Äô game of Grand Theft Auto you‚Äôre totally wrong, the Mafia series really takes the time to make you familiar with controls, movement and shooting, it is a slow paced third person game that sometimes might need a little bit of tactical movement. Mafia makes great use of the run and cover system and enemies usually die within a couple of shots, now level design was great in Mafia 2 as every mission had a different meaning and different way of completing. The level design of Mafia was actually ahead of its time, sadly mechanics weren‚Äôt and the game still feels a little rusty and slow compared to Mafia 3 that does actually have the mechanics as it is a much newer game. So in short, no they did not change anything and I like that decision as it keeps the purity of the game quite high.

[*] [b]Open world potential:[/b]
Granted Mafia 2 didn‚Äôt possess a huge man in 2010 and in today‚Äôs time it is worse, still the city of Empire Bay is extremely detailed with a lot of potential, the NPC and randomly generated humans in the streets of Empire Bay feel alive, for example in the snow timeline of the game you could see random people falling due to the icy roads and this honestly adds a crazy level of detail that is even by today's standards unmatched.Now as far as special events go you basically get nothing, you cannot race your cars not can you play quicktime missions which is kind of lackluster as far as stores and what you can do with your money you get a plethora of options  like boutique stores, vehicle garages and even gun shops.

[*] [b]Weather and other little details:[/b]
Weather and nighttime are actually working real time in the game, out of nowhere it might start raining and the rain is actually noticeable while driving, that's pretty rare for an open world story game that doesn‚Äôt really focus on driving that much. After your cars break down due to multiple fatal hits you can actually go out and repair it yourself just like in the 1950s. Lastly you heal yourself by consuming food and you even get custom cutscenes for this which is a great attention to detail.
[/list]


[h1]üìöStory:[/h1]
You have been warned, spoilers ahead.

Vito Scarletta is the main character and his story starts back in Sicily when his parents decided to avoid the WW2 italian drama and travel to Empire Bay, USA. Vito was both fascinated and disgusted by the city and had to learn the language in order to keep on surviving there.After some years Vito crossed paths with Joe Barbarro and both of them started robbing small shops together as money was low. One day Vito gets caught and gets to the chance to fight for the American army in 1943 in order to defeat Italy. Vito then comes back after an injury in 1945 and after that his mob career took on. First Vito was working for the Clemente family in which he proved useful but after someone snitched on him during the gas stamp mission vito had to serve jail time. While in jail Vito got to know strong people like Leo Galante and obviously joined the Galante prison gang. After proving that Vito is a viable option Galante got Vito out of prison right after Galante took Exit. After being a Free man Vito had only his sister as his mother died while he was a prisoner. Joe offered Vito a spot to work for the Falcone family and Vito happily accepted without seeing the bigger picture, after some breathtaking mission killing former boss Clemente, witnessing Henry's death by the Empire Bay Triads under the command of Mr.Wong and more Vito realises that Falcone wanted to kill all the other Bosses in order to sell Dope freely. In order to combat that Vito had to kill Falcone as Leo Galante ordered Vito to do in order to save himself from all the other families and the Feds.

As mentioned above Mafia 2 got major texture and lighting improvements. Most of the noticeable improvements come within cutscenes where you can clearly see a lot more detail on the skin and hair of character and even their eyes look normal now compared to the OG version. Lighting and textures and even minor geometry fixes are noticeable within EMpire bay.

I was still a teenager when the original came out and I loved it.. however, it seemed that the last third of the game was rushed - which was later confirmed by the game files and the developer. 

This remaster was, therefore, an opportunity to upgrade graphics and gameplay, as well as bring the cut material into the main game. I can confirm that they failed in both these regards. 

The graphical updates are minimal and the work that has been done to Vito's face is quite jarring when looking at the SD side characters that weren't considered important enough for an upgrade. The PhysX software that the game was originally marketed on is actually worse in this version, with the clothes not reacting realistically as the original did - I later found out you can simply delete the 'Cloth' folder within the game files to make it work, but for some reason the developers have still not patched it in the vanilla version. 

Finally, Mafia 2 was well known for having a lot of content cut that was near completion (due to studio pressure) and I was hoping to see some of this in the definitive edition... as it was already all voice acted and therefore the studio would not need any more money going towards re-dubbing the lines. This too was not included. 

Ultimately, this is a huge disappointment. Not because the original game is bad - far from it - but because this remaster could have been so much more, especially at ¬£35! HOWEVER, if you haven't played Mafia 2, you should - just wait until this goes on sale. ¬£10/$13 dollars is worth it.

This game is one of the best in the genre. A great story that you for sure will remember and make you believe you're in some Godfather movie. No other developer ever got close to Hangar 13's depiction of "The Family Life"

However this remaster unfortunately is probably the sloppiest work I've ever seen. When even the classic version runs better, sounds better and looks better. Hear me out, here. This "remaster" mainly added higher resolution textures. But nothing else to it. Increasing the size of the game from 7GB to 40. For no good reason at all. The textures while they do look great, looks completely out of place to the rest of the world of Empire Bay and everyone in it. During a conversation you still see NPC's to your left that is completely untouched or re-textured.

Especially noticable on the landlady in Joe's building. You will find her character everywhere, as well as the "Red Fox" call-girl that shows up pretty much everywhere. Reused assets constantly. Even though this happened in the classic, it's a bit disappointing that no thought were gone into fixing things like this.

What makes the game even worse is all the bugs. It's been out for a while now and very little has been done to eliminate things that never even existed in the Classic version at release. Misaligned cameras, assets clipping (Such as wearing your hat around your throat instead of on your head) Glitching AI that seems more interested in the wall than actually apprehending you. Especially noticable during the robbery where the Irish interrupts you. When escaping from the police, they don't even exit the stairwell to the roof before you shimmy across the billboard. I had to kill them and reload twice, before I got the prompt to shimmy across. And I had to enter the stairwell and blow away the cops that seemed more interested in inspecting their shoes and the wall instead of attempting to chase us.

Another mission where the AI's aim is so good you won't even make it to the first intersection that is about 20 yards in front of you when you start the mission. I did make to the second a few times before I gave up. Restarted the whole mission just to try to get a faster car before exiting the compound after the first meeting with the Chinese.

Everything, even the game play is completely broken in comparison to the classic version of this game while looking old, still at least look homogenous. No textures stand out too much to make it look like it doesn't belong there. Which unfortunately they do a lot here.

There is nothing definite with this version of the game. It's the most disappointing remaster I have ever come across. Not even the PhysX effects work as they should, leading you to delete the folder for clothes for them to at least use the basic ones that Hangar 13 implemented to even work. Unfortunately meaning only YOUR clothes will have some kind of physics while everyone else will look like they came from the original game released 2002. How this ever passed to release is something I will never understand. They should have made a proper remake of it just like they did with the first one. And released it afterwards. I'm happy I got the game for free, courtesy of owning the original game on Steam. At least I didn't lose any money on this. Because it sure feels like a loss. Just buy the original and play through that instead.

Another glitch I forgot to mention is the sound. The volume of the conversations aren't on par with each other. One line will play super loud while another will force you to increase the volume to even hear them speak. A lot of other conversations doesn't play at all. Subtitles ON my friends.
Don't but it if you already have Mafia 2. It would be a waste of money. If you don't have the original Mafia 2 wait for sale before you buy this remastered edition.

Mafia 2: DE. A game developed by Hanger 13 and D3T Studios and Published by 2K Games.

If you're familiar with my Mafia: DE review, you know basically what i'm gonna say here. The Mafia trilogy are up there amongst my favourite of this genre, The grit and violence means they are a cut above the rest, And debatable whether Mafia 2 or 3 reigns as the best of the series in my opinion. I would like to mention here, that i don't quite recall quite what  was available in the original rendition of Mafia 2, So i will be trying to review this as its own title entirely.

Story: 8/10
Having already played Mafia 2, and knowing the ins and outs of the story, the twists and turns in it still captivated me this time around. You play as Vito Scaletta an up and coming criminal in 1940's "Empire Bay" which is essentially just a soft rework of New York of the period. You are busted for some low end crimes and begin the game in service of the army. Upon leaving service you meet up with long time friend Joe Barbaro and your first steps toward becoming a "Made Man" begins. I rated this story so highly not because it isn't a cliche mafia story full of betrayal and intrigue.but because of how fleshed out Vito is as a character. His background, his interests and his personality are all almost readily apparent and begin to develop as the game progresses. I would also like to mention that this game pulls no punches. It's filled to the brim with racism, violence and sex. This adds to the realism of the era's grit and immerses you but its by no means for the faint of heart.

Gameplay: 8/10
+ Movement: A slight increase in mobility from the first game, Vito moves fairly smoothly around the world, his ability to vault short obstacles and that's position on the controller (I play 3PS games with a controller because it allows you to move slower in stealth) makes alot more sense and is far less clunky than it was in the first game. This doesn't mean its without flaws though, Vito still has a hard time navigating tight areas and often will "take cover" against completely irrelevant surfaces and get shot in the face because of it.

+ Gunplay: The gunplay here is hard to argue with, the guns feel effective and powerful and sound completely immersive, When you heart people belting out full mags of a tommy gun into the cover you're hiding behind and you hug it hard because you know peaking will clean your clock.

+ NPC/World Interactions: While the world isn't exactly ALIVE. Because the game takes place in Episodes across a 10 or so year gap, the world changes quite rapidly. But even so, each individual experience is full so to speak with people to talk to, and people living their lives, and you can really feel that as you run and drive Empire Bay's streets. My only qualm is that police seem completely disinterested with the NPC's breaking laws and only focus on you. It would add to the experience if police pulled people over occasionally.

+ Driving: While NOT as immersive as the completely remastered Mafia DE, Mafia 2 DE is still quite a solid driving experience, the cars react like you would imagine they would to the certain environmental effects, rain and snow. But also smashing the rear of you car, leaves quite a significant dent in that spot which was a nice touch.

+/- Fist Fighting: I couldn't decide if this was a positive or negative. Perhaps its both, perhaps its neither, But seeming it takes up a large portion of the game time, I have to mention it. It's great to see the mechanic where you get locked into fist fights with groups, shakes things up from the whole run and gun gameplay, But its not done particularly well here. Its pretty hard to monitor what your opponent is going to do and because Vito isn't particularly agile, he seems to get smacked in the face quite frequently.


- Difficulty: This game is easy. Far too easy even on the hardest difficulty, I don't recall it being so easy the first time i played it through but this time it was a breeze, i wish there was a realistic difficulty where gun shots actually took their effect on you, slowed you down, made your aim weaker etc. But unfortunately the overall difficulty was mild.

- Mission Diversity: One of the things that makes these kinds of games captivating is taking part in a lot of different experiences, The first game pulled this off amazingly. The 2nd..Not so much. There isn't a lot happening here, beyond driving from here to there and fight off waves of enemies until you reach your objective. A strong dynamic for sure, but it gets boring by the 10+ hour mark.

Visuals: 5/10
I was hoping for more, from the definitive edition, the touch ups weren't enough to warrant replaying the game. The game still suffers from what it always has, graphical glitches to make your character and the characters your talking to look completely broken or animations completely broken, breaking the total immersion as a whole. The remaster was almost completely irrelevant. The game is extremely graphically glitchy, in fact the first mission i played i jumped out of the cinematic car, and a woman was half way through the concrete of the footpath. Not a great experience. Surely without a doubt though on a mid to high end PC this game ran flawlessly high frames, Which i would expect no less because much of the world is still geometrical.

Audio: 7/10
Its hard to rate the audio bad here, apart from a few audio glitches that occurred frequently at the start of the game, completely loss of sound in 1 ear on my headphones or crackling as people talk, or completely cutting out entirely. But the soundtrack and audio here was expertly done back in the day, and were made to seem aged even then, It doesn't suffer in the slightest, if nothing else i feel as though it might have helped the immersion.

Overall: 8/10
Mafia 2 was a trophy winner of its time, perhaps the best Mafia game ever made (Up for debate with 3) but the Definitive Edition didn't bring much to the table, the game suffers from what it always suffered from, graphically and gameplay wise, But now suffers from its aged graphics and a new slew of audio concerns. I received this game as a freebie as many who owned the original did, But its really not any different from its original experience. Other than a very limited assortment of face touch ups to make it not seem as old as it is. A worth while experience for the sake of the trilogy but if you are after the same dedication here as the first games Remaster was, you're going to be sorely mistaken. For the price of $70 AUD for the DE trilogy though, i would warrant that price seemingly it included a full remaster, a rework and all the DLC's.

My favorite Mafia game so far (have not finished the og M1 due to it being real clunky these days and because of M1 DE). Has it all imo that it needs to have to be an amazing mafia game. A good story, wtiting (though these two kind of fall appart in the final 3 chapters due to it feeling really rushed with a bit of an abrupt end which is kinda meh) and acting. Great soundtrack. Still some great graphics (for a 2010 game) and physx is always a plus in my book (and the default destructible environments are real nice too and better than any other mafia game by far). The open world is also the best in any mafia game with different types of stores all around the city and side jobs which makes this city feel way more alive than any other mafia game (especially 3...). I also prefer the gunplay and overall feel of the gameplay in this game to the others, even M1 DE in some aspects. My only gripe may be that there is a bit too much just driving around throughout the game for me. Even though it is a part of the series, it gets a bit old sometimes. But why do I not recommend it? Oh i tell you why.

Definitive edition my ass! All of the above is pretty much true for both versions, but there are things that I encounter in this one that I have never encountered in my numerous playthroughs of the classic version. Sure, some minor bugs still carry over (which may be acceptable to some, not me but they do not really get in the way), but there are a couple of GAME BREAKING bugs in this version. I have had to restart 3 chapters because the final mission "locks" up and wont let me progress and crashing a couple of times. I have also encountered numerous dialogue scenes in cars that are broken where every person in the car speaks at the same time making it impossible to understand what anyone is saying. Also the physx effects are downgraded and you need to go into the config files to even unlock some of the missing features. 

Beyond the audio and game glitches, there are a couple of visual bugs too. Some effects even seem like bugs but they are meant to be like that (Lights in the tunnels being blinding and not in a realistic or good way). Performance is also really odd. Sure, the physx looks amazing to this day and the graphics are nice, but 18 fps on a pretty powerful machine is not acceptable. The graphical upgrades are not close to being good enough to warrant the performance impact that it has.

So all in all. Mafia 2 is a great game imo, but Mafia 2 Definitive Edition is an overpriced and inferior product to Classic. If you want to play an amazing game, buy Mafia 2 Classic for cheaper. Definetly not a perfect game, but I still even to this day have alot of fun with the game. But stay away from this edition of it. A true disappointment to all fans of the series.

Mafia II: Definitive Edition is an updated release, a HD remaster, of an already HD game that features enhanced models, textures, changes to lighting and the sound engine of the game. The game does look nicer at in motion. Some changes, like the greasy hair and the somewhat shinier eyes do look a bit strange, and I have noticed a few interesting artifacts with the Ambient Occlusion implementation, but generally, the game does look nicer. The nicer graphics don't necessarily explain the fact the download size of the game is nearly 5 times larger than the original, or the performance hit, but generally, the game does look nicer. As an owner of the original PC version of Mafia II on Steam, I received this version for free, while still keeping the old version in my library, which is a big plus (unlike Rockstar and the 'Complete' Edition of GTA IV that replaced the originals completely).

BUT, there are some issues with this re-release, starting with the first thing you see when you launch the game; the launcher is pointless. When I adjusted my settings so it would run in 1080p Borderless, when the game loaded up, it was rendering out at 480p full screen, but in a 1080p frame, so the game was in a tiny corner of my screen, and I had to navigate and change the options through the in-game options menu to get it running in the correct resolution. After getting the game to run 1080p, Borderless, Maximum settings (minus MSAA, which I ran at 4X and Vignette and Chromatic Aberration off because those effects are bad on a good day), I immediately saw they had re-done the pre-rendered cutscenes. Not just an upscaling, but they had re-done from scratch. The pre-rendered scenes look quite a bit better and might run at a higher framerate as well (which might explain the file size increase somewhat). Then the game crashed. After re-launching, Borderless Windowed Mode no longer worked, and when I tried running it through the options menu, the game threw up a load of messages about Nvidia Apex/PhysX, which is still in this version, but significantly gimped, and with no clear option to enable or disable the effects. Also, despite setting it to skip the launcher, every time I restarted, the launcher would load up first.

Once I got back onto the game, now in Fullscreen instead of Borderless, it loaded the in-game cutscene, and the audio was only going through my left ear on my headset. In-game cutscenes are mono on my setup, not pre-rendered, not actual gameplay, but the in-game scenes are. The shooty shooty bang bang part ran just fine, and audio was normal. The next in-game cutscene also ran in mono. Then the train station cutscene ran normally, then the in-game drive down the hill ran normally, and then the bar cutscene ran in mono. I was able to fix this by changing the in-game audio option to stereo and restarting the game.

Once I got to run around, I saw that the cloth physics were removed. This is disappointing, I have a Nvidia GPU so I was hoping these physics extensions would still work, considering that some PhysX particles are clearly still present, but they are not. Consequently, because some PhysX effects seem to be forced on, there may be a performance hit on AMD GPU's but I do not know for certain so take this statement with a grain of salt. Lacking the full PhysX effect experience has no impact on the actual gameplay, but it is a visual feature that is missing from the Definitive Edition that belies the idea this is the Definitive Edition for some players. Also, note that I did not run the game at an unlocked frame rate, so I can't comment on whether or not they fixed the bugs caused by running at over 100 FPS, such as the slow-motion glitch. Reading around suggests they have fixed them, but I cannot confirm that right now.

Graphically, as mentioned, the remaster is a mixed bag. Faces have benefited the most, but the eyes and hair look a little strange sometimes, appearing far shinier than they did originally. Artwork is generally of a higher resolution, pre-rendered cutscenes are completely rebuilt from scratch to use higher quality assets and run at a higher resolution and framerate. Lighting changes, such as sun effects and shadows have changed, with a stronger Ambient Occlusion process (with mixed results), higher quality shadows, including better actor self-shadowing, and a draw distance that seems to be further pushed back than it was before. The game generally looks better, although some of the artistic changes might throw you off.

Audio-wise, the soundtrack is apparently equal to what was in the base game in 2016, down 16 music tracks from the original release, some of which are on the better known side of soundtrack as well. It's far from what could be a definitive release, not quite on the same level as GTA IV, or the current state of the original Mafia if you buy it on Steam now, but that's little comfort. You are not getting the full original soundtrack experience. Apparently, some further tracks are also missing from the Joe's Adventures DLC pack, but I can't verify that myself, as I don't really want to play this version of Mafia II any further due to those technical issues. There is a mod to re-add the missing music, but you shouldn't have to mod a game to get the original intended experience. Audio mixing, by my ear, sounds a bit off in some places. Some sound effects have been replaced with higher quality assets that again I think work quite well but sound mixing seems off, even after I fixed the mono sound in some of the cutscenes, something still seemed off compared to what I was expecting to hear, as though the sound mixing in-game was wrong, with loud effects playing too quietly, something that does not occur in cutscenes, where instead it seems to lean a lot on my left speaker channel.

Overall, I can't recommend playing this version over the original. It does look nicer, but there are too many issues that make the Definitive Edition an inferior edition to the original version, which is still in your library and included in this versions purchase (or on GoG). Play the classic version instead. It doesn't look far worse (Mafia II still looks quite good) and suffers from far fewer bugs. Because this is a remastered compilation, it doesn't add anything, so you aren't missing out on any additional content unless you want to play the DLC mission packs (which aren't very good to be honest), and the original might not crash as often either.

Mafia II is a great game; the remaster is not the best way to play if you just want to play the game. The new version does not make a good game bad by any means (granted, I stopped playing before the end of hour two because I had enough of having to stop, drop out, tweak and come back to get the damn thing to work), but it is a sub-par re-release. Fortunately, unlike Rockstar, 2K aren't forcing you to use this version if you don't want to and unlike Rockstar's 'Complete Edition' mess, there are actual improvements that can be mentioned. The original release still works perfectly as long as you keep under 100 FPS on modern operating systems, it's also a HD game with a far smaller install size. There are too many drawbacks to truly call this game a definitive release. The classic release is included in this package, unlike GTA IV now, so I would recommend playing that version instead if you've never played Mafia II before.

Mafia II is a remastered edition of the classic game, including better framerates and better visual fidelity. The game takes place in Empire Bay, with a semi-structured open world modeled after New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. The game takes place over the time period of the 1940‚Äôs & 50‚Äôs, with great attention to detail within the world ranging from the architecture, cars and music. The game is told in Chapters with structured missions, controlling Vito in a third person perspective.

If you have not played Mafia II before it is well worth playing, some have been complaining about this edition only being a remaster, but it is still a fantastic game. This game's price point IS ¬£24.99/$30-35. Mafia II Definitive Edition Review

Release Date: 19 May 2020

*Note that I did not play for 2 hours as I was offline for most of the time, it was near 8 hours instead*

Pros:
The Mafia franchise has had its highs and lows and this, is at its peak, if we only consider Mafia II and not the definitive edition that is. The story is rich and although it is increasingly unrealistic to go guns blazing, that serves as a fun entry point for those who are new to the Mafia series. Maintaining its grittiness and your frustration at cops chasing you for speeding and so on. Yes, cops do matter in this game surprisingly. That aspect allows you to play in a more realistic manner aside from the shooting and explosions and that cops do give you a sense for needing to stay in the shadows and to blend in with 1940s and 1950s American society as an Italian immigrant. The story itself makes sense, the characters make sense, the dialogue makes sense and so rather than immersing you in a game such as Mafia II, it more so immerses you into a movie. Every cutscene and action from the original deals like an award winning film featured from the 70s or 80s and could be comparable to greats such as The Godfather and more modern takes such as The Irishman.

Cons:
The definite edition offers an extension pack to you for free. A ****load of bugs, glitches and optimization issues. Luckily, most optimization issues have been fixed except for the random crashes whilst bugs and glitches could range from Vito "getting up" by punching his feet through the bed and eyes pointed in a very unnatural direction during cutscenes. Textures and and coat clippings were also found annoying amongst the populace but I guess it was expected for since it was Hangar 13's job to remaster a timeless game. As they have done a poor job with Mafia III alone, they brought that inexperience into Mafia II purging of anything that is good in the game.

Verdict:
If this was a review about the classic Mafia II, this game would have gotten a higher score, but since it isn't, there isn't much to say before giving it a awfully weak,

A great replay through a fantastic game. For those who haven't enjoyed Mafia 2 before - the game is dripping with character. It has a linear story, though there are plenty of opportunities to wander and explore the world in between. Lots of elements are fairly repetitive, but well executed gameplay and an excellent story authentic to the era provide enough to get thoroughly immersed.

Over the years, Mafia II was always that milestone I knew I had to get it done with at some point, but seeing how I lacked the proper consols and capable PC growing up, It did not go as planned. All I had that related to the game was the same old graphics comparison video with it and GTA IV, however, now and after I played through the marvelous Mafia I, I finally get to taste from this forbidden apple, the game everyone praises to death, to the point where I probably never heard anything negative about it.

Well, the first frame hit, and sweet mother that was a huge step-up, seriously, I played the Definitive Edition that was released a month or two ago, and I did hear that the remaster wasn't that big aside from some texture enhancements and color calibration and oh boy dis it a looker. I don't play the latest Tripple A games so I'm not quite familiar with the state of the art graphics that hit the headlines, but I gotta say, it even holds up to GTA V in some areas and even surpasses it in a few details and gimmicks.

The story. I progress like your typical mafioso saga, even picking up on the first entry's notes, split into chapters with varying time skips that follows this trouble-maker and his childhood friend make it from street crooks to made-men. And the plot really makes you work for it. The levels are challenging especially on the hardest difficulty and even the medium one keeps you on your toes. The shootouts are unforgiving and the cops can get really brutal. I love the wanted system and how you have to be smart and cautions in order to stay low on record.

The driving system was definitely a step up from the first game, although, the simulation option did not add much, almost as if it was never there.

The characters are engaging, take the protagonist, Vito, I would always have Mafia I in higher regard in terms of the story and setting, but Vito takes the cake over Tommy as the main character. He's cool, classy and his development shows. He's like the anti average GTA protagonist where the character can do 180¬∞ between cutscenes and gameplay. Joe was the perfect side-kick, always there for his friends and true to his mafioso identity, brutal but also loyal. So good in fact that the last quote in the game moves you to tears having him as a center. And last but not least, Henry. He always had a faint but persistent presence in the story, not always there but somehow always involved, very likable, and interesting fella.

I wish the game had a Free Ride Mode like the first game because as soon as you finish the story, you're stuck loading previously finished chapters in case you want to do some free-roaming. Thankfully, there were 3 DLCs that unlocked the ability to free-roam as much as you want, moving their story from a per-chapter model to more of a GTA open-ended mission checkpoints scattered all over the map.

All in all, amazing game. Definitely, one to play over and over again. Especially the arcadey DLCs that go all the way leaderboarding on you and all, encouraging replayability and grind.

Why I don't recommend this game and by extension the original Mafia 2. I won't be writing a review of the original Mafia 2 since I would basically be writing most of the same things. However, i'm choosing to review this because in terms of purely cosmetic things it's for sure worse. First off I will give some credit where it's due, the devs of this game didn't ignore the crappy launch and fixed the gamebreaking and annoying bugs. As a downside to that though, that basically renders this game original Mafia 2 with free dlc and some bonus content if you own Mafia 3. So it really adds pretty nothing new. Now yesterday (the day before i'm typing this review.) I marathoned this game starting at the earlier mission I had started on and beat it from the 3rd act to the 15th over about 6 hours. By the time I had gotten to the end my only complaints were how annoying the cops were, the fact that there are several parts where you lose your hard earned weapons afterwards, and that you can't kill any of the bosses yourself during gameplay. However, my biggest complaint and the reason I decided to mark this review negative and also not recommend the original Mafia 2, is the ending. This a GTA clone don't get me wrong on that. I did enjoy the references to Goodfellas, Scarface, and the Shawshank Redemption. However, anyone that as played GTA knows that at the ending of the game when credits roll, you can hit continue and cause carnage and destruction like you never had before on the open world map, because you unlocked all the weapons and cool stuff. Now in this game after the credits roll and you are taken back to the main menu and hit continue story, I was expecting to be taken to the main map for some sandboxing, but instead I got started over at the ending mission. That was one of the biggest gaming disappointments in my entire life.

MAFIA 2 is an all-time classic and one of my favorite games to date. I finished Mafia II (Classic) twice in the past on my old PC. And as devs very generously granted me a free copy of Definitive Edition, I couldn't wait to play it again on my new system and as of right now I'm on chapter 15, specifically going for "Ladies Man" achievement.  
To be very honest, this is a very well made reshade. Lighting, textures, reflections represent the technological advancement we saw since the release of the original. I don't have any negative remarks, except the game could be a bit more optimized in PhysX section and a few very weird bugs.  
Ultra preset PhysX can cause framedrops in very intense gunfight situations in open roads on entry level PCs (Ryzen 1200, 1050Ti, 8GB ram, 10Gb pagefile set on SSD in my case) and I've had a few hiccups while driving under the streetlights inside the tunnels.  
Bugs include texture glitches, character animations etc. The launcher in particular is awful, should NOT have included that, and I had to relocate my Documents folder just to be able to autosave, because the game glitched.

All in all, I'm satisfied with this. Nothing more can be said about story. Linear but deep story about friendship and loss. Voice acting is great, accents really shine on Italian characters. Driving mechanism, cars, music nicely represent 50's era. It's a 7/10 in my book. Good job nonetheless, Hangar 13!

P. S. Eagerly waiting for Mafia remake :P

Let's be clear about what Mafia II Definitive Edition is: it's a very lazy graphical remaster with no other meaningful enhancements made to the original game from a decade ago. You can watch side-by-side comparison videos and see how little noticeable difference there is. Vito has blue eyes now and looks a little more tan? Maybe the textures on cars are a little sharper? Basically this looks like the original game with a reshade mod enabled. Apparently they've fixed some bugs which affected the original game on high refresh rate monitors (I was still a 60hz pleb back when I played the original so I can't say), but in exchange they've removed the PhysX elements for some reason? If you were hoping for, say, some of the additional content notoriously cut during the Mafia II's development to be restored here, fuhgeddaboutit.

Since I got Mafia II Definitive Edition for free for owning the "classic" version of the game, I guess I can't complain too much, but if I paid for this, I'd be upset.

Underwhelming graphical upgrades and cut content "might have beens" aside, Mafia II is still a game worth playing, and didn't get as much respect as it deserved because people expected it to be GTA with fedoras, which it just isn't. However, while it's an enjoyable experience, it's also quite a short one. If you're wanting to play the game for the first time you're looking at paying thirty bucks for 10-15 hours of gameplay, which is a bit dear. If the "classic" edition of the game was still readily available for PC at a lower price (like it was on Steam until the remaster was released...) I'd say just buy that. Buuut it isn't.

That being the case: If you haven't played the game before, get this, but get it on sale. If you've played it before, there is no reason to play the "Definitive Edition" apart from nostalgia, it plays and even looks (almost) exactly the same as the game you remember.
